ticket_types.name: Donation to Travel Support Program Fund

tracks.name: Hands-on Workshops
tracks.description: Hands-on Workshops offer a window into OpenStack training for operators and application developers. Sessions are typically 90 minutes and require RSVP and some prep work. Bring your laptop and walk away with OpenStack skills.

tracks.name: Upstream University
tracks.description: Upstream University is an intensive program designed to share knowledge about the different ways of contributing to OpenStack like providing new features, writing documentation, participating in working groups, and so forth.

tracks.name: Community Building
tracks.description: OpenStack is a large, diverse community with more than 75 user groups, 3,000 developers contributing upstream and hundreds supporting companies. In the community building track, community leaders will share their experiences growing and maturing local communities and discuss new tools, metrics and ongoing diversity initiatives. Content in this track will be viewable across all Summit Categories and should be tailored to the appropriate audience.

tracks.name: Working Groups
tracks.description:
This track is meant for established OpenStack community working groups to organize meetings, share reports and findings. These are primarily collaborative working sessions rather than presentations.*

* Please note: all Working Group/BoF space requests are subject to approval by the Foundation.

tracks.name: Birds of a Feather
tracks.description:
For the first time, the OpenStack Summit will formalize BoF sessions as part of the call for speakers. BoFs are not presentations or working sessions; they provide a chance for the community to gather informally around a specific topic. Topics should be non-commercial and relevant for the OpenStack community.*

* Please note: all Working Group/BoF space requests are subject to approval by the Foundation.

tracks.name: Evaluating OpenStack
tracks.description: From evaluating OpenStack to planning your cloud transition, this track covers the basics of what you need to know from a business perspective to get started with OpenStack.

tracks.name: Case Studies
tracks.description: Sharing knowledge is a core value for the OpenStack community. In the case studies track, you'll hear directly from end users, service providers and application developers who are using OpenStack to address their business problems. Learn challenges, best practices and measured results.

tracks.name: Telecom & NFV Strategy
tracks.description: 86% of global telecoms report OpenStack important to their success. In this track, telecoms will cover the value of OpenStack and open source standards to address leading use cases like IoT, NFV and 5G.

tracks.name: Products, Tools, and Services
tracks.description: How do your existing tools mix with OpenStack? How do tools your dev team is asking for fit within an OpenStack framework? Sessions in this track will answer the "OpenStack and..." question from a business perspective. OpenStack is surrounded by a vibrant network of tools and services, and in this track you'll come to understand what's possible, what's best practice, and where to go from here.

tracks.name: Cultural & Organizational Change
tracks.description: Open source success requires organizational cultures that support it. This track will discuss developing and nurturing cultures that support open source success, recruiting in the OpenStack ecosystem, and developer satisfaction.

tracks.name: CIO Cloud Strategy
tracks.description: Now that you're starting with OpenStack, tackle the details and strategy decisions, from choosing the right cloud model, planning multiple environments, optimizing costs, meeting regulatory requirements and mitigating risks.

tracks.name: Architectural Decisions
tracks.description: If you are a cloud architect or involved in planning your cloud strategy, this track will discuss proven reference architectures, configuration options, workload optimization, and experienced users will share their architectures and experiences.

tracks.name: Operations War Stories
tracks.description: Sharing knowledge and best practices is a core value for the OpenStack community. In this track, you'll hear directly from fellow cloud architects and operators who will share their stories from the trenches and lessons learned.

tracks.name: Networking
tracks.description: The networking track will feature technical presentations, use cases, design and implementation discussions relevant to cloud networking, specifically topics like SDN, scale, IPv6, policies, HA and performance.

tracks.name: Storage
tracks.description: The storage track will feature technical presentations, use cases, design and implementation discussions relevant to cloud storage and OpenStack.

tracks.name: How To & Best Practices
tracks.description: This track is about what it takes to run OpenStack in production. Automation, upgrade management, efficient tool use, cluster management, and other topics that production users encounter and want to discuss, learn and improve. If you're already running OpenStack in production, join other users in the Forum for advanced working sessions to collaborate on enhancing the OpenStack software and ops tools.

tracks.name: Security
tracks.description: Technical presentations, design and implementation discussions relevant to security and OpenStack.

tracks.name: HPC / Research
tracks.description: HPC and HTC continue to be popular use cases for OpenStack, allowing operators to run workloads on standard hardware rather than supercomputers. In this track, we'll discuss reference architectures, best practices and case studies for high performance computing.

tracks.name: Telecom / NFV Operations
tracks.description: This track will cover technical presentations, design and implementation discussions relevant to telecom operators and architects. Navigate the growing telecom ecosystem of emerging projects, cross-community collaboration and leading use cases.

tracks.name: Project Updates
tracks.description: Hear directly from technical contributors and project leads on the latest features and project roadmaps.

tracks.name: OpenStack Ops 101
tracks.description: Are you new to the OpenStack ops community? The sessions in this track will give you OpenStack 101, including an overview of the technology, navigating the ops community, and using the tools of the OpenStack project.

tracks.name: Ops Tools
tracks.description: OpenStack provides cloud infrastructure services, but there are many other tools that come into play when operating a full cloud environment. In this track, you'll learn from fellow operators and cloud experts about popular open source and commercial tools, including monitoring, billing, lifecycle management, and more.

tracks.name: Big Data
tracks.description: Learn about specific reference architectures and use cases for big data, along with updates on relevant OpenStack projects like Sahara, which rapidly provisions Hadoop or Spark clusters for big data analysis.

tracks.name: Cloud App Development
tracks.description: A large community of application developers and ecosystem of development tools is growing around OpenStack. This track will be for users who are building and deploying applications on OpenStack clouds, and cover topics like automating and managing application deployment, application software configuration, SDKs, tools, PaaS and big data.

tracks.name: Containers
tracks.description: OpenStack provides a single platform and set of APIs for virtual machines, bare metal and containers. OpenStack is a prime deployment environment for containers, but many organizations are also starting to use containers to deploy OpenStack. In this track, learn how containers fit with OpenStack, including reference architectures, use cases and updates from OpenStack projects like Magnum, Kolla and Kuryr.

tracks.name: Upstream Development
tracks.description: Upstream development sessions are targeted toward prospective and existing contributors, to discover new processes, learn about common cross-project features or libraries you should adopt in your project, or share best development practices.

tracks.name: How to Contribute
tracks.description: The How to Contribute track is for community members and companies interested in contributing to the OpenStack code, with a focus on the community processes, tools and best practices.

tracks.name: Community Building - Architecture & Operations
tracks.description: OpenStack is a large, diverse community with more than 75 user groups, 3,000 developers contributing upstream and hundreds supporting companies. In the community building track, community leaders will share their experiences growing and maturing local communities and discuss new tools, metrics and ongoing diversity initiatives. Content in this track will be viewable across all Summit Categories and should be tailored to the appropriate audience.

tracks.name: Community Building - Developers
tracks.description: OpenStack is a large, diverse community with more than 75 user groups, 3,000 developers contributing upstream and hundreds supporting companies. In the community building track, community leaders will share their experiences growing and maturing local communities and discuss new tools, metrics and ongoing diversity initiatives. Content in this track will be viewable across all Summit Categories and should be tailored to the appropriate audience.

track_groups.name: OpenStack Academy
track_groups.description: With a focus on education and training for cloud operators and application developers, the OpenStack Academy brings together hands-on workshops and day-long intensive training sessions under one roof. Workshops and trainings require an RSVP and certain pre-requisites. Bring your laptop and walk away with OpenStack skills.

track_groups.name: The Forum
track_groups.description:
At The Forum, OpenStack users and developers in equal parts gather to brainstorm the requirements for the next release, gather feedback on the past version and have strategic discussions that go beyond just one release cycle. Development teams, working groups and interested individuals will discuss release requirements, connect with community members about cross-project collaboration, and to exchange feedback between design and operations members. These are collaborative, interactive group working sessions.

* Note: these are not selected through the Call for Presentations process and submission is limited to WG chair/leader

track_groups.name: Business & Strategy
track_groups.description: IT leaders building their cloud business case are facing unique requirements to move faster and control costs within the bounds of industry regulations and business realities. For business decision makers and those who are interested in topics like financial impact, organizational change, and business products to enhance and support your deployment, case studies in this track are presented from a business perspective, where you can learn why and how organizations adopted OpenStack.

track_groups.name: Architecture & Operations
track_groups.description: For cloud architects, operators and administrators who are looking for technical sessions--ranging from beginner to advanced--that will help you improve your current deployment, learn new tools or understand how to get an OpenStack cloud up and running.

track_groups.name: Developers
track_groups.description: The Developers category will cover developing cloud applications, making the most of containers, delivering valuable services like big data analytics, as well as presentations and help getting started for upstream contributors. Please note that Project Updates will no longer be open to submissions through the Call for Presentations; PTLs will be programming this content for the Boston Summit.

schedule.title: Kuryr&Fuxi: delivering OpenStack Networking and Storage to Docker swarm containers
schedule.description:
Running microservices on Docker Swarm simplifies significantly the application lifecycle and orchestration management. However, the infrastructure aspects of these deployments when run in-house may raise quite a few questions.

In this talk we will focus on how OpenStack can bring its production ready VMs, Networking and Storage to make Swarm clusters fit well in your datacenter thanks to Kuryr-libnetwork and Fuxi.

Kuryr-libnetwork brings Neutron networking to Docker containers whether they run on bare-metal or in Nova instances. In the Barcelona Summit we demoed containers in Nova instances getting IPAM from Neutron. Now we will show how you can also configure Kuryr to get a a Neutron subport per container.

Fuxi brings OpenStack Storage (Cinder, Manila, etc.) to Docker with its focus on container persistence. In this talk we will show how you can manage your stateful containerized applications by just using the native Docker API thanks to Fuxi and Cinder volumes.
schedule.social_description: Kuryr-libnetwork and Fuxi bringing Neutron ports and Cinder volumes all the way to your containers
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Docker networking features brought by Kuryr-libnetwork
  • Docker storage features brought by Fuxi
  • Kuryr-libnetwork design and architecture
  • Fuxi design and architecture
  • How kuryr-libnetwork and kuryr-kubernetes networks containers inside Nova instances
  • How Fuxi enables container persistency inside Nova instances

schedule.title: Around the world in 80 commits:  working with a global team and global community
schedule.description: Working with remote teams is not always easy:  different timezones, different communication styles, different cultures.  But what do you do when your immediate team is remote and you're working with a worldwide open source community?  The IBM mainframe OpenStack team is spread across three continents (NA, Asia and Europe) and has faced a fair share of challenges with integrating their team together and into the OpenStack community.  Over the past year, AT&T launched a new distributed team of Community contributors. They also initiated a new working group with globally distributed participation. They have been struggling with the challenges of working effectively as a team across a diverse geographies and cultures.  The discussion will deal with tips for tools and teamwork.  We'll also talk about what challenges we still face.  At the end there will be plenty of time for audience questions and a panel style discussion.
schedule.social_description: How can you bring your devs closer to each other & OpenStack? Come & hear about global collaboration
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn what's worked and hasn't worked for two companies managing distributed teams across OpenStack.  They'll discover tools and techniques that have made these companies successful.  They'll also get a chance to ask questions about their own challenges.

schedule.title: Optimizing Swift To Gain High Performance For LOSF In Product Environment
schedule.description:
Swift suffers from significant performance degradation when it has to handle lots of small files(0~100KB) because objects are stored as separated files in backend. At iQiyi, we have developed a new durability interface on Hummingbird which is a reimplementation of Swift with Golang. Benchmark shows that write performance of the new interface is about 3X faster under heavy concurrent writes without sacrificing the read performance.  And there is no degradation when the number of small objects grows which we believe is of great importance. 

In this talk, we will discuss the design and implementation of the new durability interface such as

  • Pack multiple small objects into a single POSIX file
  • Manage metadata and index effectively with RocksDB
  • Locate the objects without modifying current ring mechanism
  • Incremental object replicator based on RocksDB transaction log to achieve eventual consistency
  • Background garbage collector to reclaim deleted space
schedule.social_description: Optimize Swift with lots of small objects by new disk file interface packing multiple small files
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Why Swift performance degrades when it comes to lots of small files applications
  • The on disk format of the new disk file interface, namely about how to pack small objects
  • How to manage the objects' metadata and index data with RocksDB
  • How to locate the physical position of an object with current Ring mechanism and index
  • How to implement a new incremental object replicator based on RocksDB transaction log to achieve eventual consistency
  • How to implement a background garbage collector to reclaim deleted spaces

schedule.title: Image Build as a Service - Why it makes sense to build your own Cloud Images
schedule.description:
What if the community or vendor provided cloud images do not fit your requirements?
Like when your cloud needs to offer

  • high performance drivers
  • additional security hardening
  • support for different hypervisors
  • images with latest available patches
  • cloud-specific preconfiguration (e.g. repositories)

For our public cloud "Open Telekom Cloud" we decided to build our own images. Utilizing open-source tools like OpenBuildService, kiwi, DiskImageBuilder, OpenStack tools, adn git we build public images, optimized to run on OTC.
This includes fully automated build, testing and publishing of the images. Following this approach we are able to adapt changes fast, including security patches, hardening and customization.

The image configurations are signed and published along with the resulting images.
This session presents how we build images and how you could build upon this work to set up your own factory, maybe extending it to build container images as well?
schedule.social_description:
ImageFactory@OpenTelekomCloud
Why it makes sense to build your own Cloud Images
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The Openstack community and most vendors provide cloud-ready OS images, but modifications are often required to make them fit well to the requirements of the underlying cloud.
In OTC we build our own images because upstream images are lacking important features like e.g. high performance drivers and support for hypervisors besides of KVM.
In this session we present, why it makes sense to build you own cloud images.
And what are the important pieces for an own Image Build Environment setup.

Learnings:

* Requirements for having own cloud images
* Architecture and Setup of an ImageFactory Build Environment
* Ways to automate testing of the images
* Where to get the OTC cloud images and make use of them

schedule.title: Deploying designate for disaster recovery
schedule.description: Disaster recovery (DR) is one of most important use cases that we hear from our customers. Setting up multi region designate for disaster recovery scenario significantly minimizes the impact on dns data in the event of disaster, as designate pushes customer zones across multiple regions so that the customer will be unaffected in case of disaster in one region. In this session we will see how designate can be configured in multi regions for disaster recovery in public cloud environment . And also showcase a small demo on how designate feature and services can be leveraged for disaster recovery process.
schedule.social_description: Deploying designate for disaster recovery
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Setting up multi region designate for disaster recovery scenario significantly minimizes the impact on dns data in the event of disaster This talk helps the audience to understand on various designate features and also how to setup designate in multi region environment

schedule.title: Kubernetes on OpenStack on Kubernetes - The Infrastructure Club Sandwich
schedule.description:
OpenStack on Kubernetes? Kubernetes on OpenStack? How about Kubernetes on OpenStack on Kubernetes? This fun and technical session will go over some reference architectures of Kubernetes in conjunction with OpenStack both above and below.  

We review the requirements and challenges of OpenStack which can be solved by using Kubernetes, as well as the needs of providing Kubernetes on top of the IaaS layers to satisfy both infrastructure and developer requirements.
schedule.social_description: Kubernetes on OpenStack on Kubernetes - The Infrastructure Club Sandwich
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees wil come away with:

  • Understanding of the architectural choices needed to host Kubernetes workloads
  • Knowledge of the Kubernetes underlying infrastructure needed to support the OpenStack control layer
  • Requirements that drive the multi-layer approach

schedule.title: Scalable LBaaS backend: using Kubernetes and ECMP
schedule.description:
The number of compute nodes handled in our OpenStack region are increasing from hundreds to thousands.
In such condition, load balancers are required to scale out flexibly as traffic increases.
However, it is difficult to realize these functions using traditional master-slave hardware loadbalancer
So, we developed and deployed scalable software load balancer in our production environment.

This load balancer system can increase capacity by just adding LB-node.
We developed the following components to realize the function:
- IP Fabric: The network that have capabilities of High bandwidth and ECMP(Equal Cost Multipath)
- ECMP: Incoming packets are distributed to each LB-node
- Bird: Advertising VIP to IP Fabric with BGP
- LB-node: Commodity server
- Kuberntes: Orchestration suitable for distributed environment

We will present the architecture and findings gained from this initiative.
schedule.social_description: We developed and started using load balancer which scales out using Kubernetes for LBaaS.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
- Thinking and designing about the development of load balancer to scale out.
- Architecture and findings gained by using load balancer with Kubernetes.

schedule.title: Project Update - Barbican
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Barbican and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Barbican plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

 

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Barbican PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Learnings from Scaling openstack Ironic at Yahoo
schedule.description:
Yahoo has hundreds and thousands of servers in data centers. Recently we deployed openstack ironic to manage some of these hardware. As we imported new nodes into ironic, we faced number of challenges related to scale. In this talk we will talk about how we scaled and optimized components such nova-compute, ironic-conductor, neutron-dhcp-agent and solved problems related to baremetal provisioning

 

The talk will have five key components:

1. Problems with nova-compute in scale and how we solved them

2. Scaling neutron-dhcp-agent with dhcpd driver

3. Scaling ironic-conductors 

4. Dealing with hardware/firmware and ipmi issues in the data centers

5. Future work.
schedule.social_description: Ironic at Yahoo scale.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: People who are interested in large scale systems. Openstack Ironic.

schedule.title: Hybrid Cloud war stories: Building a next-gen TV and media platform using OpenStack and AWS
schedule.description:
This session will detail the operational and technical challenges SkyTV (New Zealand's leading TV provider) have had in introducing OpenStack to their environment: from creating a specialised 'Cloud Ops' team to run and manage the platform all the way through to educating the wider business about the operational benefits OpenStack would provide.
Details will be provided on the technical solution put in place, and how SkyTV have used Heat, Ansible & other automation technologies to rapidly provision, update and manage complex application and networking environments across both public and private clouds. SkyTV have built a truly hybrid cloud platform based on OpenStack and AWS, and we want to share their expertise on how to make development and deployment processes seamless across both platforms.
schedule.social_description: Building a next-gen media & TV platform using OpenStack and AWS. Automation everywhere!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees should expect to learn how to start the 'journey' of bringing an OpenStack cloud into production. This includes some gotchas, how to bring and keep the company along for the ride and maintaining harmony with developers and IT ops.

There will also be the opportunity to learn how OpenStack can seamlessly fit into an existing CI/CD pipeline driven by Bamboo.

Automation experts can learn how to start maximising the usage of Heat with robust templates that produce a complex, multi-tiered architecture across many networks and projects. There will be discussion around how to drive Heat with Ansible and make sure that the right tool is doing the right job. 

Attendees will also have access to versions of the Heat templates and scripts used in the SkyTV environment, shared via GitHub.

schedule.title: Configure Your Cloud for Auto-Recovery
schedule.description:
All technology fails.  There is no getting around this point.  The part that we can influence out of that statement is what happens when the technology fails.  OpenStack in all its marvelous modular glory can be a bear when you encounter the service failure creep.  You know that think which occurs when one service fails and then causes another service to fail...then on and on.

Imagine if you could configure your OpenStack services to automatically recovery.  Yes, I know you are going to say I can do that with a cron job or something alike.  For a second think of the impact if you could link your monitoring system to another one that will trigger automated recovery processes to restore your OpenStack services without human intervention.

This workshop will walk attendees thru the process of linking a monitoring system such as Nagios to an automated recovery system such as StackStorm to produce auto-recovery OpenStack cloud actions.
schedule.social_description: Use Nagios and StackStorm to auto-recover your OpenStack services.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Attendees will learn a bit about what services should be monitored with Nagios
  • Learn some baseline threshold you can set for your monitoring events
  • Become familar with StackStorm, an open source triggered auto-remediation tool
  • Explore how you can link the two tools together to setup auto-recovery for your OpenStack services

schedule.title: Securing Web Applications with Service Chaining
schedule.description:
Securing a multi-tier web application requires a number of security functions resulting in complex layer 3 networking rules introducing error and network latency. Instead, OpenStack can service chain traffic through security functions using layer 2 constructs to reduce complexity and improve performance.


In this lab, students will be provided with an OpenStack cloud, a vulnerable web application and security functions to protect it (virtualized security machines) to protect a web application. The lab has students configure service chaining to flow traffic through all the required security functions reducing the complexity, latency and operational costs. A vulnerability scanner is available for students to validate that the security functions are indeed in place and protecting the application. This lab is run completely on open source software.
schedule.social_description: Fed up with complex networking required to secure apps? Service chaining makes it easy!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This lab educates attendees on the how to utilize virtual networking to easily introduce network security functions into the traffic flow without having to re-engineer the layer 3 networks. This includes using Heat, Nova and Neutron through the Horizon and OpenStack command line clients

Attendees will also learn how to protect web applications utilizing open source network security software available in the lab as virtual machines. This includes using network vulnerability scanners to validate that the security functions are indeed protecting the website.

schedule.title: Discover All-Flash Ceph for High Performance Storage Pool
schedule.description:
NUMA topology in storage for OpenStack provide high-level control which help users minimize latency and maximize performance. According to our experience, users are keen to know how to make Ceph run faster for I/O intensive workloads. Many companies are looking for Ceph that can provide high IOPS to run databases or mission critical applications. In order to achieve certain IOPS per Ceph cluster, the conﬁguration of Ceph parameters, PCIe SSDs and hardware plays a critical role. It also drives the demand of the server with NUMA design, which beneﬁts the Ceph performance and lowers the latency.

In this session, we'll share performance analysis and ﬁndings of all-ﬂash Ceph on a NUMA-balanced server when running MySQL workloads. You will learn how a server design and conﬁgurations affect the Ceph performance and best practices to conﬁgure IOPS-optimized Ceph for OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: How All Flash and NUMA Design Make Ceph Faster for IOPS-Intensive Workloads
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Performance analysis and ﬁndings of all-ﬂash Ceph when running IOPS-intensive workloads on a NUMA-balanced server.
  • Hardware design and conﬁgurations affect the Ceph performance
  • Best practices to conﬁgure IOPS-optimized Ceph.

schedule.title: How to KVM/QEMU tuning of NUMA and memory
schedule.description:
In this presentation, we will introduce the tuning of NUMA and memory of KVM / QEMU virtual machine.
It will explain tuning of NUMA, hugepages and malloc, and we show the results of each benchmark.

  • NUMA
    • Number of numa nodes
  • hugepages
    • No use
    • 2MB
    • 1GB
  • malloc
    • glibc malloc
    • tcmalloc
    • jemalloc

We will introduce our best practices, derived from the results of the benchmark.
schedule.social_description: How to KVM/QEMU tuning of NUMA and memory.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: • How to KVM/QEMU tuning of NUMA and memory

schedule.title: Turbo Charged VNFs at 40 gbit/s. Approaches to deliver fast, low latency networking using OpenStack.
schedule.description:
High-speed networking, beyond 10 gig in OpenStack is still a very
challenging area. OpenStack has 3 possible approaches:  SR-IOV, DPDK enabled
virtual switch, or offload via intelligent network adapters. SR-IOV while
offering high throughput and low latency, limits advanced features such as
VXLAN and MPLS based segmentation, security groups and live migration. DPDK
based approaches support live migration, VXLAN and MPLS based segmentation
and security groups but require significant host resources in order to
process the packets. Intelligent network adapters offer best of both worlds, fast throughput and advanced features while using minimal host resources.


This presentation will detail advantages and disadvantages of various
approaches. We will describe our experience in working with Netronome to
integrate Agilio SmartNic with OpenContrail and Mirantis OpenStack, provide
comparative benchmarks between vRouter DPDK and Agilio and show a quick
demo.
schedule.social_description: Turbo Charging OpenStack to 40 gbits/s. Compare vRouter DPDK and Agilio based implementations.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how to build OpenStack networks to deliver 40-gigabit performance, advantages and disadvantages of various high-speed approaches and how to integrate Agilio into OpenStack and Open Contrail and

schedule.title: Object Migration from different storage cloud to OpenStack Swift
schedule.description: One of the key aspects to consider while moving from an on-prem storage system or from a storage cloud to OpenStack swift is how to migrate the existing data to OpenStack swift. This session talks about a tool which one can use to migrate data from an object store and even Filesystem, to OpenStack Swift. This will help user to move to OpenStack Swift easily. The tool is based on OpenStack “On Demand Migration” Middleware (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/64430/) with added support for features like multi-part upload for migrating large objects, S3 ACL and few more. We will also demonstrate migration of data to Openstack Swift as part of this session.
schedule.social_description: Object migration from different storage clouds to OpenStack swift
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this talk attendees will learn :
1. About middleware used to fetch objects from source cloud storage.
2. How we automated the entire data migration process using certain drivers.
3. How large objects are migrated from source to openstack swift by doing multi-part upload.
4. How S3 ACL are migrated to openstack swift, and how using swift3 middleware we can access S3 ACL
5. Changes done to libcloud to access S3 acl and addition of new regions.
6. We will also demonstrate some use cases of object migration from S3 to swift, swift to swift and filesystem to swift.

schedule.title: A Series of Unfortunate Deployments: Running a Lambda Architecture on OpenStack
schedule.description:
We share the harrowing tale of a team of operators, devops engineers, and developers as they pursue their goal of deploying a scalable, high-performance chemistry search engine based on the Lambda architecture in Openstack.  This is not a story for the faint of heart, dear listener.

Tragedies in this talk include:

  • Laggard networks! (VXLAN/VLAN and Cisco ACI technology)
  • Murderous kernels! (CPU pinning and pre-allocated hugepages)
  • Recalcitrant storage! (Cinder backed with EMC XtremeIO; Problems found in os-brick and multipathd)
  • Mysterious APIs! (Reactive orchestration with Apache jClouds)
schedule.social_description: Running a Lambda Architecture on OpenStack.  A harrowing tale filled with tragedy (and success)!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This is the story of our team’s efforts to deploy a Lambda architecture search engine on Openstack, showcasing the trials and tribulations we encountered on our journey.  We share both what worked for us and what didn’t.  How taking advantage of all that Nova Compute offers made this deployment a success. We also highlight the importance of the Openstack operators working closely with developers to ensure maximize performance and stability.  Openstack is excellent for all things, but best when both devs and operators tailor the environment to match the expected workloads.

schedule.title: No longer considered an Epic Spell of Transformation: IN-PLACE UPGRADE!
schedule.description: Welcome to the magical school of Triple-O where impossibilities are not only possible, but a reality! Upgrade from Mitaka to Newton? Sure, we can do that and YOU can too! Let us show you the value of TripleO Magic! In place upgrades is only one item in our bag of tricks (that can be YOUR bag of tricks too!) Come join us while we show you how to conjure a rock solid OpenStack environment that has continuous validations running to ensure stability throughout the entire lifecycle of that cloud even THROUGH your in-place upgrade! This isn't a cookie cutter deployment either! Customizations abound! The reference architecture not working for you? Use your magic wand to create custom composable roles and deploy YOUR cloud YOUR way!
schedule.social_description: In-place upgrade capabilities of Triple-O.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn how Triple-O project evolved and became the best OpenStack installer and Ops Tool. Learn the process of installing, maintaining and upgrading OpenStack.

schedule.title: Adobe Advertising Cloud: The Reality of Cloud Bursting with OpenStack
schedule.description:
After successfully moving a large workload from a Public Cloud to an OpenStack Private Cloud, the former TubeMogul Operations Engineering team tackled its next important step toward Cloud Bursting.

While experiencing hyper-growth on the Adobe Advertising Cloud, the team had to figure out a simple way to quickly provision new compute resources. Our latency critical workload need our core private resources while some workload can safely leverage public cloud. Cloud Bursting helped to ensure rapid support of the business and provide a more flexible capacity planning strategy. Being able to burst some workload back to the Public Cloud allowed the team to leverage the best of public and private cloud.

In this presentation, we will detail how the team dealt with the network complexity between clouds infrastructure, the cost effectiveness of cloud bursting, the impact on performance, and the hard reality of multi-cloud environments.
schedule.social_description: Discover how Adobe's Advertising Cloud leverage cloud bursting with OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This talk will cover the technical detail of:

  • Bursting workload from an OpenStack private cloud to AWS public cloud
  • The network constraints and challenges while doing cloud bursting
  • What would be the next steps toward full cloud bursting capabilities with multiple public cloud provider like AWS, Azure, and GCP.
  • Lesson Learned and Post Cost Analysis

schedule.title: Kubernetes and OpenStack at Scale
schedule.description:
Imagine being able to stand up thousands of tenants with thousands of apps, running thousands of Docker-formatted container images and routes, all on a self-healing cluster and elastic infrastructure. Now, take that one step further - all of those images being updatable through a single upload to the registry, and with zero downtime. In this session, you will see just that.

In this presentation, we will walk through a recent benchmarking deployment using Kubernetes and OpenStack on the Cloud Native Computing Foundation’s (CNCF's) 1,000 node cluster with OpenStack and Red Hat’s OpenShift Container Platform, the enterprise-ready Kubernetes for developers. 

You'll also what's been happening in subsequent rounds of testing in Red Hat's own SCALE lab and the CNCF cluster and how we are working with the relevant open source communities including OpenStack, Kubernetes, and Ansible to continue to raise the bar for horizontal scaling of these platforms via community powered innovation.
schedule.social_description: Kubernetes and OpenStack at Scale using the 1000 node CNCF cluster
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about the preparation that was required to run Kubernetes on OpenStack at scale, the architecture of the resultant deployment and some of the issues and best practices identified along the way.

They will also learn how to gain access to the CNCF and OSIC clusters for their own community projects and how the results of these scale testing exercises are being shared with the relevant open source communities as we work together to raise the bar for horizontal scaling of these platforms.

schedule.title: Looking beyond the technology: Privacy, Trust and Security in the cloud
schedule.description:
The adoption of cloud computing and the migration of applications to the platform is rapidly transforming how businesses and individuals perform their regular day to day functions. More than a trillion dollars will be spent in the next five years, directly or indirectly, to shifting processes to the cloud. According to Gartner, "This will make cloud computing one of the most disruptive forces of IT spending since the early days of the digital age."

As the world rapidly transistions to the cloud, it's important to consider not just the technical advantages this change provides but also think about the potential non-technical risks. This talk looks at the social and political issues surrounding the current state of privacy and security in cloud computing and the trust we place in others.
schedule.social_description: Discussing the social and political issues surrounding privacy and security in cloud computing.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This talk will attempt to show the current landscape of the cloud, raise existing social and political issues and discuss how corporations and citizens are addressing these concerns. It will also consider the role of privacy and how the cloud can positively and negatively affect security.

The shift to the cloud is upon us and we're at the forefront in development to shaping what it will become.

Disclaimer: There may be a bias in discussion towards North American and Canadian issues considering the country of origin of the presenter.

schedule.title: Lessons in IPv6 deployment in OpenStack environments
schedule.description:
More operators are deploying OpenStack environments using IPv6 due to the IPv4 address exhaustion. Recent releases of OpenStack supports production quality of IPv6 deployments for tenantsby leveraging the combination of Neutron features.

This session will cover the following topics:

  • IPv6 deployments options and consideration points
  • IPv6 address configuration options and comparisons (SLAAC, DHCPv6 stateless, DHCPv6 stateful)
  • IPv6 global address management: Using neutron subnet pool feature / Using prefix delegation
  • Routing considerations: dynamic routing from upstream router to tenant routers / prevent unauthorized global address
  • Points on IPv4/IPv6 dual stack : Configurations of Additional information like DNS servers, MTU or static routes
  • Both of Neutron reference implementation and third party virtual appliances are discussed.

This session will focus on being a guide on setup and operation on IPv6 deployment.
schedule.social_description: Guide and lessons on how to deploy IPv6 OpenStack environments in production.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This session will focus on being a guide on setup and operation on IPv6 deployment. Attendees of this session can get practical guide on IPv6 deployments like below. Examples on detail configuration and command lines will be provided.

  • IPv6 deployments options and consideration points
  • IPv6 address configuration options and comparisons (SLAAC, DHCPv6 stateless, DHCPv6 stateful)
  • IPv6 global address management (neutron subnet pool feature, prefix delegation)
  • Routing considerations
  • Points on IPv4/IPv6 dual stack
  • IPv6 on Neutron refence implementation and third party virtual appliances.

schedule.title: Project Update - Blazar
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Blazar and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.


We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.


Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Blazar plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.


Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Blazar PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: OpenStack and Windows -  What's new in Ocata
schedule.description:
OpenStack is a great platform for Linux as well as for Windows, with the latter growing stronger every year as OpenStack gains more momentum in the enterprise world.

Microsoft's Windows Server / Hyper-V Server 2016 includes a lot of new cloud oriented features which are fully supported in an OpenStack infrastructure, including Storage Spaces Direct for hyper-converged deployments, Shielded VMs for the best guest isolation, Nano Server, a new networking stack and much more.

Windows as a guest on any hypervisor, including KVM, Hyper-V, ESXi, is also a great match for OpenStack thanks to Cloudbase-Init's large set of cloud provisioning actions and support for Heat templates, with lots of new features developed during the Ocata timeframe. 

During this session we will talk about all the new OpenStack Windows and Hyper-V related features, demo some great use cases and provide answers to the most common questions about how to make the best out of Windows in OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: Windows and OpenStack are a great match. Here's what Windows and Hyper-V can bring to your cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about new Windows and Hyper-V features in Keystone, Nova, Cinder, Neutron and other OpenStack projects.

The session will also provide a list of answers to common Windows OpenStack questions, especially oriented at people with an OpenStack and Linux background that look at expanding their knowledge into how Windows enterprise requirements can fit in the picture.

schedule.title: Fifty Shades of Enrollment:  How to use Certmonger to win OpenStack
schedule.description:
When securing the Openstack services by deploying them behind TLS, we need to figure out how to automatically obtain and manage the required certificates.  Certmonger has long been used for precisely this purpose, but the instance needs credentials.


This talk will explore how a new Nova micro-service (novajoin) is used to enroll nova instances as FreeIPA clients, which in turn provides the credentials to get certificates for hosts and services. Moreover, we get the abilities to implement centralized host and sudo access controls.
schedule.social_description: This talk will explore how to use novajoin to enroll instances as FreeIPA clients.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how to use novajoin - a new Nova micro-service, to register Nova instances as IPA clients.  This, in turn, will allow you to use certmonger to issue and manage host and service certficates for TLS, and to enforce centralized host and sudo access control.

schedule.title: test lunch2
schedule.description: test lunch 2
schedule.social_description: test lunch 2

schedule.title: Who left the lights on again?  Dealing with inefficient cloud usage
schedule.description: So your organization has adopted the cloud.  You've been tasked with deployment of an hybrid model.  Great! You have your OpenStack cloud and your public cloud... then you find out your organization is relying on a second Cloud Service Provider, then a third.  The all of the sudden, the CFO drops in your office asking what's up with all of the rising costs?  Who is monitoring those virtual systems being idle?  How do you get development team to adopt a responsible use of resources that are eating away at your operational budget? These are all questions that we had to address in our journey to the cloud.  Come learn some of the simple and not-so-simple solutions we have deployed to optimize our usage.
schedule.social_description: Who left the lights on again?  Dealing with inefficient cloud usage
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How an internal cloud brokerage approach can help manage costs and ensure that optimal usage is made of both the OpenStack cloud and the various public providers using techniques to monitor usage, increase workload density and tracking costs.

schedule.title: Building and using private clouds in Retail
schedule.description: Many retail companies struggle to remain relevant in a changing market. Embracing Openstack can enable companies to move faster in all facets of their business. From online sales, to web point of sale in stores, and even pipeline and manufacturing capabilities.
schedule.social_description: Openstack can aid any size company decrease time to market and enable technological agility.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How Gap, Inc. uses private cloud and the benefits its business units see from its use. How Gap, Inc. has enabled devops, user self service, and a multi-billion dollar omini pipeline using Openstack.

schedule.title: Show me my packet log - Neutron packet logging with Monasca
schedule.description:
This presentation introduces the network traffic logging feature which is

proposed to Neutron, and explain by demonstration how it works,

especially gathering log data using Monasca.

 

OpenStack network is highly virtualized by Neutron, and therefore it is

very difficult to understand how network packets are processed. A

traffic log is necessary to investigate network problem. We introduce a

packet logging feature to monitor the behaviors of Security Group at

network ports.  This feature is helpful to make sure network access rules

work as expected, and troubleshoot network problems easier.

 

To manage the logs in a centralized way we leverage Monasca's

Logging-as-a-Service functionality. Using it all the queries that are

performed are scoped to a tenant/project, so that every user can access

only his data.

 

In this presentation we will give a demonstration of this feature and show

how you can see network packet logs using Monasca.
schedule.social_description: OpenStack network traffic logging with Neutron and Monasca
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees can learn as follows:

  • An architecture and usage of Neutron packet logging feature
  • Operations that show how to manage logging data in cloud system by using Neutron and Monasca

schedule.title: Project Update - Cinder
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Cinder and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.


We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.


Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Cinder plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.


Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Cinder PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: The 5G Network: A Glimpse Into the Connected Future
schedule.description:
There’s a lot of buzz surrounding the potential for 5G to completely change the technology landscape and enable massive connectivity and IOT. But what is 5G really? What is the market opportunity for 5G and what infrastructure is needed to support it?

 

This panel, moderated by Neela Jacques, Executive Director of OpenDaylight, will bring together executives from AT&T, Ericsson, Verizon and Huawei to discuss:

  • The new enhancements in 5G and what they will enable
  • The infrastructure needed to support 5G, including SDN and NFV
  • The market opportunity for 5G including new applications like autonomous driving, smart cities and e-health practices like remote surgery
  • Who will profit from 5G, and what kinds of new business models will emerge
schedule.social_description: Learn more about 5G in relation to SDN & NFV.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This panel, moderated by Neela Jacques, Executive Director of OpenDaylight, will bring together executives from AT&T, Ericsson, Verizon and Huawei to discuss:

  • The new enhancements in 5G and what they will enable
  • The infrastructure needed to support 5G, including SDN and NFV
  • The market opportunity for 5G including new applications like autonomous driving, smart cities and e-health practices like remote surgery
  • Who will profit from 5G, and what kinds of new business models will emerge

schedule.title: Running a scientific application on an OpenStack cloud
schedule.description:
The scientific community is still largely wedded to a traditional HPC compute model where a task scheduler provisions bare metal nodes and the application runs directly on the node OS. Typically, the application is restricted to using the node's software libraries and compiler toolchain. In our experience this compute model causes the development environment on the HPC cluster and the user's desktop to differ, adding obstacles to software development. In addition, cluster software upgrades potentially alter the application's runtime behavior or results.

From our point of view the provisioning of virtual machines in OpenStack offers a user friendly alternative. But how does a scientific application perform on OpenStack?

Here we run a quantum chemistry application employing novel computational algorithms written in Fortran and MPI and investigate the changes necessary in the work flow and the application code and the impact of virtualization on performance and parallel scalability.
schedule.social_description: Running a scientific research code on OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: We looked at how much effort it is to run a scientific research code on an OpenStack cloud and what the performance and parallel scaling impact was.

schedule.title: OpenStack is aslo Open to Chip Architecture.  See how ARM64 based chips can add value.
schedule.description:
OpenStack is the lead Open Source solution for Private Clouds and this has been recognised by many hardware providers who have made there technologies work with the code.

Most are aware of the heavy use of ARM based technology in the IoT side of Cloud architectures but what many may not realise is that ARM64 based server technology offers capabilities that may well make strong technical and economic sense to Architects looking to build solutions based on OpenStack.

Walk through the use cases where the ARM64 chip offer Cloud based applications specific capabilities that could make the difference between success and failures in your clouds.
schedule.social_description: See how ARM64 chips in Compute, Network and Storage Tiers of Clouds can take you to Cloud Nivarana
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: There is often a presumption that ARM chip technologies are only relavent to Cloud Architects for Network or IoT considerations. See how ARM is now using the ARM64 based chips with it's partners to deliver fully supported enterprise ready OpenStack, Compute, Network and Storage options.

schedule.title: Hands on Lab: Octavia
schedule.description:
In this interactive workshop, memebers of the Octavia team will walk attendees through the installation and configuration of Octavia, the Open Stack LoadBalancer, on a prepared virtual machine in the cloud. Attendees will leave with an understanding of the various components of Octavia, how to configure and tune the controller and the amphora, and with some troubleshooting tips.

Attendees will learn: 

  • Octavia Architecture 101
  • How to Install and Configure Octavia
  • How to perform day to day Octavia operations tasks
  • End user usage of the API, CLI and Horizon UI
  • Tips and Tricks for using Octavia
  • Contributing to Octavia 101
schedule.social_description: Hands-on lab:  installation and configuration of Octavia, the Open Stack LoadBalancer
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Octavia Architecture 101
  • How to Install and Configure Octavia
  • How to perform day to day Octavia operations tasks
  • End user usage of the API, CLI and Horizon UI
  • Tips and Tricks for using Octavia
  • Contributing to Octavia 101

schedule.title: OpenStack Challenge 2017: A Hands-On Break-Fix Competition
schedule.description: Think you have the experience and skills to become the next IT hero and fix a broken OpenStack environment?  Join Rackspace OpenStack instructors and a room full of fierce contestants fighting to become the Supreme Stacker!  All attendees will be competitors, receiving their very own OpenStack environment and racing against the clock to fix a variety of real-world OpenStack private cloud issues.  Each break-fix scenario will include dynamic visual slide content with scenario explanations and a live scoreboard to really get the heart pumping and adrenaline flowing!
schedule.social_description: Think you have the experience and skills to become the next OpenStack hero?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: All attendees will receive access to their very own OpenStack environment and work through a variety of timed OpenStack break-fix scenarios.  These scenarios will ensure attendees learn to manage infrastructure capacity issues, decipher generic errors, debug API authentication problems, and even perform packet inspection when investigating complex networking issues.  With the help of experienced Rackspace OpenStack instructors, attendees will learn basic troubleshooting methodology and the necessary OpenStack Engineer tools of the trade.  By the end of this workshop, participants will walk away with the confidence to not only diagnose OpenStack problems but prevent these technical nightmares from occurring in their organization's production OpenStack environment!

schedule.title: Congratulations ${IT_GUY} you are now our Openstack Administrator.
schedule.description: Face it,  you are an awesome IT Administrator/Engineer.  From the menial to inherently complex you turn no reasonable task or project down.  You are suddenly approached by your manager telling you that you are now taking over the responsibilities as the company's Openstack Administrator/Engineer and he/she trusts you that you possess aptitude to quickly become a capable Openstack Administrator.   Your palms are sweaty, knees weak and  arms are heavy but they shouldn't be for too long as getting acquainted with an OpenStack cloud is not a complicated task as long as you are armed with the right tools. This visually rich presentation will cover the discovery and assessment of an Openstack cloud through the installation and use of the Openstack CLI utilities in order to help us newly minted Openstack Administrators familiarize ourselves with our newly inherited OpenStack powered clouds.
schedule.social_description: Discovering your newly inherited Openstack Infrastructure.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees are expected to learn as to how to properly discover, assess, and and learn their OpenStack infrastructure footprint through the use of the various OpenStack CLI utilities even with limited Openstack knowledge.

schedule.title: Automation of End-to-End and Full Stack Testing of an OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description:
In a large multi-site OpenStack Cloud environment, we have been testing the building blocks in all layers for two year now.  We test these blocks individually as well as test end-to-end flows across them.

The building blocks that need to be tested include hardware, OS/VMMs, OpenStack, Contrail, other software, and IT tools.  These blocks are tested using their APIs, CLIs or GUIs.

We have automated a significant part of our testing using open source tools.  We leverage Tempest for testing OpenStack.  API tests for non-OpenStack components and extensions to Tempest (e.g., testing scenarios) are automated using OpenStack plugins.  We have been automating CLI tests using TestInfra and we have also been considering Puppet Facter.  We have automated testing of OpenStack Horizon and other GUIs using Selenium.

In addition describing our automation, we will share information on the number of tests we perform, our extent of automation and the benefits we have seen as well as some challenges.
schedule.social_description: Automation of API, CLI and GUI testing in a large multi-site Cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees will learn the following:

  • The requirements for testing all components of a large, multi-site OpenStack managed Cloud that has been in production for 2+ years.
  • The need for automated testing.
  • Automation of API testing using Tempest plugins with detailed examples.
  • Options for automating CLI testing with an in-depth look at TestInfra.
  • Automation of GUI testing using Selenium with examples.
  • The features supported by our Cloud and the numbers of test cases to be executed to effectively test our Cloud.
  • Where we are in our automation journey, the benefits we have seen so far and the challenges we have faced.

schedule.title: Finding Needles in the Open Hay Stack
schedule.description: Verizon Wireless, a leader in deploying Virtual Network Function (VNF) applications on OpenStack™, and SevOne, a leader in digital infrastructure management, have partnered to provide service assurance for Verizon Wireless. Over the past 18 months logs have helped troubleshoot each layer: hardware, OpenStack, and VNF. OpenStack log use cases range from monitoring virtual infrastructure health to correlating details about an interface going down and network elements affected by the outage. Future use cases include security audits and providing confirmation of network activities. A challenge with OpenStack logs is that key logs may be at various severities, including "debug", and setting severity to "debug" in production results in a large volume of logs, taxing resources. Approaches that Verizon Wireless and SevOne have taken to address this challenge include log filtering, indexing, tagging, compression, and distributed processing.
schedule.social_description: Verizon Wireless and SevOne partner to solve real world OpenStack problems using real-time analytics
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Telecommunications operators will learn of OpenStack log service assurance use cases from Verizon Wireless production and lab deployments. Use cases resolve issues at an individual layer with operational insight into how issues at one layer, for example OpenStack, affect another layer, for example, VNFs. Operators and architects will learn strategies for managing daily high log volumes in production. Strategies include optimizing search with advanced indexing and tagging, managing high log volumes with distributed processing, and compression. Operators will also learn how presenting logs in dynamic reporting dashboards can help solve specific functional use cases. Developers will learn ways to further improve OpenStack log value in production, such as continuing to refine log severity levels based on operational needs, and/or providing the capability for operators to do so. Telecommunications CEOs will learn how OpenStack logs support delivering a reliable OpenStack-based solution in production.

schedule.title: Federation with Keycloak and FreeIPA
schedule.description:
Did you know you can use the open source Keycloak authentication portal to federate FreeIPA users through to the OpenStack dashboard? There are many benefits to this approach. FreeIPA user management provides a rich set of identity features across an enterprise (beyond just OpenStack), while also allowing a dashboard login option that does not reveal credentials to any OpenStack services.


In this session, we’ll provide an overview of the components involved in federation: OpenStack dashboard, Keystone, FreeIPA, and Keycloak. We’ll discuss how they work together, how they compare with direct LDAP authentication, and how to manually configure these components for federation. We’ll also provide a detailed overview of certificate requirements, a demonstration of federation in an OpenStack lab, and useful troubleshooting tips. In addition, we’ll describe opportunities for collaboration between teams, as a successful federation deployment may require buy-in from multiple stakeholders.
schedule.social_description: Learn how to federate users in the FreeIPA identity management system via the Keycloak SAML IdP.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This talk begins with an overview of the components involved in the Federated Identity solution: Dashboard, Keystone, FreeIPA, and Keycloak

The Federated Identity overview then describes how these components work together. Then, a comparison with direct LDAP integration allows users to understand the differences with this approach.

A detailed overview of certificate requirements will help users understand the certificate requirements of federation, including how to get these components to agree on trusted certificates.

This is followed by descriptions of how to configure the individual components, with interesting points highlighted. Next is a demonstration of federation in an OpenStack lab, followed by some troubleshooting tips.

schedule.title: Across the Hybrid Cloud with Karbor
schedule.description:
While "cloud-native" is gaining ground, most enterprise applications are still not there. But there’s no reason why such applications should miss out on the benefits of hybrid cloud.

Karbor Application Data Protection can be used to migrate an application from on-prem OpenStack to off-prem and vice versa.

Extensible architecture enables users to plug-in new backends and new resource types into Karbor and leverage all vendor-specific capabilities without compromising the ability to protect the data and ensure service continuity.

In this session we will introduce Karbor and showcase how it could be used in a cloud migration scenario.
schedule.social_description: Migrate applications from on-prem to off-prem and vice versa with Karbor Application Data Protection
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to be familiar with a new way of moving their application around the clouds with Karbor, an OpenStack big-tent project.

schedule.title: Verizon Product Case Study - OpenStack at the Edge
schedule.description:
Think OpenStack only works in data centers and test beds?   Think again.  Coming from the need to deliver an identical network service application experience in radically different environments, the Virtual Network Services (VNS) product uses OpenStack components as its underlying platform to create a massively distributed Network as a Service solution.  VNS is a portfolio of network services delivered in a flexible framework on x86 hardware allowing customers to choose the services, network architecture and delivery models that best suit their needs.

OpenStack can be used for products that are distributed out to remote sites, but massively distributed OpenStack architectures have been a difficult problem that cannot be solved without taking a radically different approach to delivering orchestration and integration tools.  The product team created an OpenStack environment that fit in small footprint yet still works with orchestration tools located in a global cloud.
schedule.social_description: Verizon Case Study: Delivering a massively distributed Network as a Service solution using OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
During this session you will learn how OpenStack was adapted to solve thorny product issues such as:

  • The need to perform in a massively distributed (think thousands of global locations) environment.
  • The need to deliver network services to customers located both at remote locations and globally distributed Verizon owned data centers.
  • Complex vendor integration, product orchestration and service delivery requirements
  • Tight hardware limitations and cost constraints.
  • Integration of orchestration tools to automate service delivery

schedule.title: Advanced controller optimization, how to get the most of your controllers?
schedule.description:
OpenStack controllers are essential components of every single installation, this ia a well known axiom. But depending on type of installation, controllers can host entire OpenStack installation or only some of the services which characteristics vary widely. On my session I am going to show you:

  1. OpenStack controller workload characteristics, there is no one which fits all.
  2. How to detect basic hardware configuration issues and how to optimize our existing hardware?
  3. What is really running on my CPUs and how can I make it faster?
  4. IRQ who does generate them? and who does serve them? can we make it faster?
  5. OpenStack processes CPU affinity.
  6. Understanding of disk controllers IO and optimization ways.
  7. Network traffic, how does controller do it? From the packet on the wire to read()/write() calls in Python code.

This session is going to be a little bit more advanced than traditional how to on uptime, top, htop, iotop. It will explain how the things work under the hood.
schedule.social_description: A little bit of  advanced topics like system and hardware profiling for OpenStack controllers.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How to understand and estimate OpenStack controller workload type.
  • How to detect basic hardware configuration issues and how to optimize our existing hardware?
  • What is really running on my CPUs and how can I make it faster?
  • OpenStack processes CPU affinity, how to get the most of it?
  • Understanding of disk controllers IO and optimization ways (blktrace).
  • Network traffic, how does controller do it? From the packet on the wire to read()/write() calls in Python code.
  • IRQ who does generate them? and who does serve them? can we make it faster?

schedule.title: Contrail, Kuryr, and Kubernetes – Crikey!
schedule.description: This talk will focus on bridging the gap between Kubernetes and Contrail using Kuryr. Contrail is a highly-scalable SDN controller that is used within AT&T’s Integrated Cloud (AIC). Our team’s work to enhance Kuryr with Contrail support can be used as a template for integrating additional SDN controllers with Kuryr.  We will detail the implementation of a new os-vif driver, give an overview of how Kuryr-Kubernetes works, and describe how it simplifies SDN in a mixed OpenStack/Kubernetes environment. We plan to share our results and to demo Contrail networking between a VM and a Kubernetes-hosted container via Kuryr.
schedule.social_description: Bridging the gap between Kubernetes and Contrail using Kuryr.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can expect to learn the details of our team’s work enhancing Kuryr with Contrail support, how to implement a new os-vif driver, and how Kuryr-Kubernetes reduces complexity of SDN in a mixed OpenStack/Kubernetes environment.

schedule.title: What’s going on in OpenStack? Learn About the Community Generated Roadmap!
schedule.description:
The OpenStack community of projects is growing and evolving. To help all of us stay current, the Product Working Group creates a Community Generated Roadmap, with the help and support of the PTLs and the technical community. This condensed, simplified roadmap outlines the capabilities you can expect in the upcoming OpenStack releases based on directional guidance from various projects.  

 In this session we'll present our findings across the different projects in an effort to give users a glimpse into OpenStack's upcoming capabilities.  The roadmap presented will span multiple releases and strive to unify the future direction of the individual projects on a per release basis.  We’ll also provide an update on Product Management in our Community and how you can get involved and contribute!
schedule.social_description: Hear what's new in OpenStack from the Product WG as they share the community generated roadmap!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the current OpenStack Community Roadmap and where to find the most current information on OpenStack.org that provides additional details (ex. Design Series PTL interviews, future interview plans).

schedule.title: When One Cloud is Not Enough: An Overview of Sites, Regions, Edges, Distributed Clouds, and More
schedule.description:
As OpenStack becomes ubiquitous, organizations have reason to deploy multiple OpenStack clouds, sites, regions, "edges," or to distribute computing, to list a few possibilities and terms. These requirements could be based on capacity, latency, geographic location, high availability, other needs, or a combination of any or all.

But how should these varied and complex OpenStack systems be designed, deployed, and managed? What should the architecture be? Or even more basic, what to these terms mean, and who uses what definition and how do they differ? As we will show, even the nomenclature is difficult, as there are several major architectures, use-cases, and groups to be considered.

We will present an overview of the various options, projects, and decision points for this topic and detail the positives and negatives of various approaches, as well as what the gaps are in terms of solutions
schedule.social_description: When One Cloud is Not Enough: An Overview of Sites, Regions, Edges, Distributed Clouds, and More
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees to this presentation should come away with a good understanding of common terminology, uses-cases, and architectures concerning organizational requirements which depend on deploying multiple OpenStack Clouds, regions, sites, edges, distributed compute, or other similar architectures. We hope attendees will be able to go back to their organizations and recognize requirements that suggest the aforementioned architectures may be needed, what the benefits and issues are, and in doing so are able to help the organization make informed decisions.

schedule.title: Project Update - Designate
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Designate and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.


We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.


Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Designate plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.


Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Designate PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: 7 "must-haves" for highly effective Telco NFV deployments
schedule.description:
Red Hat and Juniper Networks will address 7 of the biggest challenges faced by Broadband NFV deployments

  1. Predictable high performance -  linearly scalable performance, low latency, hardware agnostic with acceleration, small  to jumbo frames
  2. High availability - No single point of failure, link bonding, redundancy, load balancing, failure detection, monitoring, live migration
  3. Superior L2 & L3 connectivity - Solid L2 networking, transition to L3 routing, external IPs, IPv6, carrier grade NAT
  4. Managed multi-tenancy - Isolation of north-south & east-west tenant networks; Manageable, scalable overlay tunnels
  5. Agile programmable infrastructure - Flexible datapath, integration with SDN controller, elastic network, auto-scaling
  6. Multi-site deployments - Geo-site deployments for better scale, redundancy and disaster recovery
  7. Distributed security - move security from edge to the application, distributed firewalls, connection tracking, L2 MACsec & L3 IPsec encrypted tunnels between endpoints
schedule.social_description: High perf., high availability, L3 networking, multi-tenancy, programability, multi-site & security
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This presentation takes a deep dive into challenges faced by NFV Telco customers when moving to Openstack deployed virtualized solutions. Providing agile and scalable deployments with Openstack enables Telcos/ISPs to optimize usage of resources, deploy new services quickly and compete with higher value offerings

What will be covered?

  • Learn strategies and state of the art for deploying high performance VNFs with Openstack today
  • Red Hat and Juniper will address 7 of the biggest challenges faced by NFV deployments and why they are important to Telcos/ISPs
  • The presentation will have real world Telco/ISP deployment scenarios for the Broadband and SD-WAN usecase.  
  • It will cover issues  encountered along with workarounds and solutions provided which maybe still work in progress.
  • It will cover futuristic roadmap and requirements for Broadband NFV deployments for the next 2-3 years.

schedule.title: Intergation of enterprise monitoring product, Senlin and Mistral for Auto-healing
schedule.description: This proposal is to share an industry practice of auto-healing with reliable failure detection, real time notification, flexible recovery action. Where, a reputed enterprise monitoring product is integrated as an example of how to leverage existing tools/products outside OpenStack and industry intelligence for failure detection; Senlin is used to receive notifications from the integrated monitor and to trigger the recover action; Mistral is integrated with Senlin to allow a complementary recovery comprised of users’ custom workflows, for good handling of error cases, task parallelism and branching, and Senlin’s built-in actions which can be customized by a user defined health policy. We will demonstrate how to take all the advantages of these components in the Auto-healing solution.
schedule.social_description: An industrial practice of auto-healing by integration of the enterprise monitor, Senlin and mistral.
