schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this presentation, we will give an introduction and demonstration about how to integrate the enterprise product with OpenStack projects in order to take all the advantages of these components and achieve an industry practice of auto-healing. In more details, attendees will see:

(1) How to create and operate the alerts/notifications of the external enterprise monitor in OpenStack.

(2) How to trigger OpenStack recovery Action once notified by the external monitor.

(3) How to execute Mistral workflows for the recover purpose.

(4) How to use Senlin Policy for customization of the auto-healing loop.

schedule.title: Strategies for migrating workloads from VMware to OpenStack
schedule.description:
As OpenStack adoption increases, companies are looking at ways to migrate workloads from traditional virtualization solutions like VMware or System Center to cloud infrastructures based on OpenStack. 

There are multiple angles to this problem to consider:

  • Pets vs Cattle: when is OpenStack the right choice and when not
  • Lift and shift: when is worth to use automated migration tools like Coriolis to move virtual machines
  • App migration: when to migrate individual applications and their data to a new platform (e.g. a PaaS)
  • Re-develop: when to adopt modern paradigms like microservices, containers etc and redevelop applications

There's no one-size-fits-all answer, but knowing what your options are, you can do the right choice for each use case. Costs also have a big impact, for example it can be worth to lift-and-shift and use the saved money to re-architect the next app generation.

We will also do a fully automated lift-and-shift and DRaaS live demo using the Coriolis project.
schedule.social_description: As OpenStack adoption increases, companies are looking at migrating from VMware or SCVMM. Here's how
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about the best and fastest routes to adopt an OpenStack cloud infrastructure for existing workloads and perform informed decisions on the strategy to adopt.

Attendees will also learn how to use automated tools to perform migrations effortlessly.

schedule.title: 10 SDN solutions for OpenStack in 10 minutes
schedule.description:
First the presentation will kick off with a quick explanation on WHY the need of an SDN solution in OpenStack

The objective is to compare 10 different approches to SDN in Openstack. Each approach would be focusen in the way one SDN vendor proposes to integrate their product with Openstack.

This presentation is vendor neutral, it does not focus on pitching one particular vendor over another.

1 of the approches will be of course Neutron stand-alone as an SDN.
schedule.social_description: https://github.com/qcrivera/
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn to differentiate and compare when selecting and SDN solution for their Openstack cloud deployments. The idea is to give the attendees an idea of the questions they should be asking their SDN vendor.

schedule.title: Building and Operating a Swift S3 Storage Environment as a Service Provider
schedule.description:
In the service provider world, data is infinite and constant. It is constantly growing, constantly evolving, and companies are constantly changing the way they want to interact with it. To sustain and manage the customer demand Expedient had to get creative in how they store customer data. Running PB of block storage to run VM's and Containers was easy but customers are demanding programmable storage via a S3 API. Which presents a whole new set of challenges especially when you have to interact with both modes of IT, traditional and cloud.

To meet customers needs, Expedient leveraged OpenStack Swift(SwiftStack version) to provide that API driven storage. See the blue prints we used to build our offering, learn about how our customers are adopting it, and hear our experiences after operating this platform for two years. Many of our early assumptions were wrong and caused us some pain that you can quickly avoid.
schedule.social_description: The good and bad of building an Object Storage platform using OpenStack Swift.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: After this session, you will have an understanding on what an object storage platform could do for you, examples of how you can use it, and a path to get you started regardless of what software package you use.

schedule.title: Securing Microservice Interactions in OpenStack and Kubernetes
schedule.description:
Interacting microservices have a large dynamic attack surface from exposed APIs, communication channels, data-store interactions, and agile deployment. Communication between Kubernetes pods and OpenStack VMs further expands the attack surface. An ideal security solution will go beyond reachability and allow rich security services to be activated on demand. This talk will cover:

  • Review OpenStack mechanisms to secure inter-service communication in tenant networks, across K8s and OpenStack clusters, at both network and application layers, e.g. Kuryr, service insertion, FWaaS, Barbican, Congress.
  • Inter-operation of K8s and OpenStack mechanisms, e.g. K8s network policy & Neutron security groups.
  • Operational challenges of configuring infrastructure security mechanisms to achieve service-level security objectives, and methodology to mitigate challenges.
  • Outline and demo of a security approach that operates independently of infrastructure mechanisms to secure inter-service communications.
schedule.social_description: Securing inter-microservice communication in OpenStack and Kubernetes, and demo of new approach.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• A review of current OpenStack mechanisms to secure inter-service communication in tenant networks across Kubernetes and OpenStack clusters. Relevant mechanisms are at both the network and application layers, e.g., Kuryr, service insertion, FWaaS, Barbican, Congress.
  • Inter-operation of Kubernetes and OpenStack mechanisms, e.g., Kubernetes network policy and Neutron security groups.
  • Operational challenges of configuring infrastructure security mechanisms to achieve service-level security objectives, and a methodology to mitigate these challenges.
  • Outline and demo of a security approach that operates independently of infrastructure-level mechanisms to secure inter-service communications.

schedule.title: Demonstrate the efficient strategy to backup OpenStack Resources
schedule.description:
Backup the OpenStack is always a big and open challenge for operator or admin. If we do not have good solution then it is very painful and time consuming. One of the key goal of operators is to keep taking Cloud backup and make sure about user data and usability.

Very first and important question to achieve this goal is "Hey! What Backup Solution we can use?"

Based on some PoC and feasibility tests on different backup solution, we fetched some of the interesting results. This will definitely help audience to find out answer to their open question about backup solution. 

In this talk we will present our experience in backup area with all possible solution currently we have in market. Also we would like to talk about key features which must be included in those solution.
schedule.social_description: Demonstrate the efficient strategy to backup OpenStack Resources
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Operator and admin can get the best strategy and solution to Backup the OpenStack resources which eventually will save their time and manual effort.

schedule.title: Project Update - Documentation
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Documentation and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Documentation plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

 

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Documentation PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Experience with DPDK Troubleshooting
schedule.description:
Getting near real-time performance for VNF applications requires designing the application carefully and profiling its performance under realistic conditions. OpenStack has developed many functionalities that helps in this, such as CPU and PCI topology awareness and pinning the virtual machines to dedicated cores. The host networking stack, in turn, has been optimized with features such as accelerated virtual switches and DPDK.

This presentation gives an update of using DPDK in real VNF tests and tells some real life experiences from DPDK troubleshooting.
schedule.social_description: Experience with DPDK Troubleshooting

schedule.title: Containerizing OpenStack deployments: Lessons learned from TripleO
schedule.description:
There are multiple tools that allow for deploying OpenStack on containers. Some of these tools started from scratch with contianers in mind, some others broke backwards compatibility and some others are aiming for a smooth transition from host based deployment to a containerized one.

TripleO is undergoing the transition from a baremetal to a containerized deployment and it's already overcome several challenges related to this process. This presentation aims to share the technical challenges from a deployment and operations perspective that are common to every containers based OpenStack deployment. The experiences that will be shared go from config management to volumes and network administration.
schedule.social_description: This preso shares some of the challenges common to every containers-based OpenStack deployment
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How to migrate from non-containerized deployment to a containerized deployment
  • How to manage storage for containers
  • How to manage dynamic config generation for OpenStack deployments
  • How to distribute and group containers in a containers based OpenStack deployment

schedule.title: Designing Cloud Native Applications - Deep dive
schedule.description:
The twelve factors

The twelve-factor app is a methodology for building apps that can fully utilize the cloud capabilities and much more. Some of this discipline is enforced on applications orchestrated using Cloud foundry or Kubernetes running on OpenStack.

Case study

We dive deep into the patterns of a highly scalable architecture with examples, showcasing how Cisco's Cloud IWAN was designed to be cloud native and its successful migration from Cloud Foundry to Kubernetes based deployment.

Microservice architecture

Architecting software, as microservices that are highly scalable and portable, has its own pros and cons. We want to share how we overcame the cons with the product under consideration.

Anti-patterns

Common failures & mistakes while designing large enterprise applications, limit the capabilities of the application to be truly cloud native. We share how not to design/refactor few components.

All these learnings are applicable for any product we want to be cloud native.
schedule.social_description: A deep dive into a highly scalable architecture, showcasing how it was designed to be cloud native.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
From beginners to advanced application developers and designers, the key takeaways are,

  • Microservice architecture - pros and cons. How to overcome the cons?
  • Steps to deploy applications on Cloud Foundry running on OpenStack.
  • Steps to deploy applications on Kubernetes running on OpenStack.
  • How to refactor an application to make it truly cloud native?
  • What are the anti-patters while designing such a large application?
  • Design a large and highly scalable enterprise application.
  • Insight into the ELK stack and how it is used in the application under consideration.
  • Insight into Cisco's Network Services Orchestrator.

schedule.title: NFV Management and Network Orchestartion (MANO) using OpenStack
schedule.description:
There are several Open Source orchestration projects that integrate with OpenStack as the VIM. The OPNFV MANO working group has been working with several of them to develop common integration requirements, data models, and APIs. These include OpenStack upstream OPNFV , OPEN-O, OpenBaton and evaluate many more as the consistant approach emerges.

The Panel will provide insight on OpenStack requirements from their vantage points based on their workloads, VNF best practices and market perspective. The Panel will be moderated by Prakash Ramchandran who is chairing the OPNFV Management and Orchestration working group and seeks collaboration with OpenStack community to help OPNFV use the best of bests innovation from the OpenStack eco system.
schedule.social_description: Best practices for MANO using OpenStack for Service Providers
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: What is the precption of normative ETSI specifiction of MANO versus the reality in Open Source support in OpenStack and its upstreams in OPNFV, OPEN-O, OpenBaton, integration architecture. Why is that so many MANO stacks are required and what best pracices will help them interoperate based on Service VNFs that are composed from functional modules, legacy as well emerging ones. The panel members will provie their respective view porints and OPNFV community would like to learn and move the efforts to a acceptable common minimums to enable Interoperability and colloaboration through OpenStack community.

schedule.title: MOC Simple GUI - An "and" to OpenStack Horizon
schedule.description:
The Massachusetts Open Cloud (MOC) needs a simple intuitive GUI for its public cloud marketplace. Our goal is to provide a tool to enhance the user experience by automating mundane but complicated steps to use cloud resources.

OpenStack Horizon is inadequate to serve naive users who lack basic cloud knowledge and to whom the cloud is simply a tool to get computing results for their scientific research. This new GUI serves to be a simpler tool streamlining the cloud experience. It can be used by itself or alongside Horizon. Developing a new GUI from scratch can be both time-consuming and challenging. A collaboration with the Cyverse’s Atmosphere/Troposphere project has helped accelerate the development of the MOC Simple GUI. 

An overview of the design of the MOC simple GUI will be presented. The divergence from the upstream Atmosphere/Troposphere design to enhance security, and allow interoperability with Horizon will be discussed.
schedule.social_description: MOC Simple GUI - An "and" to OpenStack Horizon
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• complication of graphical interface design/development of public cloud marketplace and 
  • components of MOC Simple GUI: already available Django apps; relevant Python library such as libcloud and Rtwo

schedule.title: Realize the Ability of Application Orchestration in OpenStack With Cloudify
schedule.description: The OpenStack heat component can orchestrate IaaS resource(network,compute,storage),but not have the ability of app orchestration. Cloudify is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized or traditional application. The topic introduce that users can deploy services and applications with Cloudify in OpenStack based cloud infrastructure.User can model applications and service and automate their entire life cycle,including deployment on any cloud or data center environment,monitoring all aspects of the deployed application,detecting issues and failure,manually or automatically remediating them and handle on going maintenance task.
schedule.social_description: The topic introduce that users can deploy services and applications with Cloudify in OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized or traditional application in OpenStack

schedule.title: DR firedrill in OpenStack environment
schedule.description:
One of the major concerns while creating OpenStack DR environment is to ensure that the current environment can be brought up in case of a disaster.

In this talk we will be talking about ways for ensuring that OpenStack configuration can be easily migrated to a DR site with no impact. This session will also talk about the checks which should be periodically carried out to make sure that current OpenStack configuration is portable to a different site.
schedule.social_description: Ways for making OpenStack configuration easily portable to a DR site with no impact.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Ways to ensure that OpenStack configuration can be easily migrated to a DR site with no impact.
  • Checks which should be periodically carried out to make sure that current OpenStack configuration is portable to a different site.

schedule.title: New Project Meteos : Machine Learning as a Service
schedule.description:
Machine Learning is becoming a new trend in Big Data industry.

Meteos is a new Project which provides Machine Learning as a Service (MLaaS) in OpenStack.
Meteos allows users to analyze huge amount of data and predict any value by data mining and machine learning algorithms only by executing API.

By using Meteos, users can easily predict any value you want, and application developers can incorporate machine learning algorithms into their applications.

Meteos creates a workspace of Machine Learning via a Sahara spark plug in and manages some resources and jobs regarding Machine Learning.

In this session, you can see the outline and future prospective about Meteos Project. And you can see the demonstration which recommends a Movie according to user preference.
schedule.social_description: Meteos is a new Project which provides Machine Learning as a Service in OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• What is Machine Learning ?
  • What is Apache Spark ?
  • What is Meteos and Why Meteos ?
  • The procedures and life cycle of Machine Learning.
  • The outline and future prospective about Meteos Project.
  • How to Predict a value by using Meteos

schedule.title: Cinder Stands Alone
schedule.description:
Cinder is a powerful Software Defined Storage (SDS) service that is an integral part of OpenStack.  The real power from Cinder comes from its abstraction API that allows many storage solutions to work from the same API.  Cinder's API works with both open source and commercial storage solutions, and Cinder has over 70 drivers to support a variety of back end storage . With Cinder as a Software Defined Storage solution a user can perform basic volume operations like create, attach, and snapshot, without knowing the details of the backend storage array.
Did you know you can use Cinder as a standalone service, without any other OpenStack services running?  In this presentation we will cover how to deploy Cinder without the other OpenStack services and how you can create volumes and use them. Consumers can use Stand Alone Cinder for performing basic volume operations on Virtual Machines, Containers with a workflow using Docker or Kubernetes, or Bare Metal machines.
schedule.social_description: Demo of Cinder as a Software Defined Storage (SDS) service used alone, without OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendess will learn:

  • How to setup Cinder to stand alone, with no other OpenStack services running.
  • How to configure standalone Cinder SDS for various storage backends.
  • How to use Cinder to create, attach, and snapshot volumes.

schedule.title: Make both OpenStack and Kubernetes a Fail-safe - a.k.a OpenStack on Kubernetes
schedule.description:
Several companies have been working on how to build an OpenStack on the Kubernetes at the PoC level, and the way is known. However, building a product level OpenStack on top of Kubernetes requires a lot of consideration. For example, database redundancy, message queue clustering and reliable storage is required. Most of all, you can install it, but it does not tell you exactly what features of Kubernetes were used, how the container image was built, and what the argument values are for execution.

See how to build manually a high availability OpenStack and Kubernetes based on kubelet in detail, and provide guidelines on how to apply it to future in Kolla-Kubernetes(Helm).

Learn about:

  - HA for kubernetes controllers
  - HA for OpenStack in production on Kubernetes
  - Kubernetes features used to build OpenStack
schedule.social_description: See how to build manually a high availability OpenStack and Kubernetes based on kubelet in detail
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn 3 things

  - HA for kubernetes controllers
  - HA for OpenStack in production on Kubernetes
  - Kubernetes features used to build OpenStack

schedule.title: Hybrid Messaging Solutions for Large Scale OpenStack Deployments
schedule.description:
The oslo.messaging library supports the concept of service-specific transports (e.g. backends) to allow RPC and Notification services to employ different messaging technologies. The need for this dual messaging backend capability is driven by the limitations of broker-based messaging for RPC communications with regard to complexity, scalability and resiliency. The temporal coupling of OpenStack service RPC communications favors a brokerless message bus based on direct messaging capabilities rather than queuing. Meanwhile, the operation of Notification services remain best served by a broker based "store and forward" messaging bus.


This presentation will review the oslo.messaging RPC and Notification services and the operation of brokerless and broker-based messaging backends. The steps to configure and operate dual messaging backends will be demonstrated. An explanation of how high availability and cloud distribution can be realized will be provided.
schedule.social_description: The need for hybrid messaging has emerged as a key requirement for large OpenStack deployments
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the the concept of oslo.messaging RPC and Notification communications services. They will understand the temporal requirements of RPC communications and the constraints that queues place on this communication pattern. Attendees will learn about the use of the apache qpid-dispatch-router for a direct messaging backend for RPC. They will learn about the operational considerations for deploying dual messaging backends in OpenStack and the upstream activities for installation and configuration.

schedule.title: ODL/OpenContrail Integration with OpenStack, the Pain the Gain and the lessons learnt
schedule.description:
OpenStack without SDN Controller is like life without Tapas (You would understand if you’ve been to Boston).

In the dreamland everything works seamlessly. You want ODL to sing with your OpenStack or you would like to see OpenContrail dance with it, your choice, it will just work. But (we know you’ve been in the industry long enough to expect there is a catch), you have to take up the daunting journey of “integration”, which is not as pleasant and straight forward as one might think.

In this presentation, we’ll detail steps to integrate SDN Controller with your OpenStack, what are challenges and how we solved them.

Ask us your questions, share your comments and let us help share the story of our journey with those who are undertaking it now to make it easier for them what was a rather an “interesting” experience.

Leave the session on a high note of believing that we’ll make your OpenStack sing and dance with your choice of SDN Controller (ODL or OpenContrail).
schedule.social_description: We’ll make your OpenStack sing and dance with your choice of SDN Controller (ODL or OpenContrail).

schedule.title: The Future for OpenStack Distributions
schedule.description:
OpenStack offers a choice of consumption models, ranging from a “brew your own” approach from upstream code to a commercially supported enterprise-grade OpenStack distribution. Which approach is best for your business and what are the critical factors to take into account when making the right choice?

Over the past year, we’ve seen a reduction in the number of commercial OpenStack distributions to choose from. What has caused this consolidation? Should we be concerned? What is the future of the OpenStack distribution model?

This session will compare the pros and cons of choosing the “brew your own” approach or using a distribution. We’ll also explore the key things to take into account when making your decision.  This will include guidance on calculating TCO (Total Cost of Ownership), evaluating SLA (Service Level Agreement), maintenance and support requirements, skillsets and experience needed, workloads to be deployed, investment protection factors and process considerations.
schedule.social_description: How to choose the most appropriate OpenStack consumption model for your business.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How to choose the most appropriate OpenStack consumption model for your business
  • How to build a business case for an OpenStack private cloud

schedule.title: Kubernetes on OpenStack: what's available and where are the gaps?
schedule.description:
Kubernetes and OpenStack are mutually complementary in many ways, allowing for OpenStack to run on Kubernetes as managed services, and for Kubernetes to run on OpenStack so containers can access Cloud
infrastructure. In this talk, we focus on the latter case and describe how pods in Kubernetes directly leverage the OpenStack services such as storage (Cinder), networking (Neutron), identity (Keystone), etc.
We will demo how this is done on the Ocata release.

We will also examine the gaps that still exist. First, we consider the functionalities in Kubernetes that are available on other Cloud platforms, but not yet available on OpenStack. One example of this is advanced features for container volumes. Next, we consider OpenStack services essential to containers but not yet available in Kubernetes. Examples of these include  object store (Swift) and secret store (Barbican). Finally we explore how these gaps can be closed, either through the Kubernetes plugin or new support in OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: How Kubernetes pods use OpenStack services, what's missing and how to fill the gaps
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The users who run Kubernetes on OpenStack will learn how to access OpenStack services from the pods along with all the options currently available.  Examples include using Cinder for persistent volumes, load balancer to publish services to the external network, etc.

For completeness, the audience will also see the options for pods that are available on other Cloud platforms but not yet available on OpenStack.  For exploratory purpose, we will discuss the OpenStack services that in some use cases can be essential to pods and that should be made available in some manner.

schedule.title: Project Update - Glance
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Glance and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Glance plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Glance PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Securing OpenStack networking
schedule.description:
This talk will analyze the below topics and provide best practice security recommendations for running a secure networking service within OpenStack.

a) Neutron software architecture - various software components, their roles and how to secure communication.

b) Network architecture designs and isolation techniques using VLANs, L2 tunneling using VXLANs and GRE encapsulation and examine tenant network services workflow.

c) Understand how neutron interacts with other OpenStack services and securing communication and access-control.

d) Role of security-groups and strategies to mitigate various network security risks.

e) Role of quotas & resource policy engine.
schedule.social_description: Understand best practice security recommendations for OpenStack networking.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Various strategies and architectural considerations for securing OpenStack networks

schedule.title: Monitoring Hands-On Workshop
schedule.description:
In this lab you will learn how to configure and use the Monasca OpenStack Monitoring and Logging Service. Every attendee will install and configure the monitoring/logging agents on their own laptops and access a live Monasca environment. With the set of hands-on assignments you will learn how to list and query metrics, define and list alarms, configure notifications using the Monasca CLI or Python Client. Finally, we will show you how to create and use dashboards in the new Grafana 4 and Kibana with full support for Keystone authentication and multi-tenancy.

This lab session will cover the following topics:

  • Installation and configuration of metric and log agents
  • Checking and troubleshooting your installation
  • Using the Monasca CLI and/or Python Client
  • Using Horizon plugin with Grafana and Kibana

No prior knowledge of Monasca is required. It is a practical session, so please bring your laptops.
schedule.social_description: Hands-on workshop about installing configuration and usage of OpenStack Monitoring Service, Monasca.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will install, configure and use Monasca on their own laptops. They will learn by hands-on exercises how to monitor OpenStack. In this lab you will have the possibility to solve different real-life scenarios and talk with core Monasca developers. After this session, each attendee should have a basic knowledge of "how to use + configure" the following components:

  • Monasca metric anf log agents
  • CLI and/or Python Client
  • Monasca APIs
  • Horizon plugin
  • Grafana and Kibana

schedule.title: OpenStack and OpenDaylight: Integrating OpenStack with a SDN controller
schedule.description: Using an OpenDaylight-based SDN controller can provide increased flexibility and performance when constructing OpenStack clouds. In this hands-on workshop, you will create an OpenDaylight cluster and configure the cluster to provide Neutron services via the ML2 “opendaylight” plugin.  We will show how such a configuration can allow hardware and software switches to be used in concert to provide network services by using the OpenDaylight cluster to provide a single programmable way to configure and manage the switches.
schedule.social_description: Hands-On workshop integrating Openstack and the OpenDayLight SDN Controller
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Topics Covered

  1. Create an OpenStack infrastructure
  2. Create an OpenDaylight cluster to provide Neutron OpenStack services
  3. Demonstrate network and VM creation 
  4. Discuss how an OpenDaylight configuation can improve L2, L3 and other advanced Neutron services

schedule.title: The care and feeding of a public cloud service on OpenStack
schedule.description:
A talk filled with war stories from designing, building and operating a multi site public cloud service
on OpenStack with all the bells and whistles expected, including a custom control panel.
And keeping the beast running and up to date.
schedule.social_description: A talk filled with war stories from designing and building a public cloud service on OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Including but not limited to:

 

* Thoughts on design - going with community or propriatary vendor solutions.
* Due to hysterical reasons - from manual installation to Ansible Openstack and the path between.
* A bewildering story of networking.
* Handling hardware
* Around the world in 80 ms - coping with multiple locations and making them cooperate.
* The sad state of billing.
* Minor bugs, issues and and live patching.
* Vendor support - or the lack thereof.
* The API and coding against it.
* The importance of test and development systems.
* Supporting the mess, from customer input to fix in production.
* Keeping the beast up to date.
* Some final advices.

schedule.title: OpenStack Ironic - features, scalability, performance, use cases and future with Intel's RSD.
schedule.description:
In today’s datacenters there’s a lot of use cases like: BigData, HPC, Kubernetes where virtualization is not really beneficial but benefits of IaaS are really desired. Nova with Ironic integration and it’s bare-metal instances are perfect fit for such environments.

Recent advancements in Ironic closed a lot of feature parity gaps in relation to virtualized environments (ie: networking, storage, SOL, etc). There’s also a bunch of other coming like: VNC support, affinity and anit-affinity, routed networks, torrent based provisoning and NVMeF. 

This presentation would:

  • Highlight benefits of Ironic as underlay for BigData, HPC and Kubernetes clusters 
  • Share research results for provisoning concurrency improvments with torrent based image delivery
  • Share research results for reducing provisoning time from minutes to seconds 
  • Show best partices for deploying OpenStack with Ironic @ Kubernetes and benefits of that approach
  • Explain why Intel's Rack Scale Design really matters for Ironic
schedule.social_description: OpenStack Ironic - features, scalability, performance, use cases and future with Intel's RSD.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Everyone intrested in bare-metal instances in OpenStack who are looking for maximum performance and flexbility of IaaS cloud.

schedule.title: Building Trove Images using DiskImageBuilder
schedule.description:
Diskimage-builder is a powerful too for automatically building customized image. But sometimes
it becomes complicated to understand which elements should be used to build a specific image. In this talk
we will provide some insight and steps how one can make use of DIB to build different Database images for
Power and x86 architecture.
schedule.social_description: How to use Disk Image builder for building Trove images
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
At the end of the session, people would be able to know how to efficiently use DIB for building Trove images.

Troubleshooting guildelines.

schedule.title: Serverless Network Services in OpenStack and Data centers
schedule.description:
Virtualized networking services are already here, but users are facing many difficulties with
leveraging their full potential as performance, latency, management and complexity problems are
all still here.

In this talk we will present a ground-breaking approach that can be applied on any OpenStack
deployment.

We are bringing Serverless and Microservices approaches in applying network services and leveraging
your standard hardware to achieve more from your infrastructure.

We will show how we can transform any OpenStack cloud leveraging common building blocks into a
hyper scale, resource efficient cloud just like the big players Amazon, Google and Facebook do.
Network services should be able to benefit and leverage infrastructure to the max, after this talk
you will know how.
schedule.social_description: Serverless Network Services in OpenStack and Data centers
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How to provide scale out and efficient network virtual services in your OpenStack Cloud, freeing your compute resources to user work load

schedule.title: Magnum 101: Introduction to Magnum
schedule.description: Magnum is at the intsersection of OpenStack and Container technology. Find out how Magnum works, and how you can use it to offer complete container orchestration clusters to your cloud users. Find out what's new in Magnum in the Ocata release, and what's coming next.
schedule.social_description: All about OpenStack Magnum
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to leave this talk with a clear understanding of what Magnum is for, and why they may want to add the Mangum service to their OpenStack clouds.

schedule.title: Building and Operating an OpenStack Cloud with a small team
schedule.description:
ScaleUp has been running a public cloud infrastructure in Germany for a couple of years now. Initially, this cloud was built and operated by a single person. He did spend roughly 10 months on implementing the first installation.

In this presentation we will talk about our best practices and lessons learned, building and operating a public cloud with a team of only two people. We will talk about our setup in general, how we automated adding new nodes, how we accomplished upgrading the infrastructure with almost no downtime and what we do to keep things running smoothly.

We will also focus on day-to-day operations, billing for resource consumption using Ceilometer (and having lots of issues with this), etc.
schedule.social_description: ScaleUp talks about the learnings of operating an OpenStack Cloud with a small team.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will hear about best practices on how to operate a public OpenStack cloud with a small team. How can this task be accomplished by a 2 (2.5) member team when other operators have large teams for this. Also we will talk about our learnings upgrading our OpenStack public cloud across two releases with almost no downtime.

Attendees will also learn about the ups and downs of using Ceilometer to bill for ressource usage.

schedule.title: Evaluation of Cloud Options for Do It Yourself Quick Start Guide
schedule.description:
• Assuming that adopting cloud solution would be the best strategic direction that fulfills company’s vision and long term objectives, the evaluation of various options available is the most important first step.
  • Ericsson Technology Integration is a leader in integrating complex cloud solutions. Our model for evaluation various cloud solutiions and choosing the best option will be presented in this session.  Areas that will be covered are:
    • Tenant Requirement Analysis / Summarization Tool – Use of various tenant workload profiles (e.g. virtualized resource requirements, high-availability and geo-redundancy requirements etc.) to establish E2E solution baseline.
    • One Page Overview of Cloud Options – Overview of grouping of IT environment services for various Cloud solutions offerings (e.g. Openstack KVM/RedHat, VMWare, AWS, Goole, IBM, Microsoft Azure etc.)
    • Evaluation of Cloud Options – evaluate the requirements against the options to establish the baseline cost and timelines.
schedule.social_description: This session is a practical “how to” guide to evaluate cloud options to meet the tenant needs.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: • Learning Expectation: The audience will learn about an overview of multi-faceted approach for evaluating various cloud solutions offerings and learn how to select the option that best suites the needs.

schedule.title: Hybrid cloud storage with OpenStack Swift
schedule.description: The public cloud offers flexibility on where an application can run. Part of the challenge of transitioning workloads to the public cloud involve how to get on-premises data into the public cloud. In this talk, we demonstrate how to utilize OpenStack Swift with SwiftStack to synchronize data with public clouds such as AWS and Google Cloud. This enables these public clouds to be utilized as a second-site, or to take advantage of additional compute resources and services.
schedule.social_description: Hybrid Cloud? Integrate OpenStack Swift with public cloud storage.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about how to syncrhonize on-premises data with public cloud resources

schedule.title: Project Update - Heat
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Heat and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Heat plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Heat PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: m1.Boaty.McBoatface: The joys of flavor planning by popular vote
schedule.description:
As enterprise cloud usage grows, operators struggle to maintain a low-cost, monolithic infrastructure while satisfying users’ increasingly-specialized requirements and usage demands.

Most cloud operators understand the value of OpenStack (Nova) flavors in mitigating this issue, but some struggle to effectively utilize this feature because:

 

  • They lack an adequate process and automation for flavor lifecycle management
  • They look at tenant requirements in a siloed fashion and lack a big picture focus on the larger need to offer specialized, but standardized configurations
  • On the other extreme, they make the mistake of trying to standardize too much without permitting the degree of specialization needed for different use-cases (the 'everything must be the same!' mantra)
  • They have sub-optimal flavor geometries that do not maximize use of available resources

 

In this session we'll look at how to design flavors to prevent these problems.
schedule.social_description: This session will address best practices for host profile design and management in OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about:

  • Flavor terminology, semantics, and conceptual breakdown
  • What can go wrong with flavors (things to avoid, lessons learned)
  • Best practices and industry standards around planning and managing flavors
  • How to manage/mitigate cost of introducing additional flavor offerings
  • Gain an appreciation for some of the design tradeoffs for different optimization decisions
  • How to plan for and account for legacy workloads alongside cloud native workloads with respect to flavors
  • How flavors impacts and links together many disciplines and stakeholders (architecture/planning, operations, end-users, automation, etc)

schedule.title: Marketplace Mixer
schedule.description: All attendees are invited to join us in the OpenStack Marketplace Expo Hall for drinks, snacks and games; this is a great time to mix, mingle and checkout the sponsor booths!
schedule.social_description: Join us in the OpenStack Marketplace for drinks, snacks & check out all of the sponsor booths!

schedule.title: Summit Registration
schedule.description: Hey! It's Day 2. Come get your swag and your badge and get to  your session. Don't miss the keynote!!!
schedule.social_description: Come get your swag and your badge and get to  your session. Don't miss the keynote!!!

schedule.title: Marketplace is Open
schedule.description: Community Marketplace
schedule.social_description: Community Marketplace

schedule.title: Dynamic Network Fabric for NFV
schedule.description: Many NFV use cases (i.e. vCPE, vBRAS and vBNG), all require dynamic scaling, agile resource balancing, and geo redundancy across multiple PoPs (Point of Presence).  We argue that the current OpenStack platform does not handle network dynamics well because its resource allocation is not network-aware but compute-centric. To overcome this, the network fabric needs to be enhanced to be a dynamic platform that can react to failure, resource contention, and performance degradation in the system.  In this talk, we present and demonstrate an OpenStack enhanced dynamic network fabric that offers high availability, manageability, and performance required for carrier-grade. To react to network dynamics we provide underlay network aware PoP level rerouting. Within the PoP, we find the best resource reallocation via bandwidth-guaranteed VM placement. In addition, we use SLA verification to check if the reactions satisfy the SLAs.
schedule.social_description: Enhanced dynamic network fabric that offers high availability/performance required for carrier-grade
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This presentation will introduce our experience of building a vCPE PoC on top of OpenStack with production grade VNFs. Our key differentiator to existing platform is a dynamic network fabric that can be aware of the underlay to make deployment decisions based on changes happening in the underlay. We will show that an intelligent overlay routing and VM placement mechanism are in place to guarantee high performance and availability when workloads are relocated and the underlay network changes.  To bookend these features, a dynamic SLA assurance engine will be shown to catch SLA violations. The presentation will show the design and algorithms for these technologies and show the benefit of significant savings in vCPE resources.

schedule.title: Beyond Automation – Taking Vitrage into the Realm of Machine Learning
schedule.description:
Beyond automated expert analysis - Vitrage takes the first steps into the realm of machine learning.
Vitrage is the official OpenStack project dedicated to root cause analysis (RCA) and deduced insights into the behavior of the Cloud. With the help of a graphical model representing the different relationships between system entities, and a friendly UI, Vitrage hopes to achieve its mission of organizing, analyzing and visualizing a holistic view of the system.
In this talk, we will present and discuss the first steps of augmenting Vitrage with machine learning capabilities. Until recently, Vitrage used mostly humanly-written templates to drive automatic RCA, deduced alarms & states. The next step is to start detecting those rules in the data itself, discovering connections over time from the observed history. Here we will discuss the challenge, where Vitrage is today, and what to expect in the near future in this exciting journey.
schedule.social_description: The first steps of augmenting Vitrage RCA & deduced insights, with machine learning capabilities.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn about some of the new and exciting steps that Vitrage is taking into the realm of Machine Learning, with the focus on discovering how faults impact system behavior and propagate throughout the cloud, generating new insights for Vitrage to use and reflect to users.

schedule.title: OpenStack message bus security with Trove Database-as-a-Service
schedule.description:
Trove is the OpenStack Database-as-a-Service project and allows users to provision and manage the lifecycle of a dozen different database technologies using a single common set of primitives, API and tools. The database instance(s) are run in virtual machines or on bare-metal instances provisioned through Nova and a guest instance includes the chosen database and a guest agent. The guest agent communicates with the control plane over a message bus (oslo_messaging).

A crucial security consideration when deploying Trove is how one properly configures the system to prevent compromised guest instances from becoming an attack vector to the OpenStack deployment as a whole.

This presentation describes specific architectural elements of the Trove project, including a new capability in the Ocata release that allows deployers to encrypt all message bus traffic, and illustrates how this feature makes a Trove system secure and safe to operate in a multi-tenant environment.
schedule.social_description: This talk describes how to securely operate Trove in a multi-tenant deployment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees can expect to learn about specific security related aspects of the Trove architecure, best practices for deploying Trove, sample reference architectures, new security capabilities implemented in the Ocata release, and how Trove's architecture enables it to be safely operated in a multi-tenant environment.

The talk will feature a live demonstration on an OpenStack cloud and users will be able to see a fully configured and operating system.

schedule.title: How Cloud Native VNFs Deployed on OpenStack Will Change the Telecom Industry
schedule.description:
Many of the existing network functions, such as routers, firewalls, load balancers and such, have undergone the initial transition from a physical appliance to a virtual appliance. That transition required mostly performance optimization to accommodate the additional I/O overhead of the hypervisor and some configuration changes to accommodate the fact that a VM can be more dynamic in nature.

This talk will dive into the main requirements that differentiate a cloud native network function from the traditional network function, and, after making the leap from non-virtualized to virtualized network functions, what is then required to achieve cloud native capabilities, along with the challenges and benefits of this transition. It will also discuss how by providing open projects as building blocks, including Neutron, Magnum, Kuryr, among others, OpenStack is playing a major role in powering this revolution.
schedule.social_description: How Cloud Native VNFs Deployed on OpenStack Will Change the Telecom Industry
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn why the open and building-block nature of OpenStack makes it the most future-ready cloud and how the Telecom industry will need to move to a cloud-native world in order to build and future-proof their NFV deployments

schedule.title: AT&T Container Strategy and OpenStack's role in it
schedule.description:
We will present AT&T Container's Strategy and OpenStack's role in it and how OpenStack needs to evolve.

- What type of workload drives AT&T's Container needs?  We will talk about AT&T Entertainment Group's video content delivery and in Mobility and Network Services

- What is driving Containerization?  Beyond the direct benefits of containers around lower footprint and packaging goodness, the DevOps / Infrastructure as Code  benefits of predictability and consistency are also pushing us to move faster

- What is a Container Sandwich?  Running Containers in VMs that are containers themselves & also containerization of OpenStack services and allowing workloads to innovate and BYO container orchestration at least temporarily 

- What is the value of Kolla, Magnum, and Kyuyr? What is missing?

- How do we bridge efforts across OpenStack and CNCF?

- What do we use right now versus what we use in the future?  MK22/Saltstack with Helm-like artifacts
schedule.social_description: AT&T Container's Strategy and OpenStack's role in it and how OpenStack needs to evolve.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Container technology, OpenStack's container related projects

schedule.title: Mastering in troubleshooting NFV issues
schedule.description:
Yesterday, we have been talking about fitting, developing and designing OpenStack as the preferred product for NFVi use case. This involves shaping certain features like SR-IOV, DPDK, CPU pinning, etc to meet telco use cases. Today we have reached into the prime stage of deploying, testing and using openstack in Telco environments. At this stage troubleshooting has a vital role to play.

Working in support organization, troubleshooting NFV issues was one of our primary task. We have come across many issues during and after OpenStack deployment for NFVi, onboarding VNFs, UAT testing, etc which ranges from configuration issues, bugs, non-working of features, booting failure or kernel panic on VNFs, performance issues, etc.

Throughout this session we will explain how to troubleshoot NFV issues using real life examples, share tips and tricks for efficient troubleshooting and importance of collaboration with multiple stakeholders and how to efficiently handle it.
schedule.social_description: Almost everything about troubleshooting OpenStack NFV issues
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Throughout this session we will explain how to troubleshoot NFV issues using real life examples, share tips and tricks for efficient troubleshooting and importance of collaboration with multiple stakeholders and how to efficiently handle it. Attendees will learn troubleshooting techniques for an NFVi deployed using OpenStack with multiple VNFs from different vendors by understanding how to approach different problems at different layer ranging from configuraiton issues, performance, VNF onboarding, bugs, etc.

schedule.title: OpenStack Telemetry and the 10,000 instances
schedule.description:
In this presentation, Julien, Red Hat Project Team Leader for OpenStack Telemetry and Alex, Red Hat performance engineer, will describe how the telemetry stack is now able to measure 10,000 instances easily.

First, they will explain how the telemetry architecture has been reorganized these last cycles to scale horizontally to this point. Then, they will demonstrate the performance tests and benchmarks that have been run to push the telemetry software beyond the scalability limits that were known until now. The results of those tests will be shared and explained to the audience. Finally, our speakers will offer their view on the progress that has been made and the possible next steps for the project.
schedule.social_description: Julien and Alex describes how the telemetry stack is now able to meters 10,000 instances easily.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: By attending this talk, participants will learn how the OpenStack Telemetry has been transformed from a slow beast to a fast-paced project that scales beyond many of most common OpenStack project. They will discover what are the current strengths and pitfalls of the telemetry software and will have a glimpse of what might be coming next for this OpenStack branch.

schedule.title: Accelerating Big Data Processing and Framework Provisioning with OpenStack Heat-based Hadoop/Spark
schedule.description:
Apache Hadoop and Spark are gaining prominence in handling Big Data and
analytics. Default Hadoop and Spark can not leverage the high-performance
networking features (e.g., RDMA, SR-IOV) on modern clouds efficiently. These
frameworks are traditionally written with sockets and do not deliver the best
performance on modern high-performance networks. In this talk, we will provide
an in-depth overview of the architecture of Hadoop and Spark. We will examine
the challenges in re-designing networking components of these frameworks with
modern interconnects and mechanisms (such as IB, RoCE, RDMA). Using the
publicly available software packages in the High-Performance Big Data (HiBD,
http://hibd.cse.ohio-state.edu) project, we will provide case studies of the
new designs for several Hadoop/Spark components and their associated benefits.
Through developing Heat-based complex appliances, we will present the fast
provisioning of these frameworks on OpenStack-based clouds, like NSF Chameleon.
schedule.social_description: Accelerating Big Data Processing and Framework Provisioning with OpenStack Heat
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees can learn from following aspects:

a. Newcomers to the field of Big Data processing can learn the design principles and implementations of Hadoop and Spark, and their enhanced designs with RDMA-enabled high-performance interconnects on modern high-performance clouds.

b. Big Data system and application researchers, designers and developers can learn how to achieve optimal performance for Hadoop and Spark middleware on modern clouds with high-performance interconnects, storage systems (HDD, SSD, NVRAM, NVMe-SSD), and multi/many cores.

c. Next-generation data center designers and cloud architects can learn how to accelerate the provisioning of these high-performance RDMA-based Hadoop and Spark on OpenStack-based environments and understand the performance tradeoffs and characteristics with these frameworks.

schedule.title: Developing software for IoT devices with limited resources using OpenStack
schedule.description: The internet of Things (IoT) is the network of physical objects or "things" embedded with electronics, software, sensors, and network connectivity, which enables these objects to collect and to exchange data. IoT will create new opportunities for more direct and seamless integration between the physical world and computer based systems. What if you can make device handle as much tasks as you’d like without having device modified with additional hardware? What if you can run most of your software on cloud but not on actual IoT device?In this talk we would like to describe how can IoT device software can be developed and workload handled with OpenStack Functions-as-a-Service by decoupling hardware-intensive tasks into what we called “functions”.
schedule.social_description: Developing software for IoT devices with limited resources using OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Key things that attendees will learn during talk:

  • Why IoT programming is truly awesome experience
  • How to delegate IoT software execution to a “functions”
  • Why functions-based IoT software development does not restrict IoT platform choice

schedule.title: Project Update - Horizon
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Horizon and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Horizon plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

 

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Horizon PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: GETting Science & IT Together at OMRF with Swift
schedule.description: The Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation has an abundance of research & business data with various groups in our non profit doing their own storage. The IT department & small set of labs met separate storage needs rapidly with a single OpenStack Swift cluster. The joint project has helped bring together historically “warring” departments. This talk features staff from both Research & Enterprise IT discussing the collaboration to build a shared Swift cluster for the growing needs of Commvault and genomic archive data and then detailing the deciding factors in the selection, including introducing OpenStack to traditionally Microsoft IT (with SwiftStack).  We'll cover detailed aspects of the deployment such as encryption, capacity expansion, & the trek to an offsite region (encrypting slow links with pfsense). This talk will also explore new use cases beyond backup/archive for the after simple Swift API development. All with a CFO approved cost model (hint, it’s bring your own disk)
schedule.social_description: OMRF shares details of their collaborative Swift cluster for scientific & business data storage.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn

* Brief history of OMRF fragmented storage
* how Swift brings this together under one system
* Troubles of grant budget cycles
* Implementation details
* Active Directory authentication
* Commodity hardware selection
* Drive level encryption
* pfsense offsite ipsec vpn
* Expansions
* Successes
* Archive & Commvault backup use cases
* External data delivery with auto deleting data
* Data repository for genomic analysis
* Private docker registry store
* Troubles
* Offsite bandwidth
* Filling quickly
* Adding disks too fast
* Making Install/Service easy for Windows focused IT dept
* SwiftStack
* Ansible
* Metadata importance
* Applying to research data to build a searchable repository for easy sharing
* Quick overview of successes by developing with API
* Custom tool for access control temp url generation
* Wrapping analysis programs that need posix

schedule.title: The Ceph Power Show - Hands-on Lab with Ceph :: Episode 2 - 'The Jewel Story'
schedule.description:
Join our Ceph architects and experts for this guided hands-on lab with Red Hat Ceph Storage. In this session, you will get an expert introduction to Ceph concepts and features, followed by a series of live interactive and hands-on modules

Module 1 : Introduction to OpenStack Storage and Ceph
Module 2 : Understanding why Ceph is now a big deal for OpenStack
Module 3 : Setting up RHCS cluster
Module 4 : Setting up Replicated and Erasure Coded storage pools
Module 5 : Accessing Ceph cluster via Block Storage interface
Module 6 : Accessing Ceph cluster via Object Storage interface
Module 7 : Scaling up a Ceph cluster

This lab is perfect for users of all skills, from beginners looking for an introduction to experienced users who want to drill the experts and explore advanced features related to OpenStack storage. Lab modules are designed for an adaptable pace and to allow free-form work in a sizable lab hosted in the clouds.
schedule.social_description: Ceph Hands-on Lab : A deep dive experience to Ceph
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
By the end of this session attendees will :

  • Have better understanding of Ceph architecture and concepts
  • Hand-on with latest and the greatest RHCS release
  • know how Ceph is one-stop shop for all your OpenStack storage needs
  • Have confidence in installing, setting up and provisioning Ceph in your environment
  • Get experience working with Ceph Block, Object and File storage interfaces

schedule.title: Learn about Keystone to Keystone federation and see it work with Horizon for Ocata
schedule.description: Keystone to Keystone federation has been present since Kilo but not much has been talked about it. In this session we will talk about how it differs from the other forms of federated identity (SAML, OpenIDC). We will talk about the use cases, how it works, setting it up, and how to use it. We will also show what the new horizon UI looks like (from Ocata) when switching between Keystone providers.
schedule.social_description: Learn about Keystone to Keystone federation and see it work with Horizon for Ocata
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees should expect to learn:

  • How Keystone to Keystone federation is different from the other forms of identity federation
  • How it works
  • The use cases
  • How to briefly set it up
  • How to use it

schedule.title: AT&T Cloud Evolution : Virtual to Container based (CI/CD)^2
schedule.description:
AT&T has rapidly deployed more than 80 AIC zones over the past two years; on track for 100 this year. Behind the scenes we have scaled out pipelines enabling iterative development, production reference architecture deployments, and hardware integrated Full Continuous Deployment. These improvements have enabled more frequent releases providing community flexibility, while ensuring enterprise stability. Operational demands of rapid patching moved us from Ansible playbooks to a robust industry-standard mechanism to guarantee state and prevent drift using Lifecycle Management (LCM) and Puppet.

AIC is transitioning to a containerized infrastructure and control plane which includes a redefined set of pipelines, participating in and contributing to the community, and preventing lock-in by ensuring community support. As we evolve, the container-based (CI/CD)2 experience is a first class citizen available for everyone to consume, expand, and participate.
schedule.social_description: AT&Ts existing CI/CD process and future CI/CD challenges for containerized control plane.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about:

  • Implementing OpenStack Build, Test, Deliver, and Quality pipelines in an enterprise environment
  • Fully Automated Deployment using OpsSimple
  • Reduced differences between developer and production deployment workflows
  • CI/CD pipelines responsible for delivering AT&T’s containerized local control plane (cLCP)
  • CI/CD requirements for hosting containerized infrastructure and control plane
  • How to get involved in AT&T’s cLCP CI/CD

schedule.title: SmartNICs - Paving the way for 25G/40G/100G speed NFV deployments in OpenStack
schedule.description:
Red Hat and Netronome will address the growing demand for higher performance from the NFV datapath

NFV applications running on virtualized infrastructure in OpenStack today must achieve 10G linerate. Mobile application VNF vendors demanding  higher speeds with 25G, 40G & 100G links to server.  

Accelerated datapath options today and what lies ahead

  • SR-IOV (in deployment) - bare-metal performance, switching operations (filtering, tunneling, bonding) requires external switch(ToR), VM-to-VM requires hair-pinning at ToR
  • DPDK accelerated openvswitch (OVS-DPDK) (PoC trials) - multiple cores to achieve 10G  line rate;  vswitch supports bonding, firewall, conntrack, tunneling, live migration, but at extra cost
  • SmartNIC Offload  (PoC trials) - offload of OVS flows from vswitch to a SmartNIC eswitch; support for  OVS flow match/action, firewall filtering, tunneling, bonding, NAT, conntrack. Selective acceleration with fallback to vswitch(slow-path). Bare-metal performance, no overhead
schedule.social_description: With the arrival of smartNIC, NFV usecases can get hardware acceleration with feature rich software
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Switch vendors have always used hardware offload with smart ASICs. With the arrival of smartNIC, NFV usecases can get the best of both worlds, hardware acceleration with feature rich software while increasing efficiency

What will be covered?

  • Deployment progression of  NFV datapath  from SR-IOV to OVS-DPDK to HW offload
  • Topologies for HW offload: SR-IOV with OVS offload,  bonding, firewall conntrack usecase,  live migration, partial vs full offload, OVS kernel vs OVS-DPDK offload.
  • Initial performance benchmarks - SR-IOV vs OVS-DPDK vs HW-Offload
  • Integration in Openstack - SR-IOV to NIC with vSwitch fallback, selective flow offload, implications to Nova, Neutron, heat orchestration
  • Limitation of HW offload- vswitch slow-path is slower, max flow capacity, conntrack/NAT support, max 5-tuple filters, prioritizing flows to offload
  • Future of HW offload -  SDN controllers OVN & ODL, programmability (eBPF, P4)

schedule.title: Let OpenStack Applications Control their Destiny
schedule.description:
As OpenStack matures as a platform we see that the infrastructure services are stabilizing in terms of features and interfaces. Therefore, there is enhanced focus on Applications running on OpenStack cloud.
 
A cloud based environment provides flexibility of on-demand resources allocation, mobility, availability for workloads. Unfortunately, today majority of OpenStack APIs are associated with virtual instances instead of applications. As application developers produce software for cloud based deployment, they still cannot seamlessly tap into the flexible cloud based deployment environment because much of the benefits of a cloud based environment revolves around the infrastructure.
 
E.g., auto-scaling of a service in the cloud is a very powerful tool but it remains an infrastructure service and not an API for the application developer. Similarly, Security Profiles, connectivity needs, storage requirements are all attached to the OpenStack instance rather than the Application.
schedule.social_description: How exposing Cloud Infrastructure APIs to Applications Developers can produce resilient Cloud Apps
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn about powerful APIs which exposes the unique features of cloud based deployment environment to your application and how to use them to develop a resiliant and scalable application.

schedule.title: How to train a OpenStack dragon
schedule.description: Many of the aspiring Openstack developers often get overwhelmed by the vastness of code base, the long procedures to follow, the how-tos of open source, the testing strategies, the design patterns, the review culture, the galore of tools in use and above all setting up developer environment. An aspiring Openstack developer will gain the necessary knowledge and confidence to contribute to Openstack in this talk. They will get an imperative head start, learn to be more productive, prioritize right things and start making commits. Senior devs will share their experiences of training new devs & interns, and success stories therein. Presenters include PTL emeritus of Glance and a senior software devop; both have worked on Openstack for more than 4 years, trained new developers and Outreachy interns. One of the presenter is a brand new dev and has already trained a Outreachy intern; but is equally excited to share her experience of learning Openstack from scratch and of teaching the same.
schedule.social_description: A friendly talk on how to start contributing to core Openstack projects.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees especially developers and devops will learn about the upstream development and the DOs and DONTs of committing code to core Openstack projects. They will hear about real world mentorship experiences and interactions with new developers and interns; consequentially gain the knowledge to approach senior developers for getting started on Openstack. They will learn some of the best practices followed in the core projects like Glance. They will have the opportunity to gain insight into the review system and understand the intent behind review comments. Often remarks and direction on the review comments can be misleading so this talk will clarify some of the common styles, relevance, context and culture of the feedback. Attendees will be able to get an idea of how they can make their changes stand out and how they can actually make a difference.

schedule.title: Creating an agile environment for DevOps
schedule.description:
Docker, Puppet, Kubernetes, Ansible, and Jenkins to name a few. DevOps lives on orchestration. Storage enables DevOps and integrates with the products and integrations used by organizations to empower their applications and operations teams.

Storage and infrastructure teams often feel that they exist simply as a service provider to applications teams with the goal of providing a reliable, but featureless, set of low-cost capabilities while letting the application handle the advanced logic.  However, this simply isn't the case.  Infrastructure, and particularly storage, are critical to the success of an application and leveraging the capabilities of the underlying platforms increases effectiveness and efficiency.  Snapshots, cloning, replication, and other features which are made accessible directly to applications ensure their satisfaction and help to enable success for everyone.

Come see how letting go of control of your storage and enabling the applications is the right thing to do!
schedule.social_description: Come learn why letting apps manage their own storage is important!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Provisioning, cloning, testing, and managing storage is easy with OpenStack and container
  • Declarative configuration management tools can assist with managing storage requirements for applications
  • Features of the storage array(s) can provide significant benefit to the application lifecycle

schedule.title: The challenge of openstack performance optimization for 800 nodes in singe region
schedule.description:
The Openstack is becoming more mature in the last few years, but it is still a huge challenge in the scalability, e.g. managing more than 1,000 nodes in the singe region. Generally speaking, the Openstack manages 200-300 nodes in the single region for the routine scenario, because of the performance limitation of some of the main centralized components, a.k.a. rabbitmq, mysql, keystone and haproxy. As the conclusion of test, we found the Opentack has been becoming more and more unstable while the numbers of nodes were over the threshold. For the sake of managing more nodes, we had some work on stratege and architecture including some optimization in code.

I will talk about the following agendas in this session.

1. What's the facts affect the scalability of openstack and metrics of operformance.

2. How to optimize the perfomannce of message queue.

3. How to optimize the performance of database.

4. How to optimize the performance of keystone.
schedule.social_description: The challenge of openstack performance optimization for 800 nodes in singe region
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How the largest single region in China work and what problem we met.

More important, you can see how to optimize the performace for different components.

1. What's the facts affact the scalability of openstack and metrics of operformance.

2. How to optimize the perfomannce of message queue.

3. How to optimize the performance of database.

4. How to optimize the performance of keystone.

schedule.title: Scaling NFV - Are containers the answer?
schedule.description:
Abstract: Containers are the biggest hype today - In the latest Heavy Reading Survey (October 2016), 68.4% of the responders said they will use containers for NFV. While containers provide high scale, low latency and a low startup time, however, no one really understands the complete impact of containers on how it changes the virtualization model for NFV and what impact it has on the networking and orchestration model for NFV.


Containers are well dsigned for scale out applications but for containers to work with NFV we need the ability to assign public IP addresses to containers. That is not so easy as it sounds. 

In this presentation, we will discuss the NFV architecture with containers in detail. In particular we will discuss topics like Kuryr (Containers and Openstack), Container networking, Container instantiation with Openstack, Scale, Performance (Latency and Throughput) and data path acceleration for containers.
schedule.social_description: Are containers ready for NFV? What do you think? explore answers to many of these questions
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Container and how they can be used for NFV

Limitations of containers

Orchestration NFV with VMs and Containers using Openstack

schedule.title: Workload Onboarding and Lifecycle Management with Heat
schedule.description:
As the Openstack community continues to simplify the cloud deployment process, more and more businesses are adopting Openstack within their infrastructure. However, there seems to be a lack of knowledge base in the community regarding workload onboarding and management using tools native to Openstack.

 

This talk introduces the advanced use of Heat (with a particular focus on SoftwareDeployment resources) in order to provide a structured process for deploying and managing workloads in the cloud.

 

At the core of this structured process is a base repository containing basic building blocks for Openstack infrastructure, as well as a structure (with examples) for developing and deploying software configurations at all phases of an instance’s lifecycle.


The target audience for this talk is the cloud end-user who has some familiarity with Heat (or other similar cloud orchestration tools), as well as devops teams managing cloud resources on behalf of cloud non-friendly users.
schedule.social_description: Using Heat to provide with a structured process for deploying and managing workloads in the cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Requirements for using SoftwareDeployments
  • How to use SoftwareDeployments to deploy software configurations resources at any phase of the instance lifecycle
  • Best practices surrounding the use of SoftwareDeployments
  • A base structure for developing new or custom software configurations
  • How to keep track of existing workloads in the cloud at different update cycles over time

schedule.title: Project Update - Ironic
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Ironic and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Ironic plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.
