Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

 

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Ironic PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Grow your community: Inspire an impostor
schedule.description:
The OpenStack community is highly collaborative, fast-paced, and helpful. However, some new community members are overwhelmed with new terminology and detailed processes, especially those with impostor syndrome.  They struggle with an internal battle where their confidence and competence are not aligned.

Impostor syndrome is a psychological phenomenon that affects people from all backgrounds and all skill levels. They feel like their competence level is much lower than it really is and they feel this way on a regular basis. This can cause community members to become detached or feel incapable of providing meaningful contributions.

This isn’t simply being humble -- it’s something entirely different.

Major Hayden, principal architect at Rackspace, will lead the audience through a discussion around impostor syndrome, how to identify it, and how to overcome it.
schedule.social_description: Impostor syndrome stifles open source communities. Learn how to define, identify, and overcome it.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn how to define impostor syndrome through a brief story, a humorous series of images, and a more clinical explanation. We will also talk about how to identify impostor syndrome in ourselves and within an open source community.

Finally, we will use the OODA loop to give attendees guidance for overcoming impostor syndrome for themselves and for others in their community.

schedule.title: Get me a network: from boot to woot!
schedule.description:
The OpenStack Networking API has a very fine-grained control over the networking resources made available to cloud users. While this is considered a strength for some use cases, it may also be a source of frustration for users when their primary use case is to get compute-centric workloads up and running quickly.

This presentation will introduce a networking feature also known as 'get-me-a-network'. This feature is designed to automate the basic networking provisioning for OpenStack workloads: rather than letting cloud users handle networking setup steps themselves, nova and neutron coordinate the provisioning of networking resources during the VM boot process, thus making the networking setup transparent.

The presentation will cover which use cases fit for this feature, the community effort behind the design, the development, and the integration of the feature, as well how to further improve it, and build on it to deliver a great user experience.
schedule.social_description: Learn how to give Internet access to your VMs without a networking degree.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The new user experience to provide VMs with networking connectivity. The community process to successfully deliver such a feature.

schedule.title: OpenStack TCO/ ROI - Going beyond Cost per VM
schedule.description:
Existing TCO models for OpenStack clouds [1,2,3] are focused heavily around cost savings/ cost per virtual machines. They also tend to be focused heavily on a specific vendor offering. ROI models, on other hand, are pratically non-existent. This trend is not unique to just OpenStack private clouds. TCO models for AWS public cloud also tend to focus on VMs and extend to some other services. However, true ROI from adopting cloud services comes from the business agility it enables. Currently, there are no TCO/ ROI models that quantify this.

This talk summarizes our research at CloudDon [5] and presents TCO/ ROI for OpenStack clouds from the perspective of representative workloads and consumption models. This also goes beyond existing metrics such as Cost Per Vm or Cost Per TB by quantifying business impact OpenStack enables.
schedule.social_description: Do you know TCO of OpenStack cloud? Does your ROI model quantify business impact? Attend to know
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees are expected to learn complete TCO models on OpenStack cloud based on representative workloads. They will also learn true ROI on OpenStack investments by quantifying business impact it enables.

schedule.title: 300 microservices, 200 datastores and 11 months later: moving Snapdeal from public to private cloud
schedule.description:
Snapdeal is one of India's largest ecommerce organization which successfuly migrated from a public to a hybrid cloud built on top of Openstack. The talk will dive into what you need to plan and execute a succesful cloud migration with five 9s uptime of service oriented architecture with over 300 microservices. We will share our strategy of service groups and dependancy graph planning, highlight risks and give audience insight into what tools we built to leverage the hybrid cloud for cost optimization and on demand scalibility.

 

Along with strategy of migration, we will give attendees a demo of our orchestration toolset used to do this migration which includes dendrite: our take on infrastructure as code, terraform and how we can spin up Snapdeal on demand. We hope that this talk will give attendees insight to plan their own migration strategy for a cloud native load.
schedule.social_description: 300 microservices, 200 datastores and 11 months later: moving Snapdeal from public to private cloud
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
- Strategies on how to migrate a large microservices workload from public to private cloud

- Tooling required for such migration

- Lessons learnt and pitfalls while doing such a migration

- Help attendees with toolset that could be used to build hybrid cloud orchestration

schedule.title: The power of collaboration: How cross-community collaboration benefits both CNCF and OpenStack
schedule.description: Open source values collaboration. The collaborations take place within a community, and across communities. The collaboration between CNCF and the broader OpenStack community eliminates boundaries, and members of both groups participate in design collaboration to produce a more responsible development process. Although the cross-community collaboration is usually difficult in practice, the developers working in the mentioned communities make it work seamlessly with a shared common focus on solving technical problems. In this panel, you will hear developers involved with Kolla-Kubernetes and OpenStack-Helm talking about their first-hand experiences of working with the Kubernetes/Helm project by identifying operator’s gaps and communicating requirements through live design sessions targeted at the development of Kolla-Kubernetes and OpenStack-Helm. We want to cover approaches that have worked for both sides, and also cover some lessons learned for future collaborative efforts.
schedule.social_description: The power of collaboration: How cross-community collaboration benefits both CNCF and OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Why is such a collaboration beneficial to both communities
  • What collaborative approaches were used to form a communication pipeline between the two communities
  • Examples of tangible results from the collaboration

        - Issues

        - Pull Requests

        - Design (paths made possible)

        - Upstream Approach Validation

schedule.title: Protecting Plaintext Password in OpenStack Service Configuration Files
schedule.description: Current OpenStack services require plaintext passwords and credentials for various access, e.g. database, keystoneauth, etc.  Even with proper file permissions set on these files, often time during troubleshooting sessions, these configuration files are send via emails without the passwords properly redacted.  Also, the ability to change passwords across multiple nodes are heavily relying on the deployment tools of choice (ansible, fuel, etc.).  This talk discusses a proof of concept in the work to leverage barbican key-management service as a way to mitigate these two problems and handle configuration management.
schedule.social_description: Configuration security and management with barbican
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Some of the results from the proof of concepts conducted internally, and discussion on additional improvement in this space.

schedule.title: Deploying Containerized Openstack : Challenges & Tools Comparison
schedule.description:
Nowadays many tools to deploy Openstack in Containers are used, some of them are Kolla-kubernetes, Stackenetes etc but which is the best and what should i choose as an Operator or cloud provider?" is a very big question.

As an cloud Operator which can be best container based openStack deployment in the market. Why to choose Kolla-Kubernetes or any other tool? Differences and their brief comparison among all the container based deployment would be covered in talk. Kolla-k8s and Openstack both uses the kubernetes to maintain the life cycle of the deployed services.

If they are using the same or different tool to manage the life cycle they which one is effieciently utilizing the tools this property and upto what extent and for what specific purpose.

All the comparison based talk would be presented.
schedule.social_description: Deploying Containerized Openstack : Challenges & Tools Comparison
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: After the completion of this presentation audience will be able to opt the best technique for container based deployment of openStack, which also manages the lifecycle of the services from operator or cloud provider perspective.

schedule.title: Successfully Redefining a Vendor-Customer Relationships in a DevOps World
schedule.description:
DevOps demands continuous delivery and direct interaction which is often not part of typical vendor-customer relationships.

SAP and SUSE have been collaborating on the deployment of enterprise-sized OpenStack clouds for the HANA Cloud Platform, with the goal of being able to significantly scale up (# of nodes) and out (# of AZ & clouds) in the near future.  During this collaboration, many lessons were learned about the technical and procedural challenges of implementing, operating and maintaining larger clouds.

In this talk we will not only explain the difficulties encountered and how we dealt with them, but more importantly how this prompted us to question the fundamental assumptions and limitations of the traditional vendor-customer relationship, and make a paradigm shift to a true partnership. Adopting a more agile collaboration model allows the vendor to react more quickly to customer requirements and gives the customer more influence on ongoing design and engineering activities.
schedule.social_description: Redefining Vendor-Customer Relationships in a DevOps World: an enterprise story from SAP and SUSE
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Experiences from real world scenarios at scale
  • How to improve the vendor/customer relationship
    • building ONE team that delivers a service
    • enabling code sharing (open sourcing)
    • using same collaboration tools
    • encourage direct communication and reduce process barriers
  • DevOps model between departments and across organizations
  • Upstream collaboration and requirements sharing

schedule.title: Project Update - Keystone
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Keystone and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Keystone plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Keystone PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Free my organization to pursue cloud native infrastructure!
schedule.description: Hear from a real deployment of OpenStack at East Carolina University in Greenville, NC.  Here we discuss what steps we undertook to both evaluate and start our OpenStack Journey to transform our IT services that we provide to over 23,000 students on our higher-education campus.  Also covered is what advise we have for you to start off on the right foot and avoid some of the pitfalls that we've discovered!
schedule.social_description: Our OpenStack journey at East Carolina University (ECU), and how flexible solutions helped us.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn why we've chosen OpenStack for our campus IT infrastructure, why we've chosen OpenStack, and where we are taking our deployment next. Attendees will also gain insight into the risk and reward versus the effort of building vs buying infrastructure for an OpenStack deployment.

schedule.title: WAN Traffic Control as a Service in Neutron
schedule.description:
Today, OpenStack admins can define network entities and VM-level policies in Neutron, but not on the Tenant / Network level.

The lack of tenant / network level traffic control at the WAN gate can result in high network bills, by allowing cross-site traffic to grow unchecked.

This problem is further exacerbated by the the increase in SD-WAN deployments and the growing popularity of hybrid (private/public) cloud solutions - both of which rely on WAN traffic.

We introduce a new open source project for defining WAN Traffic Control as a Service in Neutron.  This project is designed as a Neutron service plugin, extending the API with new capabilities.

We also introduce a software reference implementation based on Linux TC that requires zero configuration at the underlay network layer.
schedule.social_description: WAN Traffic Control as a Service for Neutron
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn about the new WAN Traffic Control as a Service project, and the new possibilities it brings for further development by the community and vendors.

schedule.title: Build production ready container platform based on Magnum and Kubernetes
schedule.description:
Have you containerized your applications running on Kubernetes atop OpenStack? No. Why? Right now Magnum is act as container infrastructure management service, it’s not enough to meet customers’ requirements. For example, private image repository, CI/CD tools, etc are needed to deliver a more featured production ready container platform. 

During the development of container platform for our OpenStack customers, we had done the following work, including but not limited to: 1) Focus on the Kubernetes COE Driver in Magnum, and introduce more production necessary features to it, like DNS, Ingress, Prometheus, EFK. 2) Integrate Harbor as private image repository and Jenkins as CI/CD engine. 3) Add unified authorization/authentication layer to different subsystem among OpenStack, Harbor, Jenkins, and Kubernetes. 4) Optimize Magnum code, like async API operations and multi API workers to make API response more quickly.

In this presentation, we will detail on how to resolve these problems.
schedule.social_description: Build production ready container platform based on Magnum and Kubernetes
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
a) Focus on the Kubernetes COE Driver in Magnum, and introduce more production necessary features to it, like internal DNS, Ingress, Prometheus, EFK(Elasticsearch, Fluentd, Kabana).

b) Integrate Harbor as private image repository and Jenkins as CI/CD engine.

c) Add an unified authorization/authentication layer to different subsystem among OpenStack, Harbor, Jenkins, and Kubernetes.

d) Optimize Magnum code, like async API operations and multi API workers to make API response more quickly.

schedule.title: Proactive support and Customer care
schedule.description:
Day after day, you deal with the components of OpenStack. You see them and you can work with them and fix bugs, but what if you have a production cloud? How do you care for it? What if someone breaks it trying to correct a problem? What if it's YOU?

In our support practice, we see a lot of issues, some of them hard to fix, some of them not so hard.

Mostly, we see a fear of the unknown, a fear that any move you make will burn the house down.

In this session, we'll teach you how to support any of your clouds while avoiding any unexpected behaviour by using simple tools and Monitoring systems.

In this talk we will discuss:

  • Architectural issues created by humans
  • How to avoid cloud a breakdown
  • Support best practices learned from real enterprise issues
  • Simple cloud monitoring that helps avoid issues
  • Engineer's fears and how to soothe them
schedule.social_description: In our support practice, we see a lot of issues. Mostly, we see a fear of the unknown.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about:

  • Simple cloud monitoring
  • Cloud etiquette
  • How to quickly fix your cloud
  • How to deal with production breakdowns
  • Cloud support best practice

schedule.title: Wow I finally understand Neutron: A Hands-On Workshop about Neutron Networking
schedule.description: We know Neutron is super powerful but were lost when trying to use it? In this hands-on workshop, participants will take a fun, and educational journey through Neutron and how it relates to real-world networking basics. Each participant will gain hands-on Neutron experience by receiving credentials to a live OpenStack environment! By the end of this hands-on workshop, participants will not only know how to create networks, subnets, routers, floating ips, and security groups, but truly understand the important actions taking place behind the scenes that make all of it a reality! No prior OpenStack experience is necessary!
schedule.social_description: This "intro" workshop answers the question:  "What is OpenStack Neutron and how do I use it?".
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will first learn about the history of software defined networking and the origin of the Neutron project. A cohesive review of the OSI model and linux networking tools/features will lay the foundation for how Neutron provides powerful multi-tenant isolation . Each Participant will then gain hands-on Neutron experience by accessing a live OpenStack environment where they will learn how to create networks,subnets,routers,floating ips, and security groups! By the end of this workshop, attendees will not only walk away with the knowledge on how to operate Neutron, but the confidence to engage with others about the project!

schedule.title: Containers Networking using Kuryr -- A Hands-on lab.
schedule.description:
Kuryr aims to be the “integration bridge” between the two communities, Docker and Neutron.

It also intends to propose and drive changes needed in Neutron (or in Docker) to be able to fulfill the use cases needed specifically for containers networking.

The Kuryr effort is focused to be the courier that delivers Neutron networking and services to Docker.

In this lab, attendees will setup Kuryr and integrates with Neutron networking. 

Attendees will also do hybrid setup where they will create VMs and containers using docker on same network  as a part of lab exercise .
schedule.social_description: Containers Networking using Kuryr -- A Hands-on lab.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This hands-on lab is intended for openstackers with intermediate knowledge of OpenStack Networking (Neutron) and some hands-on experience with Docker containers. Attendees will learn about the project Kuryr and how it enables network communication among containers and also between a container and virtual machine.

schedule.title: Self-Analyzing & Auto-Remediating Cloud Platform Certification
schedule.description:
This self-healing, adaptive, and auto-remediating process for Cloud ecosystems is powered by the continuous execution of fully automated health checks. The health checks are executed in production against all availability zones, in 24/7 timeframe.

The results and related available resources are then logged, stored, monitored, and mined for potential issues. Any identified issues are then auto-triaged, and where possible auto-debugged, via a combination of data mining, data warehousing, and various modern pattern-identification methods and technologies. Issues are then auto-remediated on the fly without impacting end users. By leveraging this combination of data science and automation with the intent of automatically finding and fixing issues, we enable higher Cloud platform reliability and availability numbers.
schedule.social_description: Advanced Cloud Certification process enabling auto debugging, self analyzing and auto remediation.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The session will enable audience how to tackly the problems associated with private cloud implementation. It will further bootstrap them on advanced certification methods that will provide a complete automation for:

  • Fine tuning the functional tests into automated health checks to be executed in production environment in multiple availability zones
  • Execute health checks frequently and monitor results, create metrics
  • Develop rule based pattern engine which identifies issues and does auto debugging
  • Remediate issues even before it starts impacting end users

schedule.title: OpenStack, Kubernetes and SaltStack for complete deployment automation
schedule.description:
Development and ops teams have to keep up with growing business requirements. On the one hand, software services are getting more complex, and you need to integrate multiple pieces of software for varying business requirements. On the other hand, time to market delivery cycles for products and related services are shortening, making efficient and rapid operations even more crucial.

OpenStack Heat offers blueprints for infrastructure, Kubernetes provides service definitions for containers, and SaltStack provides application stack definitions automating the entire delivery process for both approaches.

This talk presents the new salt-formulas project, which provides an ecosystem of more than 100 services, as well as how we can reuse the same components that power OpenStack itself for automation of the cloud or container workload as well. A demonstration that shows the provisioning of an application to both Kubernetes and OpenStack from the same formula definitions concludes the talk.
schedule.social_description: OpenStack, Kubernetes and SaltStack integration for complete build and deployment automation.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Openstack Heat templates
  • Kubernetes services
  • The Salt-formulas ecosystem
  • Reclass metadata management
  • Jenkins CI/CD pipelines

schedule.title: Finding the Balance between Open Source and Proprietary Work
schedule.description:
Many developers are required to work on a proprietary company project, but they must also maintain active in the Open Source community. "We need new features, and to release our product next month, but you also need to make sure you maintain contributing" said the manager. This is a hard feat to accomplish, which many struggle with.

With the evolution of services, companies must determine what goes in OpenSource and what to keep proprietary. Compaines do not wish to contribute their Intellectual Property, but still want to make an impact on the OpenStack community. This also becomes a struggle. What can and can't we contribute, and will our companies IP ever be allowed into an OpenStack project?

This panel will cover experiences on the above topics from various different OpenStack contributors, who do not fully work on OpenSource.
schedule.social_description: This panel will cover experiences from various different OpenStack contributors on time management.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendess should expect to learn:

  • What can and can’t be contributed to the OpenSource community. There are items which remain intellectual property, however there is a process of contributing Intellectual Property which varies by company.
  • Various tips and tricks to the OpenStack Community.
  • How to maintain active in an OpenStack project while spending the time on proprietary projects.

schedule.title: SAP’s Converged Cloud powered by OpenStack
schedule.description:
OpenStack in the Enterprise at global scale? Join us and take

a look behind the curtains of Converged Cloud’s infrastructure

powering SAP’s Cloud offerings.

 

Converged Cloud offers a multitude of advanced services like

LBaaS, DNSaaS, NFSaaS and Monasca Monitoring all implemented

on industry standard enterprise ready backends.

 

We will take you on a journey beginning with the user experience

we offer to our customers, gradually descending further

down towards the heart of the machine making stops at

our Kubernetes based container infrastructure  for deploying, running

and updating OpenStack in 13 Regions, looking at our packets

flowing through the L2/L3 infrastructure implemented on top

of Neutron HPB and watch Kubernetes nodes auto deploying

to scale out the capacity.

 

Finally we will discuss what is missing in OpenStack to transform 13 individually

Installed OpenStack Regions to a single multi tenant Cloud Platform

and how DMVPN, MPLS and L3VPN’s helped with that problem.
schedule.social_description:
A look behind the curtains of Converged Cloud
powering SAP’s Cloud offerings on OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
We will be giving an inside into Enterprise

Cloud requirements and how they differ from

the widely discussed service provider use-case.

We show how OpenStack features like Neutron 

HPB helped to build an infrastructure that has scaled

to 13 Regions and thousands of VM's running in

an uptime critical business.

 

We will showcase how we architected a control/dataplane

split that allows customer payloads to be responsive even

if the entire OpenStack control infrastructure (API/DB/Messaging)

is crashing.

 

We will also introduce our Helm/Kubernetes based deployment 

mechanism which is alowing us to roll a consistent code-base

to all our Datacenters in a continuous delivery fashion.

schedule.title: High Availability for Instances: Moving to a Converged Upstream Solution
schedule.description:
Whilst HA of the OpenStack control plane is mostly a solved problem, HA for guest VMs and compute nodes is still a work in progress, with several partially overlapping implementations available based on masakari, Pacemaker, Mistral, and others.

This talk from core members of the OpenStack HA team presents the latest news on a project to converge on a single upstream solution which is modular, flexible, and provides a smooth migration path from already deployed solutions. This project aims to address the User Story defined and prioritised by the Product Working Group in order to address the common requirement for operators who need to run legacy "pet" workloads within their OpenStack clouds.

We will also explain how developers and operators can get involved in this project in order to provide guest HA in their own clouds.
schedule.social_description: High Availability for Instances: Moving to a Converged Upstream Solution
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees can expect to learn:

  • What High Availability of the compute plane (compute nodes, hypervisors, and guest VMs) entails
  • Why High Availability of the compute plane is important
  • A summary of the solutions currently available upstream
  • The status and future plans of the project to converge these solutions
  • How they can get involved with the project

schedule.title: Taking Openstack to the next level with highly available instances
schedule.description:
In this session, we'll define what highly available instances are, explain why it is important to users, show how to effectively manage mixed pet and cattle workloads and show how highly available instances relate to Service Level Agreements.  Additionally we'll cover the state of Instance Ha, what is supported now and what's coming in the future.

Service level agreements with clients are key to being successful whether it be a private or public OpenStack cloud.  Just having a highly available Openstack installation may not be enough to satisfy that requirement. Highly available instances takes Openstack to the next step, ensuring that evacuable instances stay up and running when a compute node or hypervisor unexpectedly goes down. This session will address several uses cases related to the need for evacuable and non-evacuable instances and how they relate to SLA contracts.
schedule.social_description: Taking OpenStack to the next level with highly available instances, what does is mean?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Understand what highly available instances is and why it is important to your Openstack installation

Understand how highly available instances relate to SLAs and your customers

Understand the state of Instance Ha, what is supported now and what is coming in the future

schedule.title: Tales of 5 woman making AT&T a leader in openstack adoption
schedule.description: AT&T has publicly announced its aggressive goals to virtualize the services it delivers. It has been successful in meeting its goals so far on an OpenStack based Cloud platform. In this panel discussion you will hear from 5 women that are from the SD&E organization in AT&T who have been key contributors to this success from the inception of this program. They play varied roles in planning, requirements, development and testing areas at different levels from a general manager to engineers. You will hear about their current responsibilities, backgrounds and their rapid evolution into catalysts of the rapid growth of AT&T’s Openstack Cloud.
schedule.social_description: Hear from AT&T Women OpenStack leaders on their journeys!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: You may be a technologist or a manager. You might be from data center management, application development, QA or some related discipline! If you want to hear about successful journeys of five women just like you who are blazing their trails in the OpenStack program at AT&T, this panel discussion is the right place for you to be at!

schedule.title: Using ANSIBLE and RESTful APIs to provision OpenStack Physical Infrastructure
schedule.description:
"Getting the infrastructure right" is critical for a successful OpenStack deployment.  Automating the infrastructure setup and configuration can mitigate human error.  Join us as we present and demonstrate a case study on automating infrastructure deployment with Ansible and REST APIs.
 
Topics covered:
1. Using REST APIs to import infrastructure inventory into Ansible
2. Using Ansible to configure:
 - Network switches
 - Management processors
 - Server BIOS
 - Server storage arrays
3. Using Ansible to install OpenStack
schedule.social_description: Using ANSIBLE and RESTful APIs to provision OpenStack Physical Infrastructure
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. Using REST APIs to import infrastructure inventory into Ansible
2. Using Ansible to configure:
 - Network switches
 - Management processors
 - Server BIOS
 - Server storage arrays
3. Using Ansible to install OpenStack

schedule.title: Project Update - Kolla
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Kolla and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Kolla plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Kolla PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Short history of OpenStack Projects’ security pitfalls
schedule.description: This talk lists out the security vulnerabilities and pitfalls we have come across with earlier OpenStack releases and how they were fixed. It is a retrospective on some diverse security issues that crept into OpenStack and their effects on the project. The idea is to educate the future developers, operators and users about these security vulnerabilities so that they are not repeated. These previous vulnerabilities can be used as starting point for security testing of any new OpenStack project. We can learn from our mistakes and improve the security landscape for OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: To educate on security pitfalls that affected earlier releases of OpenStack and prevent them.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: gain knowledge about previous security pitfalls and vulnerabilities that affected the earlier OpenStack releases and learn from the mistakes to improve the security landscape for OpenStack.

schedule.title: Making OpenStack-Ansible work for you!
schedule.description:
OpenStack-Ansible (OSA) is a (cleverly named) project for deploying production OpenStack clouds, with Ansible. OSA is designed to be customizable and flexible, and the OSA team is always looking for ways to help make it easier for people to get involved in, and to use OSA the way they want.

 

If any of the statements below sound like you, then this talk is for you:

  • "I'm looking to deploy OpenStack, and integrate my existing tooling (monitoring/logging/etc)"
  • "I'm involved in a new OpenStack project, I'd love to integrate it with a full OpenStack deploy and provide deployers a mechanism to deploy it in production"
  • "I'm a developer looking to get involved in OpenStack deployments - where do I start?"

This talk is all about enabling operators, and developers, and showing you how you can utilize OpenStack-Ansible to achieve your goals.

Using examples , I will show you how you can solve your issues, and talk about some of the things we are doing to make this even easier in the future.
schedule.social_description: How can you get involved in OpenStack-Ansible and make it work for you?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
During this talk you can expect to learn:

  • An overview of OpenStack-Ansible and its architecture.
  • How to integrate existing applications with OpenStack-Ansible.
  • How to start a new OpenStack-Ansible role, and how to integrate it fully.
  • Where to get started as a new developer looking to get involved in OpenStack-Ansible.

schedule.title: Don't Fail at Scale: How to Plan for, Build, and Operate a Successful OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description:
OpenStack is a unique set of cross-functional, fast-moving technologies that challenge the status quo in any IT organization.  It has been easy to read about and buy into the interweaving of compute, storage, and networking technologies in a single platform.  Despite such amazing promise and technology, technology is littered with companies who have tried and failed to deliver a successful, scaleable, supportable OpenStack cloud to their customers.

Architects and IT teams tasked with designing and deploying OpenStack clouds could face multiple challenges that impact the result of a successful deployment.  We will discuss what you need to consider before, during, and after an OpenStack cloud deployment that will help make it successful and meet business and IT needs of any organization.
schedule.social_description: We made the mistakes so you don't have to.  Learn about what makes OpenStack deployments a success.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Anyone planning for, building, scaling or operating an OpenStack cloud who has had challenges and successes in the past.

schedule.title: Using Software-Defined WAN implementation to turn on advanced connectivity services in OpenStack
schedule.description:
OpenStack Neutron is the networking component of the OpenStack architecture that enables network virtualization (NV). It enables the creation of overlay networks that are decoupled from the underlying network hardware and runs independently on top of a physical network. But it is often not enough for an enterprise or a telco to deploy OpenStack for networking using standard Open vSwitch, Linux Bridge, or the standard ML2 plugin.

This session will illustrate the integration of SDN with OpenStack - how they work together and why they need to work together to provide connectivity services such as Service Chaining, SDDC, SD-WAN and WAN optimization, as well as security services such as Firewall and Intrusion detection. Attendees will learn: (a) Differences between SDN and NFV (b) How OpenStack enable SDN and NFV to easily work together (c) Typical Challenges encountered and how they can be overcome / mitigated and (d) Use case of a large Tier 1 telco
schedule.social_description: OpenStack for networking using standard Neutron is not always enough. Learn how SDN complements
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn: (a) Differences between SDN and NFV (b) How OpenStack enable SDN and NFV to easily work together (c) Typical Challenges encountered and how they can be overcome / mitigated and (d) Use case of a large Tier 1 telco

schedule.title: Red Hat Openstack Certification Program
schedule.description: Certification is a way that many software vendors identify to test how a professional know about products and technologies. In Cloud Computing is not much different. Red Hat provide a certification program to certify Engineers in Openstack Platform. After this presentation, attendees will be able to understand how to get this certification level and how this certification can improve your careers, increase opportunities and bring knowledge for inside companies.
schedule.social_description: Alessandro Silva work as Cloud Success Architect at Red Hat
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How to get a Certification Program in Red Hat Openstack Platform

schedule.title: Cinder node Resiliency (Handling Media, Network and Software Failures)
schedule.description: Fault Tolerant Storage is a given for any enterprise storage solution. This lightning talk highlights efficient ways to handle various faults like Storage Media Failures, Network Failures, Software Failures in a cinder node. This session will also cover efficient ways of migration of workloads across cinder nodes.
schedule.social_description: This session will cover efficient ways to handle cinder node resiliency
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees to this session will learn how cinder node resiliency can be handled

schedule.title: Deploy OpenStack Service Chaining using Heat
schedule.description:
This presentation will give,

- Overview about Service chaining and Heat (template-based orchestration mechanism),

- Brief introduction about Heat orchestration engine, Heat resource plugin, Heat orchestrate Templates(HOT), template parameters.

- Examples of how you can deploy collections of resources -- networks, servers, storage, and more -- all from a single, parameterized template and demo to setup SFC network and compute node infrastructure using HOT templates
schedule.social_description: Deploy OpenStack Service Chaining using HOT
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
[1] Overview about - Heat orchestration engine - Heat resource plugin - HOT templates and parameters

[2] How to create heat stack

[3] Demo to look on Service Chaining deployment using  HOT and  feel the explained concepts

schedule.title: Storage Capabilities in Cinder
schedule.description:
Come and learn Cinder’s many cool features including the following:

- Volume migration that allows a volume to be migrated from one backend/pool to another;

- Image volume cache that allows a boot volume to be created more efficiently;

- Replication v2.1 that allows a storage backend to be failed over to recover from a disaster;

- Backup/restore that provides data protection for the storage backend. 

- Generic volume groups that allows volumes used by an application to be managed together.

Upon the completion of this session, you will learn what storage capabilities are supported in Cinder and what may be coming in the future.
schedule.social_description: Come and learn storage capabilities in Cinder such as migration and replication.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees will learn the storage capabilities supported by Cinder such as the following as well as what may be coming in the future:

- Volume migration that allows a volume to be migrated from one backend/pool to another;
- Image volume cache that allows a boot volume to be created more efficiently;
- Replication v2.1 that allows a storage backend to be failed over to recover from a disaster;
- Backup/restore that provides data protection for the storage backend.
- Generic volume groups that allows volumes used by an application to be managed together.

schedule.title: FWaaS v2 - A new beginning
schedule.description:
The Firewall as a Service (FWaaS) team has been busy over the last couple of cycles coming up with an alternate model to the existing API (from Havana) to make it more usable based on feedback from a number of quarters. The FWaaS v2 API enables users to apply collections of firewall rules as a policy on a neutron port (both Layer3 & VM). Further, we can selectively apply different policies for ingress and egress traffic.

Security is needed at multiple levels and to protect against attacks originating internally, which prompts a need to support richer Security abstractions at the VM interface as well. At this point in the network, with the presence of Security Groups, the implementation takes care to exist as an additional layer over the Security Group API to provided additional enhancements.

Details of the API, along with the detailed use cases and a demo will be presented. A Roadmap of features for the Pike release and onwards and discussions for user feedback will also be covered.
schedule.social_description: The FWaaS v2 API  with detailed use cases, demo, roadmap and user feedback.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees will get familiar with the FWaaS v2 API. The use cases can help users see how they can  deploy it in their own cloud environments. We would also like this to be a forum to connect with (potential) users to get their feedback and help drive priorities for the roadmap and the Pike release specifically.

schedule.title: OpenStack and OpenDaylight: An integrated IaaS for SDN and NFV
schedule.description:
OpenDaylight is an open source project under the Linux® Foundation with the goal of furthering the adoption and innovation of SDN. Red Hat is bundling a distribution of OpenDaylight as part of its Red Hat® OpenStack® Platform, featuring the OpenDaylight NetVirt application as an integrated back-end to OpenStack Neutron.

In this session, we will talk about the journey we have taken to productize OpenDaylight at Red Hat. We will cover:

- What is OpenDaylight
- Use cases for OpenDaylight with OpenStack
- The OpenDaylight NetVirt project
- How OpenDaylight interacts with OpenStack
- The Red Hat OpenStack Platform offering
- How we see OpenDaylight help solve challenges in the networking industry, such as container networking and physical network fabric management, the open source way

 

We will focus on networking technical and cultural challenges, and how OpenDaylight is uniquely architected to serve as the right foundational framework for SDN and network functions virtualization (NFV).
schedule.social_description: How OpenDaylight is uniquely architected to serve as the right foundational framework for SDN/NF
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this session, we will talk about the journey we have taken to productize OpenDaylight at Red Hat. We will cover:

- What is OpenDaylight

- Use cases for OpenDaylight with OpenStack

- The OpenDaylight NetVirt project

- How OpenDaylight interacts with OpenStack

- The Red Hat OpenStack Platform offering

- The future of OpenDaylight, and how we see it help solve challenges in the networking industry, such as container networking and physical network fabric management, the open source way

We will focus on networking technical and cultural challenges, and how OpenDaylight is uniquely architected to serve as the right foundational framework for SDN and network functions virtualization (NFV).

schedule.title: The Evolution of the User Group: Facilitating OpenStack Adoption
schedule.description:
Now that OpenStack has reached a stage of maturity that makes it an attractive enterprise platform, its continued growth over the next 12 months is going to depend not only on the technical contributors (both from individuals and companies), but more essentially from widespread ADOPTION by companies and organizations in the real world.  Within the community, the conversation has shifted from how to best architect the code (and measure such contributions), to how to make it easier to install, deploy, and bring OpenStack-based clouds into production. The question is: What role do/should user groups play in this?

This panel includes leaders in architecting and building OpenStack communities that have expertise and creativity in trying new things and bringing new results to and from our user groups. Collectively, we are responsible for 4 of the largest communities in OpenStack (including the west coast user group Ambassador, and fast-growing Women of OpenStack community).
schedule.social_description: Architecting User Groups to develop community and facilitate OpenStack adoption
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this session you will learn from community leaders about what is the role of the User Groups, the Community Architects, and the OpenStack Ambassadors in growing the adoption of OpenStack.

  • How we can change how we define "success” in OpenStack and how can can orchestrate our local communities to rally behind this initiative? 
  • Where have the biggest growth areas in OpenStack been?
  • How has the impact of Telcos, NFV, and SDN adoption, as well as large public clouds in Asia pushed OpenStack back to the forefront of conversations?
  • What impact will new and disruptive technologies like Containers, AI, IoT, and Machine Learning have on OpenStack and what opportunities do they bring (from a community/user group architect perspective)? 

Come hear 4 of our top community leaders talk about how we have successfully organized and orchestrated our communities to contribute to the success of OpenStack and ensure a bright future!

schedule.title: Moving Toward Efficient Usage of Cloud Resources
schedule.description:
Allowing business agility and developer ease of access to shared and costly cloud resources often leads to the underutilization of those resources.  In the worst case, resources get maxed out, more resources are purchased, and the cycle continues, all the while the efficient usage of those resources continues to degrade.  The ability to move fast must be paired with the ability to identify and root out underutilized resources, or waste.

We outline the challenges and organizational forces that contribute to the problem outlined above.  We provide metrics required to measure and trend the efficient utilization of resources, and we outline the capabilities, policies and strategies that allow an organization with thousands of developers to efficiently share cloud resources while allowing for business and developer agility.  We consider the scope of public and private clouds for the use of production and non-production workloads.
schedule.social_description: Capabilities, policies and strategies to help reduce that waste in shared cloud resources.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should come away with an understanding of the challenges that lead to chronic underutilization of cloud resources (waste), have a sense of how to calculate that waste and an understanding of the policies and capabilities an organization should implement in order to maximize the use of the cloud while allowing for business and developer agility.

schedule.title: Practice of integrating OpenStack with existing virtualization and storage in China Mobile
schedule.description:
As a traditional telecommunication company, China Mobile has huge amount of existing virtualization and storage resources. Most of them are VMWare and Citrix virtualization with IPSAN/FCSAN storage.  Beyond the resources, China Mobile has built a universal monitoring and alarm system named BOMC. Now China Mobile is gradually turning into OpenStack platform . We have to  integrate and manage these existing virtualization and storage resources with OpenStack and adapt monitoring data into BOMC.

In this topic, we will share our practice and experience of how we achieved this goal and discuss about what OpenStack needs to improve from our perspective.
schedule.social_description: China Mobile's practice of integrating OpenStack with existing VMWare, Citrix and SAN Storage.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn these aspects from our sharing:

StartFragment EndFragment

  1. How to integrating OpenStack with existing VMWare virtualization, how to import existing networks and virtual machines into OpenStack and how to deal with some special cases such as duplicated VLANs, relevant snapshots, and etc.
  2. Problems and Solutions of Integrating OpenStack with FUJITSU, HP and IBM's SAN devices.  These problems include path failures after live-migration, timeout in concurrent creation, residual device in multipath, and etc.
  3. How to adapt OpenStack 's monitoring system into existing monitoring System such as adapting Ceilometer into China Mobile's BOMC. How to integrating OpenStack with authentication, authorization, accounting and auditing system.
  4. Discuss how to extract common parts of our integration work and contribute them to the OpenStack Community.

schedule.title: Implications of 5G and Edge Computing on OpenStack
schedule.description:
The advent of 5G and required densification have brought about opportunities for virtualization and broader distribution of RAN components - both in access and core networks. The challenges of the vRAN (virtualized RAN), however, are immense and will require a significant collaboration between the key stakeholders within the Cloud and Mobility industry. This presentation will address the following aspects of virtualizing RAN.

  • Options of centralized vs. distributed RAN including a description of how gNB (next generation NodeB) functions will be distributed 
  • Potential candidates for virtualization and containerization of RAN components – both in access and core networks
  • Implications on the network and the SDN choices/selections
  • Integration with OpenStack based cloud management
  • Integration with other ecosystems such as OPNFV, ODL, xRAN, Kubernetes, CNCF, OCI etc.
  • Hybrid cloud options for 5G virtualized components
  • Next steps
schedule.social_description: Implications of 5G and Edge Computing on OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Introduction to the ‘cloudification’ of 5G that would include both access and core network components
    • Densification requirements
    • gNB distributions – centralized vs. distributed
    • Proposed changes in the core network
  • Introduction to distributed deployment and management of OpenStack in small footprints
  • Challenges of deploying virtualized RAN components into a hybrid cloud environment
  • Exploring multi-tenant use of such a deployment for diverse set of workloads (VNF, CDN, AR/VR, IoT etc.)

schedule.title: Project Update - Kuryr
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Kuryr and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Kuryr plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Kuryr PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: OpenStack: A popular destination for Legacy IT
schedule.description:
OpenStack is a destination on the road from legacy IT.  This session will look at OpenStack and the similarities to Legacy IT.   We will explore the potential of OpenStack to optimize Operations, Delivery, Compute, Storage and Network to garnish the benefits of an OpenStack environment.  

Movement to OpenStack does not have to be all or nothing.  We will review security ramifications, preparing your legacy IT today to transform to OpenStack in the future, and key attributes that will make your shift to OpenStack.  

The session will close with examples of OpenStack installations, pulling together the technology discussed to real-world environments.
schedule.social_description: OpenStack: A popular destination for Legacy IT
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn the following :

  1. Birds eye view of Openstack and Openstack Projects.
  2. Difference between Openstack and Legacy IT.
  3. Migration/Transformation  to Openstack.
  4. OpenStack installations.
  5. Real-world environments and examples.

schedule.title: Develop like OpenStack develops - BonnyCI
schedule.description:
OpenStack is one of the largest open source projects in the world. One of the hallmarks of OpenStack is it's strong development infrastructure, which has enabled quality to remain high along side velocity and inclusiveness. A large part of that is built upon the capabilities in the highly scalable development infrastructure OpenStack has organically grown over ther years.

With BonnyCI, we're imagining a world where any project can tap into these capabilities and begin making use of massively parallelized, automated gating CI that includes cross-repository dependencies.

In this talk we'll discuss how OpenStack's CI system evolved to this point, what Zuul is and what it can do for your project, and how we believe BonnyCI will make that easier than ever before. We'll also share how we're using OpenStack and the ways you can contribute to and use BonnyCI today.
schedule.social_description: BonnyCI creates a world where any project can tap into OpenStack-like gating CI
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this talk we'll discuss how OpenStack's CI system evolved to this point, what Zuul is and what it can do for your project, and how we believe BonnyCI will make that easier than ever before. We'll also share how we're using OpenStack and the ways you can contribute to and use BonnyCI today.

schedule.title: Accelerated OpenStack Networking with Contrail vRouter
schedule.description:
The OpenContrail system enables OpenStack to support virtual networks that span across datacenters, using a vRouter software dataplane component. However, running the dataplane purely within the hypervisor can have a significant CPU and memory bandwidth cost.

We describe how a programmable NIC (SmartNIC) can accelerate the dataplane by offloading the routing function and directly delivering traffic into and out of VMs. With the concept of “representative interfaces” and a vendor-neutral offload API, the presence of hardware acceleration can be almost transparent to the orchestration and management layers.

This new approach requires OpenStack to treat VM and hardware interfaces differently from those of traditional NICs. We examine the tradeoffs of various acceleration architectures, and the implications of SmartNICs to OpenStack architecture. The resulting system offers the flexibility of software while improving on the resource usage and performance of traditional hardware.
schedule.social_description: Using SmartNICs to accelerate Contrail vRouter offloading routing and delivering traffic into VMs.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This presentation will describe the approach the accelerated vRouter team took, and issues encountered, in offloading Contrail vRouter to a SmartNIC.  This includes:

  • Hardware acceleration model for OpenStack networking. This model applies to OpenContrail, OVS, or any other vRouter/vSwitch based datacenter
  • The concept of “representative interfaces” will be examined in their use with hardware offload and Contrail vRouter OpenStack integration
  • Novel Contrail vRouter hardware offload API
  • Criteria for choosing Contrail vRouter dataplane functionality to be offloaded to a SmartNIC versus functionality that remains with the host vRouter
  • Performance gains in a SmartNIC accelerated OpenStack deployment
  • Live migration and the SmartNIC

schedule.title: OpenStack Security  - Translating it into Real World  products
schedule.description:
It is no secret that OpenStack is continually adding security features, but it is by no means perfect -- yet.  OpenStack has never really addressed security in a way that translates to a distributed model.  It is one thing to stand up an OpenStack environment in a lab or a data center, very much closed and controlled environments, but it is a very different thing to build a publicly available product that has the security functionality to meet the stringent requirements needed by financial institutions, healthcare organizations, government agencies and telcos.

In this session we will discuss how to best translate OpenStack security to real products in the real world based on Verizon’s experience with building several commercially available OpenStack based products and services.  By drilling down into some ways to address security by using the OpenStack tools, the team was able to create secure environments that met the most stringent requirements of our customers.
schedule.social_description: In the trenches tips on how to apply OpenStack security tools to real products in the real world.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
During this session you will learn how the team addressed thorny security issues such as:

  • The need to perform in a massively distributed (think thousands of global locations) environment.
  • Addressing security in a global environment – limits and opportunities.
  • Needs for Role Based Access Control and a separation of customer and administrative access – corralling the security cats.
  • The need to support customers with sophisticated regulatory and security requirements – think HIPAA, FedRAMP, PCI compliance and others.
  • Different approaches to minimizing the vulnerabilities – how to control the environment without compromising on rapid service delivery.

schedule.title: Introducing Swifta, a performant Hadoop file system driver for OpenStack Swift
schedule.description:
The Hadoop file system driver for Swift is increasingly important as Hadoop ecosystem deployments on OpenStack grow in scale and demand ever-increasing performance. After several months of experience using the OpenStack Sahara-extra file system driver with Hive, Spark, and Presto, we realized that a clean slate redesign would allow us to address threading and data management considerations that significantly impact performance.

We developed a new Swift file system driver, “Swifta”, featuring thread pools, lazy seeks, caching of identical requests, object listing imrovements etc. We tested our implementation against on-premise Ceph object storage, successfully running large queries that otherwise simply failed, and running other queries with substantial performance improvement.

This presentation will discuss the design, implementation, deployment, and performance characteristics of Swifta, which we plan to open source this year, and its use in our cloud-based big data environment.
schedule.social_description: Walmart's Hadoop file system driver for OpenStack Swift
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about our months-long experience using the currently-available Swift driver, our motivations for revisiting the overall architecture rather than continuing to make incremental changes to the existing implementation, and performance characteristics of our implementation.

schedule.title: Collectd and Vitrage integration - an eventful presentation
schedule.description:
The ability to monitor the Network Function Virtualization Infrastructure (NFVI) where VNFs are in operation will be a key part of Service Assurance within an NFV environment. The relevant events and metrics must be reported to higher level fault management systems, to detect violations (and enforce SLAs), as well as faults or degradation in the performance of NFVI resources. If fixed function appliances are going to be replaced by virtualized appliances the service levels, manageability and service assurance needs to remain consistent or improve on what is available today. One specific use case that needs to be supported in NFV deployments is the ability to detect and correct noisy neighbor co-tenants.
This talk will showcase how Intel Resource Director technology can be used in conjunction with Vitrage (the Root Cause Analysis service in OpenStack) to detect and correct a noisy neighbor, as a result of collaboration with the Barometer (NFVI Service Assurance) project in OPNFV.
schedule.social_description: How to detect and address a noisy neighbor usecase using collectd and Vitrage.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This session will look at how to address a noisy neighbor situation. We start by detecting the noisy neighbour in an NFV/OpenStack environment with collectd. Next, notifications of this event are propagated to Vitrage, where the problem and its impact can be visualized and exported. Finally, in response to the event and the analysis relevant actions will be taken to fix these violations on the platform.

Attendees can expect to learn about:

- How to unlock additional platform events/notifications via Collectd and Vitrage.

- How Intel RDT can be used to detect a noisy neighbor using collectd and relay notifications to Vitrage.

- Notification enhancements and insights undertaken by Vitrage to essentially build a service assured NFVI

- Next steps, use cases and how the community is committed to improving OpenStack in this area

schedule.title: Point and Click ->CI/CD: Real world look at better OpenStack deployment, sustainability, upgrades!
schedule.description:
The journey from a static, monolithic, GUI driven OpenStack cloud deployment methodology to a more modular, developer oriented, CI/CD driven deployment methodology can be quite challenging. But the benefits this change in approach brings, which include continuous, agile updates and uninterrupted service upgrades, far outweigh the resources, time, and training to effectively transition from one approach to the other. A CI/CD driven methodology also strategically aligns the deployment mechanisms for the next generation of containerizing the OpenStack control plane!

This session is includes the perspective of the AT&T Entertainment Group, which is using OpenStack at production scale.
schedule.social_description: Moving from Point-and-Click to CI/CD driven deployments of OpenStack brings some terrific benefits!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn:

  • The differences between a "traditional" OpenStack deployment using the Fuel project and the containerized OpenStack cloud methodology
  • When to use the Fuel approach
  • When the containerized approach is more appropriate
  • How companies adapt to changes in resources and training required between the two methods of deployment as one depends on Cobbler and Puppet and the other depends on MaaS and Salt.
  • AEG’s perspective on how the transition from one method to the other has benefitted the company
  • Methods for taking the modular services approach to the next level

schedule.title: How to utilize OpenStack Swift as an S3 storage target
schedule.description:
The OpenStack Swift project provides an excellent AWS S3 compatibility layer which is used privately on-premises and by service providers to provide S3 compatibility for their applications and users.


In this talk, we will demonstrate how to configure and use the S3 middleware with SwiftStack. We will discuss how the architecture to provide S3 compatibility scales. Come hear how to set up cloud storage that is compatible with AWS S3!
schedule.social_description: Come see how to setup an S3-compatible storage cluster with OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn about the S3 copatibility that the Swift3 project provides, what's supported, and what's not (yet) supported.

schedule.title: Facing The Public - What’s Still Missing from OpenStack for Public Cloud Operators?
schedule.description:
As OpenStack has matured, it’s emerged as the weapon of choice for private clouds. Now, in our seventh year as a community, how can we close the gap on missing public cloud features?

Enter Tobias (CityNetwork, Sweden) and Sean (Datacentred, UK), two developers from Europe both working independently at different OpenStack cloud providers. After chatting in Barcelona both realised that they’d essentially been writing the same private code to “plug the gaps” in the OpenStack toolkit in order to make it operable for a public cloud business.

In this talk, they announce the formation of the new Public Cloud Working Group and they share their combined journeys in the hope that we can, as a community, figure out how to make OpenStack the best public cloud toolkit that it can be.
schedule.social_description: In our seventh year as a community, how can we close the gap on missing public cloud features?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• What public cloud providers need from their OpenStack deployments to effectively run a profitable business.
  • Where OpenStack currently falls short for public cloud providers.
  • How we can move towards improvement.

schedule.title: Architecture and Optimization on 3000 Nodes Baremetal Cloud in China Mobile
schedule.description:
As the leading mobile services provider in Mainland China, China Mobile Limited and its subsidiaries manage the world’s largest mobile network and the world’s largest mobile customer base.

China Mobile selected a software stack of all open source components. Use OpenStack as cloud solution, has deployed several 1000 nodes cloud clusters powered by OpenStack.

One of the cloud including 3000 nodes is providing baremetal service, which will be used to run workload like Hadoop cluster, operation analysis system, bussiness support system, orcale Database etc.

In this topic, we will reveal the Architecture of this OpenStack baremetal cloud in China Mobile, how to design and deploy the 3000 nodes baremetal cloud powered by OpenStack and Ironic component.

where is the bottleneck of baremetal system from our testing?

what's the gap between community project with large scale deployment?
schedule.social_description: Reveal the Architecture of the 3000 nodes baremetal cloud powered by OpenStack and Ironic in CMCC.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. How we design and deploy the 3000 nodes baremetal cloud powered by OpenStack and Ironic component.
2. The gap between Ironic community project with large scale deployment. In the actual deployment and use of ironic to build a private baremetal cloud, which functions need to be enhanced, how to increase?
3. How many controller nodes are required for 3K ironic baremetal cluster? what kind of services do the controller nodes should deploy. F.g. How many TFTP servers should deploy, How many nova-compute should deploy?
4. The network solution of this baremetal cloud.
5. The analysis of time consuming and success rate in baremetal provisioning. 
6. The optimization result for our testing.

schedule.title: Project Update - Magnum
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Magnum and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Magnum plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

 

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Magnum PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Introduction to OpenStack Load Balancing
schedule.description:
This will be an introductory level session covering Octavia and load balancing in OpenStack.  We will cover load balancing use cases, the OpenStack load balancing model, load balancing providers (drivers), the API, CLI, and horizon dashboard.  The session will start with basic load balancing concepts and work our way up to advanced topics such as TLS offloading and layer 7 load balancing.

Attendees will come away with the ability to use the network load balancing capabilities in OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: Introduction to network load balancing in OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This is an introduction to network load balancing in OpenStack.  Attendees will come away with a basic understanding of how to use load balancers in OpenStack.

Topics will cover:

What is network load balancing?

What are some use cases for using load balancing?

The OpenStack load balancing model:

          Load balancers

          Listeners

          Pools

          Health Monitors

          Members

Load balancing providers (drivers).

The load balancing Application Programming Interface (API).

The load balancing Command Line Interface (CLI).

The horizon dashboard for load balancing.

Session persistence.

TLS offloading.

Layer 7 load balancing.

schedule.title: Tapping into the Strengths of the Hybrid Cloud
schedule.description:
As companies embarked on their cloud journeys, many shifted their infrastructures to the cloud and eliminated all on premise hardware. As applications shifted in the cloud it opened a different set of challenges and concerns for CIO/CTO’s — things like performance, security, data protection, and availability.The hybrid cloud gives CIO’s/CTO’s the ability to take a balanced approach, placing core applications on premise, with the remaining datasets to reside in a public or private entity- and reaping the benefits that come from both approaches. In this session, Murali Balcha, co-founder and CTO of Trilio Data will explore:

  • When it makes sense for a business to consider a hybrid approach
  • The many use cases for the hybrid cloud, including storage capacity, archiving, and  best use of resource consumption
  • How to effectively get started with hybrid clouds-- and how to set your business up for success long term
  • The tools and technologies available to aid in a hybrid cloud journey
schedule.social_description: Learn to tap strengths of the hybrid cloud with insights from Murali Balcha, CTO @Triliodata
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• When it makes sense for a business to consider a hybrid approach
  • The many use cases for the hybrid cloud, including storage capacity, archiving, and  best use of resource consumption
  • How to effectively get started with hybrid clouds for your business-- and how to set your business up for success long term
  • The tools and technologies available to aid in a business hybrid cloud journey

schedule.title: Easier OpenStack Deployment: Novice Installation Using Kolla
schedule.description: A key factor in increasing the adoption of OpenStack is offering a straight forward and time efficient deployment process. The Operations Team in the OpenStack Innovation Center recognise that the demand for ease-of-use is ever increasing with customers pushing to increase functionality and decrease complexity. In our previous efforts we demonstrated how we took the OpenStack deployment time from 40 hours to just over 6 hours. Once again, we accepted the challenge of showing OpenStack is easy to install and using Kolla, achieved deploying OpenStack within 1 hour. We validated Openstack using Kolla on a 100 node cluster and recorded common issues faced by Operators deploying OpenStack. With this information, we created an Ease of Use guide that allows Operators with no prior experience in Openstack to deploy multinode OpenStack. In this session, we will provide participants the opportunity to utilize our guide and complete a full production grade deployment of OpenStack using Kolla.
schedule.social_description: An easier and time efficient way to deploy production grade OpenStack using Kolla.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn to utilize the ease-of-use install guide to deploy OpenStack using Kolla and  different ways to tackle some common issues that may be encountered in any deployment scenario.

schedule.title: Barbican Workshop - Securing the Cloud
schedule.description:
**Back by Popular demand, It was the most popular workshop at the Barcelona OpenStack Summit.**

Security is at, or near, the top of everyone's list of "stuff that's important," yet the management of security artifacts (such as keys and certificates) has been lacking a cohesive solution.  This is where Barbican comes into the picture.  Barbican provides secure storage and provisioning of secrets, including keys and certificates. 

This workshop provides a tour through the magical world of Barbican, led by core members of the Barbican project.

By the end of the class you will know:

  1. Importance of secret storage
  2. How to store and retrieve secrets with Barbican
  3. How to submit an order with Barbican
  4. How to create a container
  5. How to use quotas
  6. Uses for additional user metadata
  7. Dogtag Certificate System Integration
  8. Barbican Dev-Ops Architecture
  9. Use cases for Barbican / Examples
  10. Castellan (Generic Key Management Interface) Use Cases
  11. Barbican's Roadmap
schedule.social_description: Barbican Workshop - Securing the Cloud. Everything you need to know about Barbican!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees of all skill levels can attend, from Beginner to Expert.

 By the end of the class an atendee will know:

  1. Importance of secret storage
  2. How to store and retrieve secrets with Barbican
  3. How to submit an order with Barbican
  4. How to create a container
  5. How to use quotas
  6. Uses for additional user metadata
  7. Dogtag Certificate System Integration
  8. Barbican Dev-Ops Architecture
  9. Use cases for Barbican / Examples
  10. Castellan (Generic Key Management Interface) Use Cases
  11. Barbican's Roadmap

Attendees are not expected to have any previous experience with Barbican.  A basic understanding of security components (such as keys and certificates) and a basic understanding of REST is helpful, but not required.

schedule.title: Public Cloud dilemmas: stay close to the upstream code
schedule.description:
As a public cloud provider, every day we face challenges in the pursuit of happiness of our customers.
Choosing OpenStack as a base for our public cloud brings many advantages but may also be tricky.
We want to share our journey, how we found a balance between keeping up with upstream, and meet our clients' expectations.

On the first hand, fixing bugs and quickly developing new features for our infrastructure is very important for our Public Cloud offering. On the other hand, being in touch with upstream is a must-have. It's very easy to lose the balance.
How to handle a development stream and production with limited time and day to day constraints?
How to be present in the community while maintaining a large scale infrastructure all over the world?
schedule.social_description: How we found a balance between keeping up with upstream and meet our clients' expectations.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How to keep balance between keeping up with upstream and meet our clients' expectations as a Public Cloud providers.

You will discover what are the challenges a public cloud operator faces. Based on those facts, you will learn what you shouldn’t do to avoid losing your time in a wrong direction.
Instead we will share a simple and smart strategy to stay close to the upstream repositories. This will help you push your code upstream easily.

schedule.title: Bridging the gap between deploying OpenStack as a cloud application and as a traditional application
schedule.description:
