OpenStack is often deployed using a traditional application approach. However, it's possible to treat OpenStack as a native cloud application. TripleO is a project aimed at exactly that: using one OpenStack cloud to deploy and manage another.

Applications designed for the cloud often share some common properties: microservices architecture, elasticity, multi-tenancy, and scalability. Traditional data center applications also have their own set of requirements: physical storage, heterogeneous hardware, and existing management tools. These two sets of requirements often contrast with one other.

In this talk, we'll discuss how TripleO balances these approaches and bridges the gap between these two methods. We'll discuss how the TripleO feature set meets the needs of deploying OpenStack as both a cloud and traditional
application. We'll cover how TripleO uses Heat, Ironic, and Neutron, and we’ll highlight some of the recent additions to OpenStack that could be integrated into TripleO.
schedule.social_description: Bridging the gap between deploying OpenStack as a cloud application and as a traditional application
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees can expect to learn how TripleO deploys OpenStack as a native cloud application, and how that approach is balanced with traditional datacenter operational needs.

Advanced usage of OpenStack projects, primarily Heat and Ironic will be demonstrated in showing how TripleO works. Advanced features in TripleO itself will also be shown. These features would include using predictable baremetal
configurations, static IP addresses, network interface configurations, physical storage configurations, template composability,  and integration with existing provisioning systems.

Attendees will also learn about:
- How TripleO takes a microservices approach to deploying OpenStack
- Orchestrating those microservices across clusters
- Taking advantage of hybrid infrastructure (virtual infrastructure, public/private cloud, baremetal) for OpenStack deployment and development
- How Tripleo can abstract it's deployment model so it can be used to deploy OpenStack anywhere

schedule.title: Deploy It Like You Mean It: Committing to Continuous Delivery with Jenkins Pipeline in OpenStack
schedule.description:
Here’s where you’re at: You’ve got a pretty good automated software delivery system in place, but wonder if it could be improved. Maybe you’ve even heard of Jenkins Pipeline already, but don’t know if it’s right for you.

Why I’m here: I want to share the joys and pains of transforming our standard deployment methods into beautiful, efficient pipelines. After spending too long being complacent with existing and lacking deployment automation, we’ve finally taken the steps to change for the better.

Focus Areas:

  • Benefits: Efficiency, decreased deployment time, versatility.
  • Obstacles: Converting code, time investment, plugins & version upgrades.
  • Conversion: Steps for making the change from an existing code base.
  • Advice: Best practices and things to watch out for.
schedule.social_description: Deploy It Like You Mean It: Committing to Continuous Delivery with Jenkins Pipeline in OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn how Jenkins Pipeline could transform your continuous delivery system. In this session, we'll identify use cases and key steps to implement conversion. Attendees will take away the benefits of Jenkins Pipeline as well as stories of obstacles encountered first-hand.

schedule.title: A monitoring case study for Monasca: Smart City infrastructure
schedule.description:
Objects, that populate smart cities, are able to send real-time information. Users need to understand objects data in order to handle the city’s assets. This case study presents the city of Messina, Italy, where smart devices map environmental phenomena.

The University of Messina developed a framework for IoT, Stack4Things, to collect information from the devices. Stack4Things collects data in real-time. Using network virtualization, the framework provides IaaS-like services from a pool of IoT devices.

Monasca, the OpenStack Monitoring Service, analyses and presents the measured data. Monasca supervises the healthiness of the IoT nodes too.

Stack4Things and Monasca together help to collect, analyse and present the information to users who can decide the best course of action to improve the environment of the city.
schedule.social_description: OpenStack and IoT: Stack4Things and Monasca collect, analyse and present information to users.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn:

  • The integration of IoT and OpenStack Cloud
  • How the city of Messina uses the device information and how operators can access it from the management interface
  • The business case that Messina wants to solve and the impact of saving money using advanced technology
  • How to use the most suitable configuration for IoT and OpenStack
  • The best practices to get real-time data and to react fast to device information

schedule.title: OpenStack Instance Availability - Trying to keep your pets happy
schedule.description: For those that are looking at OpenStackd deployments - High Availability has often been a concept overlooked. The basis of Cloud Native Apps are that they are stateless and can easily be replicated. But, with the advancement of Openstack - many companies are placing their primary Business Applications within the Private or Hybrid Cloud. Other areas of Openstack have HA now, for example the Control Plane of OpenStack with HA proxy and clustering. Yet, we sometimes overlook some of the options available of Copute nodes and Instances. This session will provide an overview of a few of those options; and provide some insight into each. The session is not meant to be one to dive deep into the options available for the HA of coompute nodes and Instances. But to introduce those new to OpenStack with options that they can consider based on their use case(s).
schedule.social_description: Ideas for keeping the OpenStack Pets available
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. Options to provide for OpenStack instance availability

2. Different components of the availability for Instance availability

schedule.title: Operational lessons from running Openstack and Ceph for cancer research at scale
schedule.description:
In 2014, Ontario Institute for Cancer Research in Toronto, Canada began the Cancer Genome Collaboratory, an OpenStack environment designed to scale to 3000 cores and 15 PB object storage.

In this talk we will discuss the various design goals and trade-offs considered in order to arrive at the hardware choices. We will show how a team of two people manage it, going through day-to-day operations, security updates, Openstack and Ceph upgrades.

We will cover how the design choices affected the deployment, operational and monitoring tools as well as lessons learnt and things we want to do different in the future.
schedule.social_description: Large scale Openstack and Ceph deployment used to find life saving answers in cancer research.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
What hardware we use, the networking design, what monitoring tools we use and how we do maintenances.

How we upgraded Openstack from Juno up to Mitaka, and Ceph from Giant up to Jewel.

How we grow the environment, and how we load test it.

schedule.title: Swift – Bigger than big
schedule.description: OpenStack Swift has always been about “big”. Petabytes of data, thousands of requests per second, and clusters with hundreds of nodes are just a normal Tuesday for Swift clusters. But when Swift was first released seven years ago, 4TB drives were big and 24-bay storage nodes were dense. These days, you can buy 10TB drives and put 80 of them in one server. Continent-spanning clusters are normal, and workloads with billions of objects are expected. This massive increase in scale brings new challenges for any storage system, and the Swift community has risen to the task. Come hear about improvements made in Swift to support the biggest storage hardware available today and how we’re continually improving the system to tackle the challenges ahead.
schedule.social_description: Have large data? Come learn how Swift is scaling to support huge data workloads.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the latest capabilities for OpenStack Swift to scale to not only large capacities, but large dense storage nodes.

schedule.title: Future of Containers in OpenStack
schedule.description:
OpenStack is a mature project widely adopted by organizations. After enough buzz and momentum, Containers have also matured.

Both Containers and OpenStack have got their place in production. OpenStack community has always taken keen interest in supporting Containers within OpenStack.

OpenStack has tried multiple ways to add support for Containers but none has proved to be solving the issue so far. So Zun is new project trying to bridge the gap between Containers and OpenStack by making Container available as a first class resource in OpenStack. Zun aims to closely integrate with both container tools and container orchestration engines(COE).

This talk will try to explain how Zun is trying to support containers the same way as VM and baremetals are supported today in OpenStack and will also explain the Zun’s focus and roadmap.
schedule.social_description: This talk explains the future of containers in OpenStack with new project, Zun.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• The state of containers in OpenStack at present.
  • Discuss about the container related projects available in OpenStack today in brief.
  • Making containers as first class resource as VM and Baremetal supported by Nova and Ironic respectively.
  • Integration with various other OpenStack projects like Keystone, Glance, Cinder, Nova, Kuryr.
  • Provide the best of both Container and OpenStack world.

schedule.title: What do you mean start with unit tests? (Newbies’ guide to contributing to OpenStack)
schedule.description:
With the upcoming boom in web and software programmers, there is an ever increasing potential for contributors. But how can a newer or weaker developer from different backgrounds get up to speed?

Many developers start with libraries and frameworks well supported with tutorials and demos. OpenStack, however, is a full blown infrastructure - a very different beast. There are plenty of operator level tutorials easily accessible, but developer contribution guides or tutorials are often limited. This may scare away developers that are used to such an ecosystem resulting in opportunities foregone.

To tackle these problems for people starting out, we will be discussing interactive ways to explore OpenStack using the Python Debugger and testr. We will be covering some ideas on understanding the inner workings of the various APIs in OpenStack using Pdb, and discuss how to utilize Tempest to both expand your knowledge and give back to the tool you love (which tool? OpenStack, duh).
schedule.social_description: Love OpenStack and dying to contribute, but aren’t a wiz? Try the Tempest approach - debug and test
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
If you join us for a light hearted and insightful presentation we can promise to give you an alternative to torturing yourself with the OpenStack code-base. We were recently faced with the same problems you are most likely facing right now. We had the same general thought: I have web/software development experience and interact with this mysterious cloud infrastructure people call OpenStack, but I have no idea where to start.

We know that the docs and database are full of spaghetti diagrams and that even the simplest of the “low hanging fruits” seem complex and convoluted. We have been there, digging through the code base only to get lost in the woods.

We found a way to bite off manageable bits and want to share it with you. Even if you have no interest in testing, or debugging – we guarantee that with just a couple of days you will have a base understanding from which to proceed in any direction. Important highlights include APIs, layout, and function.

schedule.title: The Cost of Maintaining Your Image
schedule.description: This is not a talk about cosmetics, but images are at the core of every cloud.  While your image may be pretty on day one, how do you maintain patching, the security configuration and the set of packages that will satisfy a set of multiple teams running OpenStack workloads in multiple sites? This presentation will cover IBM’s experience at deploying at scale an image management practice that manages a series of Operating Systems distribution, satisfying the specific requirements of product teams and ensure that you do it in a cost effective manner.  We will cover how IBM leveraged DevOps tools & concepts to automate the maintenance and distribution of images.
schedule.social_description: Automated Image Management for OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn how technologies like Jenkins, Packer and Ansible can be used to produce consistent OpenStack Glance image in order to deliver a consistent set of healthy images

schedule.title: Real Time KVM and How it Works
schedule.description:
With the majority of network functions running on OpenStack today, why do we not see more and more radio access network solutions in the space.  Real time is one of the main reasons and with RT-KVM we are addressing the need for synchronous communications and other features which rely on guaranteed delay below 10us.

In this session we will show how it's deployed with both hardware and software features as well as example workloads.

There are also some cases where RT-KVM should not be used and this will be covered as well.
schedule.social_description: Realtime KVM via OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendee will leave this session with an understand how to deploy openstack with RT-KVM and the use case or example workload which uses it today.

schedule.title: Project Update - Manila
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Manila and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Manila plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Manila PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Cloud wars! Public vs Private cloud economics.
schedule.description:
Public or private, which is cheaper? A ever-present, hotly-debated topic but one that often lacks substantive data. In this session we'll leave the politics aside and focus on the facts!

A major data processing company was recently trying to determine what cloud model would meet their needs most cost effectively: public cloud, or private hosted OpenStack. After much searching, they discovered that there really isn't much data available on the topic. They asked us to look at their workload and make a recommendation.

What we found surprised us. In this sure-to-be provocative session, we'll dive into the following topics:

  • Unit cost economics
  • Reservations: paying for capacity vs paying for performance
  • Urban sprawl / orphans
  • The "feature black hole"
  • Financial modeling

We'll present our findings - which will surely prompt a healthy debate with session attendees!
schedule.social_description: Cloud wars! Public vs Private cloud economics. Which is cheaper/better/faster?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Unit Cost Economics:

  • Capacity reservation versus performance
  • Hardware utilization
  • Thin provisioning
  • The law of large numbers

Urban Sprawl

Feature Dependency

  • AKA the black hole
  • AKA cloud vendor lock-in
  • AKA getting stuff done faster!

Financial Modeling

Other Factors

schedule.description: Back by popular demand, the official OpenStack Summit Community Party will celebrate what locals love the most, the Boston Red Sox. Fenway Park is a place where dreams are made, traditions are celebrated and baseball is forever. Join us for an evening at the oldest ballpark in the MLB filled with nostalgia, game day activities, food, live music, and much more. The Fenway buyout offers attendees a unique one of-a-kind opportunity to experience the historic ballpark like never before. RSVP coming soon!
schedule.social_description: The official OpenStack Summit Community Party at Fenway Park.

schedule.description: It's Wednesday. Come get your swag and your badge and get to  your session.
schedule.social_description: Come get your swag and your badge and get to  your session. Don't miss the keynote!!!

schedule.title: The Vitrage Story: from Nothing to the Big Tent
schedule.description:
The story of how Nokia took Vitrage from concept to the Big Tent in just six months.

A year and a half ago, a few Nokia developers realized that Root Cause Analysis (RCA) was lacking in OpenStack. They put together the basic code for what is now known as Vitrage – an RCA and Deduced Alarms service that supplies insights about OpenStack through open APIs to practically any service imaginable, and connects the physical, virtual and application layers.

Vitrage was first introduced as an idea at the Tokyo summit – we came with diagrams, our collective experience and a lot of passion, and got the blessing of key people in OpenStack.

This is a story of going from a concept, to a working code, to a community, to becoming an official part of OpenStack – and all this in record time. We will describe the steps we took along the way, the decision points, the failures and successes that led us along this route. This is a story for anyone dreaming about the Big Tent.
schedule.social_description: The story of how Nokia took Vitrage from concept to the Big Tent in just six months.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees can learn how an idea can become a reality. 

We will describe the steps we took along the way in order to shorten the time to our acceptance into the Bit Tent to a minimum. We will advise on the important things to notice in the beginning of the process, to make the journey as smooth as possible, and how you can work within OpenStack, by its guidelines, in order to achieve your goal.

schedule.title: Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence for Smart City Networks
schedule.description:
Automated networks are essential for smart cities. A key enabler is the use of AI techniques and ML to drive network automation. AI and ML have seen a resurgence in investment with renewed promise because of 2 changes in recent years: availability of many more data points, and deployment of specialized silicon providing highly parallel computation increasing processing capacity for data processing making AI and ML technology less “brittle”. Expectation is ML can be utilized to train AI systems to recognize patterns in vast amounts of real time network telemetry data, providing early recognition of developing network performance issues, before they negatively impact human experience. Then policy driven AI systems can take automatic action to change the course of events, avoiding impacting user outages. This panel ML and AI explores architectures and techniques needed to automate smart city networks.

Juniper – Sumeet Singh AppFormix CEO

Intel – Bob Ghaffari, Director

Nokia - TDB
schedule.social_description: How ML and AI enable high performance networks for smart cities.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Panel will discuss current advances in machine learning (ML) and atrificial  (AI) techniques, the requirements of smart city networks, and how ML and AI can be applied to build large scale and high performance networks for smart cities where network intrastructure will carry large volumes of IoT traffic and be shared.

schedule.title: AI with applications to manage them self by machine learning
schedule.description: While the Applications run seamlessly on openstack but they dont have capability to learn how they can survive the critical failure and what action need to be taken to make the service available all time. Adding AI to the cloud can help the applications to decide what to do at what time for example if the heavy workload comes up whether to spawnup another instance and make HA with the other to handel the load and if the system is giving warning migrate to the other system and keep the service available and sense the action by reducing the load to the operators
schedule.social_description: while the applications run seamlessly on openstack the AI can help the applications to decide
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
What is AI

Applications can learn the action to be taken and can decide

How to implement that with openstack

schedule.title: Kolla-Kubernetes: Day 2 operations enable sleep optimization!
schedule.description:
OpenStack is in many cases difficult to deploy, scale, manage and maintain. Kolla-Kubernetes is a community driven deliverable of the OpenStack Kolla project that delivers complete lifecycle management, often referred to as day-2 operations, of OpenStack services running on a Kubernetes underlay.


Complex tasks and deployment patterns including high availability, dynamic reconfiguration, recovery from node failure, and service migration can be performed in a production environment with confidence. In this presentation, we provide an overview of Kolla-Kubernetes and provide a demonstration of reconfiguration, upgrade, and permanently stopping a Kubernetes compute node with control node service migration. 

By demonstrating the flexibility and resilience of Kolla-Kubernetes, quality of sleep for Operators planning or deploying OpenStack on Kubernetes is vastly improved.
schedule.social_description: Kolla-Kubernetes presents a focus on day 2 operations of OpenStack using CNCF native tools.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How Kubernetes makes OpenStack operations easier
  • How Kolla-kubernetes enables day 2 operations of an OpenStack cluster.
  • An example of managing a complex stateful applcation in kubernetes
  • Current approach for bridging the CNCF community and the OpenStack community
  • Challenges experienced with managing OpenStack with Kubernetes
  • Operating Kolla-Kubernetes on a 20 node cluster.
  • Delivering high availability service architecture, for the entire stack that composes OpenStack.
  • How Kolla-Kubernetes can easily scale up or down compute, storage, and networking services using Kubernetes.
  • What does kubernetes offer openstack?

schedule.title: Build Bare Metal Kubernetes Cluster for HPC on OpenStack in Translational Medicine Research at SJTU
schedule.description:
With the medicine technology advances, it is possible to create a patient profile by a full genomic data along with vast amount of patient data from personal fitness devices, medical record, etc. Translational medicine is aim at moving faster from research to patient care by integrating the data across traditional silos which requires a cloud to support multi-tenancy, self-service, big data analysis and HPC workload. OpenStack are good at virtual machine management, while we use VM to serve as a container host which brings virtualization overhead in overlay networking, I/O operations, etc. and it won’t get benefit from some advanced features. In this session, we'll share:

  • How to build an OpenStack cloud for HPC with multi-tenancy and self-services;
  • How to build a bare metal kubernetes cluster with OpenStack Magnum and Ironic;
  • The issues we are facing and how we overcome them;
  • The gaps remaining and what does the community need to improve in the future;
  • More thinking and new ideas.
schedule.social_description: Build Bare Metal Kubernetes Cluster for HPC on OpenStack in Translational Medicine Research at SJTU
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How does OpenStack resolve the issues of HPC in Translational Medicine Research.
  • How to do a 1-key bare metal container cluster provision on OpenStack with Magnum and Ironic projects.
  • Some new thinking and improvements with current container management on OpenStack.

schedule.title: Compliance and Integration Testing in China Mobile Using Dovetail
schedule.description: This speech intends to share some of the integration experience and challenges from China Mobile in our field deployment of NFV, and the compliance verification trail we have done with the Dovetail team in OPNFV. The Dovetail project intends to provide automated tools to validate the compliance of a commercial System Under Test (SUT) with certain expectation in behavior and open source interfaces conforming to the reference platform, which could be one of the releases of OPNFV. Such compliance testing helps Operators detect interface conflict in multiple commercial products, and can largely reduce the integration matches.
schedule.social_description: Compliance and Integration Testing in China Mobile Using Dovetail
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This speech intended to share some of the integration experience and challenges from China Mobile in our field deployment of NFV, and the compliance verification trail we have done with the Dovetail team in OPNFV. The Dovetail project intends to provide automated tools to validate the compliance of a commercial System Under Test (SUT) with certain expectation in behavior and open source interfaces conforming to the reference platform, which could be one of the releases of OPNFV. Such compliance testing helps Operators detect interface conflict in multiple commercial products, and can largely reduce the integration matches.

schedule.title: No code, no problem: tales of getting involved with the OpenStack community
schedule.description:
OpenStack is a technology that comes with a vibrant and active community. Even without a strong technical background, you can become involved and contribute. 

The talk will cover: 

- Personal stories from OpenStack community members on their journey in becoming involved:
         - These are from individuals who have been involved with overseeing user groups, the ambassador program and contributing to media and publications
        - As a result of these contributions, highlighting the positive impact

- Unpacking the community structure, demonstrating all the possible points in the OpenStack ecosystem where others with a non technical background can enter and join the community

- Finally, a summary with encouragment of non technical members to join and contribute!
schedule.social_description: Hear personal stories of first time involvement in the community, even without coding expertise
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees should expect to learn from my and others experiences in being involved in the OpenStack community, without a strong coding/technical background. This proving the OpenStack space is truly open for all, whether it comes from a management perspective (ie Facilitating user groups) or Advocacy perspective (Ambassador program or media contributions) and so on. 

Attendees should also walk away feeling excited and empowered to grow their communities even more, encouraging more individuals to join and contribute, whether they come from a technical background or not.

schedule.title: Serverless on OpenStack with Docker Swarm, Mistral, and StackStorm
schedule.description:
It’s just a matter of [short] time when your users will demain Serverless from your OpenStack Oh,do they, already? Indeed, “Serverless computing” can be a good fit for variety of tasks and workloads. Where it fits, it offers a better consumption/usage model for developers and higher resource utilization for cloud operations.

In this talk we show how to build a DIY serverless solution that matches and goes beyond AWS Lambda or OpenWhisk, on your OpenStack cloud. Learn how to do it with readily available open source tools and OpenStack components. The resulting serverless solution  not only executes “Lambda-like” short-burst functions, but runs complex, long running, multi-step workloads, like genomic computation pipelines or big-data map-reduce jobs.


Learn the solution’s architecture, see a demo(!), and dive into the implementation all the way to the code. Gain a practical understanding of “serverless”, and take home a DYI recipe to build serverless into your OpenStack cloud.
schedule.social_description: Go Serverless on your OpenStack Cloud. DYI recipe with Docker Swarm.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: You will gain a practical understanding of “serverless”, and learn a DYI recipe to build Serverless into your OpenStack cloud.

schedule.title: Integrating Ceilometer with the existing monitoring solution using Zabbix
schedule.description:
We believe that somehow we can make use of this product in a production environment, but, that depends what metrics are more important for the Organization. The project is called ZCP,ZCP's main features is summarized as follows:
* Automatically gather information about the existing Cloud Infrastructure being considered (tenants, instances);
* Seamlessly handle changes in the Cloud Infrastructure (creation and deletion of tenants and/or instances);
* Periodically retrieve resources/meters details from ceilometer and get that collected data directly into Zabbix.
Benefits for customers or cloud users:
* Zabbix mainly monitors the metric of OpenStack physical nodes, and Ceilometer is for the OpenStakc internal usage.ZCP maybe a way to allow to have one common monitoring system (Zabbix) for several OpenStack-based Cloud Data Centres.
schedule.social_description: Integrating Ceilometer with the existing monitoring solution using Zabbix
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The main objective for the creation of a Zabbix-Ceilometer Proxy is the integration between Ceilometer and Zabbix. With ZCP it is possible to monitor different services and instances that run on the OpenStack infrastructure and get that collected data directly into Zabbix.

How Zabbix distinguishes a tenant from an instance:
- A tenant is a host-group in Zabbix;
- A host is an instance in Zabbix

ZCP's main features:
- Creates/deletes new host-group when a tenant is created/deleted;
- Creates/deletes a new host when an instance is created/deleted;
- Sends the metrics collected by Ceilometer directly to a Zabbix Server.

schedule.title: Project Update - Mistral
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Mistral and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Mistral plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Mistral PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Diving in the desert.  An in depth session into configuring and using OpenStack Sahara.
schedule.description:
Big data analytics is a hot topic for most organizations today as they race to convert vast amounts of data into useful information that can be leveraged to make critical decisions or recommendations in a very limited time window.

Today, there is a widely accepted talent gap when it comes to creating and managing Hadoop clusters, even for the experts - it can take hours (or days) to get a fully functional Hadoop farm up and running.

On top of that, it can be difficult to find entry-level programmers who have sufficient Java skills to be productive with MapReduce.  

OpenStack Sahara is looking to address most of this challenges by facilitating the deployment of hadoop clusters based on several distributions and provide a set of APIs to facilitate data processing tasks. 

In this OpenStack academy session, the participants will run through the procedure to deploy a fully functional Hadoop cluster from scratch while learning how to perform simple Map and Reduce tasks and navigate HDFS.
schedule.social_description: Deploying a functional Hadoop cluster in OpenStack while learning how to perform Map Reduce jobs.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees will walk out of this session with a fully functional OpenStack Sahara enabled cloud in their notebooks.

They will learn how to deploy two different sets of Hadoop clusters based on Vanilla and MapR plugins from scratch.

Once the hadoop cluster is up and running, the participants will learn how to:

1) Navigate Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS)

2) Create Map and Reduce workloads.

3) Leverage on Hive and Pig as a higher level of abstraction to run your jobs.  (Time permitting)

schedule.title: Marketplace is Open
schedule.description: Marketplace is Open
schedule.social_description: Marketplace is Open

schedule.title: Magic wand behind large OpenStack and Virtual network functions (VNF) orchestration - OpenECOMP
schedule.description:
ECOMP (Enhanced Control, Orchestration, and Management & Policy) is the magic wand behind virtual network functions (VNF) Orchestration within AT&T on top of the largest distributed OpenStack cloud in the world (100+ locations) a.k.a AT&T Integrated Cloud (AIC). AT&T Opensourced ECOMP as OpenECOMP.

The combination of OpenStack and OpenECOMP is a powerful platform to deploy and manage large scale deployment of VNFs in large numbers across a global footprint of datacenters.

The OpenECOMP software platform delivers product/service independent capabilities for the design, creation and lifecycle management of the VNF. 

OpenECOMP consists of several modules used to interact with OpenStack and the VNFs. 

This talk will illustrate all the insight of OpenECOMP’s use in managing a large number of geographically diverse OpenStack instances.
schedule.social_description: Magic wand behind large Virtual network functions (VNF) orchestration above OpenStack- OpenECOMP
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will gain an insight into OpenECOMP and its interactions with OpenStack data centers to successfully support large scale VNF deployments.

Attendees will also will learn how to run OpenECOMP and OpenStack in support of large scale Telco grade cloud.

Demo of OpenECOMP and its interaction to OpenStack.

schedule.title: Managing python source installations using lessons learned by OpenStack's CI systems
schedule.description:
One of Python's greatest strengths is the large and diverse set of existing code bases that you can build on to accomplish your goals. Unfortunately, as projects grow, managing your dependencies can become a constant headache.

Unwinding which transitive dependency update now conflicts with other dependencies or is simply broken then somehow preventing that version of the dependency from being used is a common issue that needs to be addressed. Other issues include ensuring the correct system packages are installed so that Python packages can be built and link against system libs properly. Consistently reproducing an installation across more that one machine is surprisingly difficult. The list goes on and on.

As part of running a continuous integration system that installs Python packages tens of thousands of times per day the OpenStack project has learned how to deal with many of these issues. I will talk about these tools and the problems they solve.
schedule.social_description: Managing python source installations using lessons learned by OpenStack's CI systems.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The two target audiences for this talk are developers responsible for packaging their Python projects and the individuals installing/deploying Python packages.

Developers doing packaging for their projects should learn how they can make life easier for both themselves and their users by avoiding common issues with existing tools and providing necessary information for others to successfully install their software. Operators deploying Python packages should learn that they are not alone struggling with the consumption of Python software and that there are decent workarounds for many of the problems that they face. Hopefully this helps make Python packaging a little better for everyone using it.

schedule.title: Maximizing Hardware: Server Simulator
schedule.description: Scalability is one key feature that drives OpenStack adoption around the globe. With the dispatch of OpenStack's 14th release dubbed Newton, OpenStack makers affirm that it now incorporates enhanced scaling abilities. The Operations team at the OpenStack Innovation Center decided to demonstrate that OpenStack is effortlessly scalable to 500 nodes in a single region. To complete this task, we decided to work on a tool that allows them to target a set number of servers and "partition" them; if you have 10 physical servers, split those into 100 virtual servers, and use them as compute nodes within an OpenStack deployment. In this session we will examine the simulator tool, deep dive into its internals, and run through a demo. You will learn how you might utilize it to test the scaling of various OpenStack services and decrease the cost of creating labs and staging environments within your company.
schedule.social_description: Test OpenStack services/features at scale with minimal bare-metal nodes
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: how to use the Simulator tool to test scalability of OpenStack services, create labs and stage environments

schedule.title: Performance testing OpenStack networking with DPDK and RT
schedule.description:
With Network Function Virtualization (NFV), many traditional network elements that have requires real time guarantees will run on OpenStack clouds. To guarantee that they continue to meet the strict telco requirements, we must keep measuring the performance of the cloud platform . This also allows to compare the suitability of different OpenStack variants for real-time use.

The key metric in NFV is network latency and especially the worst case network latency, together with good throughput with low drop rates. This presentation explains the measurements that we have conducted on OpenStack platforms.
schedule.social_description: How to test OpenStack platforms for network performance and latencies
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will gain knowledge of what performance metrics are most relevant for telco and other real time applications, and some best practices in doing the measurements.

schedule.title: Tempest Plugin Crash Course
schedule.description: As the number and scope of OpenStack projects expands, project creators have a need to rapidly test that their project is interoperable with the core OpenStack services. Developers need to be able to test that their code does not break this interoperability without the hassle of extensive manual testing. Core reviewers need to ensure that new patches do not break the functionality that their project offers to the core OpenStack services. All of this can be accomplished by leveraging the Tempest project to create a specific software library called a Tempest plugin. This presentation explains exactly how a Tempest plugin fits into the OpenStack ecosystem, provides a step by step tutorial on how to create a Tempest plugin, demonstrates how to use the plugin to run tests in a local cloud, and explains how to test new code by incorporating an existing project's plugin into OpenStacks test infrastructure.
schedule.social_description: This presentation explains what a Tempest plugin is and how to create one.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn the history and context of Tempest plugins, and how to create a Tempest plugin for an existing OpenStack project.

schedule.title: China National Offshore Cloud Platform: Large Scale OpenStack Optimization
schedule.description:
China national offshore group is a giant state-owned company in china, which dominated and supervised by the SASAC. And up to now, the company has been developed into a global giant with diversified business, ranging from oil-gas exploration, oil refining, and chemical fertilizer to power generation, new energy and financial service.

Currently, the company has built 9 datacenters across Asia, America, Australia and Africa, which running 600+ international core applications to support their increasing business need and 80000+ employed staff daily office work. While all the datacenters are built in a distributed way, which lacking the ability to manage the resource in a unified way. So to solve the problem, the company finally decided to transform their existed datacenter into cloud datacenter. The newly built cloud datacenter will provide IaaS/PaaS/SaaS service for the end user, and migrate all the application to the cloud datacenter step by step.
schedule.social_description: China National Offshore Cloud Platform: Large Scale OpenStack Optimization
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The cloud datacenter will be built across multiple countries, and the one in Beijing will become the primary one. And all the datacenters have deployed the OpenStack platform to delivery cloud resource. Besides, virtualization platform, SDN and distributed storage are fully integrated with the OpenStack Platform. Up to now, above 700 IBM power machine existed, and besides, virtualization platform like VMware and XenServer, and bare mental server also existed, so new plugin was developed for integration.

The scale of the project was huge, so it was separated into several period, in the first period, 2000 physical CPU has been built, and the number of the physical CPU will be expanded to 40000 by the end of the project.

schedule.title: Immutable OpenStack infrastructure
schedule.description:
At Paddy Power Betfair we deploy our services in an immutable way and with zero downtime. From the beginning we architectured our OpenStack implementation to be able to deploy it in an immutable way. Discover in this talk:

  • how we automated the deployment of a new OpenStack release
  • how we manage multiple instances of OpenStack running in parallel
  • how we recycle automatically compute node from one instane to another
  • how we are going to upgrade OpenStack from Kilo to Ocata
  • and all the challenges we faced while doing this work
schedule.social_description: Discover how we deploy and upgrade immutable instances of OpenStack at Paddy Power Betfair.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How we automated of the infrastructure supporting OpenStack: Network Switches, Hardware configuration and Patching, Libvirt Servers, OpenStack Undercloud VM, ScaleOut, Hardware migration from one instance to another (Hints: Ansible, GO CD, Ironic Standalone)

How we organised our pipelines to migrate our services from one old OpenStack implementation to the new one.

schedule.title: Does my app or tool work on OpenStack Cloud X? Use RefStack to find out ...
schedule.description:
When you have developed your application against an OpenStack and want to move to another cloud, you want to find out how compatible it is? If you are using a tool to manage your application landscape in one cloud, how do you get an idea of the compatibility of an OpenStack cloud with this tool?

The answer is Tempest and RefStack.

RefStack has traditionally been used to collect results from tempest runs and compare against the OpenStack Powered (fka Defcore) guidelines. This is great and ensures a base level of interoperability between the passing cloud implementations.

RefStack has planned to support custom guidelines recently. This allows you to create guidelines that match the needs of your application or tool -- use it to find out whether a cloud is suitable for you.

The presentation will give you an overview how to develop guidelines and use RefStack custom guidelines to give you the answers. We will look at some real world examples and discuss benefits and todos.
schedule.social_description: Custom guidelines are a powerful tool to determine cloud compatible with your apps or tools.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will see RefStack custom guidelines applied in practice and learn about the possibilites and limitations to use them to determine application and or tooling compatibility.

They will develop an understanding of how custom guidelines look like and should be defined.

schedule.title: Project Update - Neutron
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Neutron and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Neutron plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the PROJECT PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Date with China OpenStack Hackathon
schedule.description:
I have participated in China OpenStack Hackathon twice and really gained a lot.

It’s an activity for OpenStack upstream developers to solve bugs in community and offer a stage for all developers to communicate face to face.

My talk is going to be 4 parts.

#1.What's the China OpenStack Hackathon

#2.Why take part in Hackathon

#3.My Hackathon experience

#4.What I gained in Hackathon
schedule.social_description: OpenStack Hackathon is an activity for upstream developers to communicate and solve bugs together.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Wishing more upstream developers to participate in OpenStack Hackathon with media campaign.

schedule.title: Zero Touch High Availability with Masakari and Consul
schedule.description: In most cloud deployments, a mix of cloud-native (cattle) and traditional (pet) workloads exist. Traditional, non-cloud workloads require infrastructure support to manage availability. Openstack Masakari project recovers pet workloads from hardware failures by automatically re-locating VMs to healthy nodes. It relies on infrastructure monitoring to detect failures e.g. pacemaker. Although workloads from a failed node are recovered, distributed consensus cluster needs reconfiguration. Cloud admin is expected to reconfigure node monitoring software and re-establish the consensus. Platform9 implemented a zero touch node monitoring solution with consul. This solution integrates with Masakari API to provides a completely automated HA for Openstack. In this talk, we present a deep dive on Masakari and automated cluster management for HA clusters.
schedule.social_description: In this talk we demonstrate a seamless HA solution for Openstack using Masakari and Consul.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Role of Virtual Machine HA in protecting workloads from failures. Common HA terminology such as MTBF, recovery time, etc. Architecture of Masakari and its features. Consul as distributed monitoring solution and automated zero touch reconfiguration solution with consul based distributed consensus.

schedule.title: Non-native English speakers in the OpenStack community: A True Story
schedule.description:
The primary language of most open source projects is English, but open source users and contributors span the globe. Non-native speakers face many communication challenges when participating in the ecosystem. In this talk, as non-native English speakers and contributors to OpenStack projects and its community, we will share our experiences and some best practices for coping as and including non-native speakers in your project.This talk will include:

  • Common issues for non-native English speakers
  • Tips for avoiding and resolving these issues
  • Suggestions for effective communication
schedule.social_description: How to contribute to OpenStack community through "True Stories" as non-native English speakers
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about what is the challenges of non-native English speakers and how we overcome them. It is useful for many contributors because there is a lot of non-native English speakers now in the OpenStack community which is so big.

schedule.title: Practical OpenStack Operations: What happens after Day 1
schedule.description: You now have a fully deployed OpenStack Cloud. Great. You made the right decision. But what happens next? This presentation looks into the most common operational problems that a typical Cloud administrator will face after day 1: security, currency, monitoring, problem detection, analysis & resolution, scalability and configuration elasticity, among others. It will compare capabilities of familiar DevOps tools, such as Ansible, Juju/MaaS, Nagios/Icinga, Zabbix, ELK, Ganglia, Grafana, etc. The DevOps landscape is extensive and it can be confusing to understand the pros and cons of a particular stack of applications to complement Cloud operation needs. It's our goal in to clarify the available options and categorize them, while emphasizing their differences, strengths and weaknesses. Lastly we discuss best practices to integrate them with OpenStack to achieve flexible and effortless Cloud operations.
schedule.social_description: This presentation addresses the most typical Operational problems a Cloud Administrator will face.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
OpenStack Administrators will learn what are the most common tasks they should do to operate their Cloud Infrastructure successfully. This will include:

- scalability considerations

- tenant and user access & security

- updates & upgrades

- health and availability monitoring

- performance tunning

schedule.title: Cloud Dataverse
schedule.description:
Cloud Dataverse is a new service for accessing and processing public data sets in an OpenStack Cloud. It is based on Dataverse, a popular framework for sharing, preserving, and analyzing research data. Cloud Dataverse extends Dataverse to replicate datasets from per-institution repositories to a cloud-based repository and store data in Swift, enabling applications running in the cloud to access data in-situ. We use OpenStack Sahara to launch on-demand Big Data applications that use Swift as a datasource for analytics jobs running on Hadoop, Spark, or Pig.

We follow the user's journey through the Cloud Dataverse: browsing datasets, the harvesting/replication process, viewing files in the object store, and the use of compute provided by Sahara. To enhance user experience in Sahara, we will provide the automatic generation of default cluster templates via the Dataverse UI, which will allow users to bypass the complexity of Horizon.
schedule.social_description: Cloud Dataverse extends Dataverse for improved data processing workflows in the OpenStack cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• The features of the existing Dataverse project
  • The relevant new functionality which allow the integration of Dataverse with OpenStack
  • The basics of OpenStack Sahara

schedule.title: Collaboration of OpenStack Blazar and OPNFV Promise for meeting NFV resource management requirements
schedule.description:
While cloud allows users to provision resources on-demand and gives an illusion of unlimited capacity, in reality the underlying resources are limited and require resource sharing which could cause inefficient cloud operation. This is especially important for NFV clouds, where service degradation may occur if additional resources are not available adjacent to the resources for a network service that may experience expected or unexpected spike in traffic.

OPNFV Promise project was initiated to solve this problem by introducing resource reservation for future usage. Since OpenStack is considered to be the defacto VIM for NFV, OPNFV Promise team is collaborating with OpenStack Blazar project and Product Working Group to address this issue.


This session will aim to provide an overview of how Promise and Blazar address the following

  • Accept future resource usage requests
  • Provide guaranteed access to reserved resources
  • Manage resource usage conflicts
schedule.social_description: Learn how OPNFV & OpenStack projects are solving future usage requests for NFV & general workloads
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this session, attendees can learn why resource reservation is important, not only for NFV workloads but for general cloud operators. We will provide details on the results of collaboration between OPNFV Promise and OpenStack Blazar project teams which includes the following:

Generalized user story for capacity management for cloud providers & operators (via OpenStack PWG)

  • Gap analysis between this user story and *real* OpenStack features
  • Collaboration to update OpenStack Blazar code


Since NFV is just one use case for OpenStack, OPNFV Promise team has agreed to expand the scope to generalize the requirements while developing the user story in collaboration with Blazar team. Attendees can learn how Promise project has translated its specific requirements to generalized OpenStack requirements and how they are being addressed by the community.

schedule.title: Pit stop at 100mph – hot to upgrade a large scale public cloud from Juno to Mitaka
schedule.description:
Upgrading from one major OpenStack version to the next can only be described as a painful experience to put this in positive words. Things turn from dark to pitch black if you try to do this on a large scale public cloud and not only one major version but actually three – from Juno to Mitaka!

This presentation describes how we nevertheless managed to implement this update in production nearly without noise, what prereq measures we took, how a good vendor can support and in what problems we ran.

Additionally this will highlight further strategies how to maintain large scale environments in service provider grade.
schedule.social_description: Lessons learnt from a real-life upgrade of Open Telekom Cloud from Juno to Mitaka.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How to survive a major version upgrade of OpenStack
  • How to minimize downtime for the platform and the customer
  • How to do proper customer communication
  • Faced pitfalls and scalability problems
  • Strategies for large scale platform operations

schedule.title: OpenStack and OVN - What's New with OVS 2.7
schedule.description:
OVN is a virtual networking project built by the Open vSwitch community.
OpenStack can make use of OVN as its backend networking implementation
for Neutron. OVN and its Neutron integration are ready for use in OpenStack
deployments.

This talk will cover the latest developments in the OVN project and the
latest release, part of OVS 2.7. Enhancements include better performance,
improved debugging capabilities, and more flexible L3 gateways.
We will take a look ahead the next set of things we expect to work on for
OVN, which includes logging for OVN ACLs (security groups), encrypted
tunnels, native DNS integration, and more.

We will also cover some of the performance comparison results of OVN
as compared with the original OVS support in Neutron (ML2/OVS). Finally,
we will discuss how to deploy OpenStack with OVN or migrate an existing
deployment from ML2/OVS to OVN.
schedule.social_description: Learn about OpenStack Networking Using OVN from the Open vSwitch community.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn the latest developments about OVN and how they may be used for OpenStack Networking deployments.

schedule.title: Project Update - Nova
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Nova and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity. 

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Nova plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term. 

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Nova PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments

schedule.title: Octavia: Load Balancing for OpenStack
schedule.description:
Octavia is now a top-level OpenStack project providing network load balancing.  In this presentation, we will introduce the new Octavia project and what it means for load balancing in OpenStack.  We will discuss the spin-out of neutron-lbaas and octavia from the neutron stadium including the ongoing merge of the neutron-lbaas v2 API into octavia.

The team has started work merging neutron-lbaas into octavia in the Ocata series and plan to complete this work during Pike.  We will talk about backward compatibility and migration plans, not only for the existing API, but existing load balancers and vendor drivers from both an operator and end user perspective.

Finally, we will give an overview of the updated octavia project roadmap including what we plan to accomplish for Pike.
schedule.social_description: Introducing Octavia as a new top level OpenStack project for network load balancing.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees with learn about the Octavia poject and the ongoing effort to merge neutron-lbaas into Octavia.  This will include the changes planned for the Pike release and our roadmap for the project going forward.

Topics will cover:

What is included in the new octavia project?

What does the neutron-lbaas / octavia merge mean?

Overview of the new Octavia v2 API.

The migration plan for operators and users.

Changes for the vendor drivers currently available via neutron-lbaas.

The Octavia project roadmap.

schedule.title: Bite off More Than You Can Chew, Then Chew It: OpenStack Consumption Models
schedule.description:
While deciding on your OpenStack deployment methodology is important, sometimes the biggest issues arise from customizations that weren't well planned. We'll talk about thinking through when and where to use nonstandard configurations and the operational and business impacts of doing so.  Equally important to your success is the model by which you consume OpenStack.

The topics we will cover include:

  • Consumption Models, Pros and Cons
  • Stability vs. Capability
  • Maintainability vs. Customization
  • Building an OpenStack Practice vs. Consuming OpenStack as a Service
  • Costs, Operational Challenges, and Upstream Considerations associated with each consumption model
  • Approaches to Managed OpenStack

After leaving this session, you'll be prepared to think through the long term ramifications of your deployment and customization decisions on your organization as a whole, and make better decisions as you continue your OpenStack cloud Journey
schedule.social_description: Discuss different consumption models with opinions from three different managed cloud providers
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The topics we will cover include:

  • Consumption Models, Pros and Cons
  • Stability vs. Capability
  • Maintainability vs. Customization
  • Building an OpenStack Practice vs. Consuming OpenStack as a Service
  • Costs, Operational Challenges, and Upstream Considerations associated with each consumption model
  • Approaches to Managed OpenStack

schedule.title: CIB Fintech Company built the first and largest Chinese financial industry cloud with OpenStack
schedule.description:
In 2005,Industrial Bank launched the “Bank link Platform”,which is a total financial service solution including payment、settlement、total solution of IT system、agency international settlement and so on.
In Nov. 2015,the Platform had signed a total of 637 customers,529 of them had been online,294 of them were cooperative banks which had counter-link with CIB,including more than 35 thousand outlets,total amount of payment settlement had exceed more than 2.5 trillion RMB.
In Dec. 2015,CIB Fintech Company was founded by CIB、Global InfoTech、Kingdom Technology and New land.It built the first Chinese financial industry cloud with openstack,“Fintech Cloud”,which undertaking the part of IT solution service of “Bank link Platform”,mainly providing financial cloud computing services for its cooperative partners such as commercial banks,medium banks,village banks,and non-bank financial institutions.
So far, Fintech Cloud's openstack environment has 400 nodes, and has planned about 1000 more nodes.
schedule.social_description: Fintech Cloud have provided financial cloud services for more than 500 banks by using OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How to provide Inclusive finance service with openstack, so that helping small and medium banks enhance IT management level and market competitiveness?
  • So far, Fintech Cloud's openstack environment has 400 nodes, and has planned about 1000 more nodes. How to design and implement the solution for the deployment of OpenStack on the large scale?
  • More than 500 banks become Fintech Cloud’s tenant, how to design and implement the billing system for these tenants?
  • Financial services require high availability and security, how to enhance the availability and security of Fintech Cloud?

schedule.title: Using OpenStack SDKs to create my first cloud native application
schedule.description:
Cloud native applications are designed, developed, deployed and consumed differently. To be able to innovate applications in the cloud, application developers need help for changing their mindset from the traditional way to the cloud native one.

Have you ever wondered how to create a cloud native application for an OpenStack cloud? Join us and find out how to do it with this hands-on workshop where you will be developing cloud applications using OpenStack APIs and SDKs.

Hands-on labs

  • Web photo album: Interact with Swift API using Shade SDK (Python) to upload and store pictures in an OpenStack cloud and show them in a frontend application.
  • Video encoder:  By using the Gophercloud SDK (Golang), learn how the encoder application communicates with Nova API to launch transcoding workers that convert media files into different formats.

Please bring your laptop with Docker installed and the openstack-shade and openstack-gophercloud images pulled from Docker Hub.
schedule.social_description: Learn how to create a cloud native application using SDKs to interact with the OpenStack services.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
By the end of this session you will

  • Understand what is a cloud native application.
  • Have knowledge about the available OpenStack resources for application developers.
  • Learn how to choose the best SDK to build your application and most important, get experience developing cloud native applications that use OpenStack APIs and SDKs.

schedule.title: Hands-on to configure your cloud to be able to charge your users using official openStack components
schedule.description:
Selling the services provided by a Cloud is one of the essential aspect of the life of a Cloud Provider (both Public or Private). Thus being able to define the various prices and policies that needs to be apply needs to be done using some components at the root of the infrastructure.

In this workshop you'll have the chance to learn how access the new way to handle metrics in an OpenStack Cloud but also to use them for your pricing rules. ALl this using ONLY some official components !

This hands-on (you need to bring your laptop) will tackle the following aspects :

  • reminder of gnocchi and cloudkitty
  • installation of gnocchi
  • installation of cloudkitty
  • configure cloudkitty to use gnocchi
  • define a standard pricing policy using horizon
schedule.social_description: Hands-on to configure your cloud to be able to charge your users using official openStack components
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• reminder of gnocchi and cloudkitty
  • installation of gnocchi
  • installation of cloudkitty
  • configure cloudkitty to use gnocchi
  • define a standard pricing policy using horizon

schedule.title: Secure Containers using Kernel Self-Protection
schedule.description:
Today container orchestrators provide a multitude of features for containers targeted to improve the security of host like seccomp, user namespace etc. We are proposing a kernel feature in this direction for improving the host kernel security using kernel self-protection during the run-time of containers.

Host kernel can declare its critical resources e.g. IDT, RO data etc. and also processor state that needs to protected. Hardware assisted virtualization features can be used for "hardening"  these kernel resources and locking the processor state when the processor is executing in “guest” (virtualization) mode.

We have extended the KVM hypervisor so that we can use the hardening technique to sandbox the container execution context by driving the processors to guest mode before executing container code. We can maintain the lightweight and efficient features of containers and at the same time achieve hardening of the host kernel without any typical virtualization overhead.
schedule.social_description: Sainath works for Intel in the field of containers and virtualization software.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees walk away with another perspective on protecting openstack hosts using hardware-assisted virtualization

schedule.title: OpenStack + OpenHPC = HPC Cloud
schedule.description:
High performance computing (HPC) is one of the fastest growing segments of the computing industry, but meeting the complex software demands of an HPC application is challenging in a cloud environment. OpenHPC, a Linux Foundation Collaborative Project, provides an integrated collection of HPC components to provide an HPC software stack.  Two recently completed prototypes demonstrate enabling an HPC environment within an OpenStack cloud using OpenHPC:

  • Creating an HPC sub-cluster within an OpenStack cloud
  • Extending a traditional HPC system with additional resources available from an OpenStack cloud

Architectures to provision an HPC environment with HPC optimized bare metal images and OpenHPC ingredients within OpenStack allow HPC jobs to complete successfully in cloud and hybrid environments. Enabling HPC within OpenStack creates a foundation to execute HPC applications in cloud environments with performance approaching that of a traditional HPC bare metal cluster.
schedule.social_description: OpenStack with OpenHPC provides an efficient platform to enable and run cloud and HPC applications.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attend this session to learn how to enable an HPC environment using OpenHPC within an OpenStack cloud, including:

  • A brief introduction to HPC: systems, configuration, and deployment
  • An introduction to the OpenHPC project
  • Detailed architectures of two prototypes to provision an HPC environment with HPC optimized bare metal images and OpenHPC ingredients within OpenStack
  • Setting up an HPC cluster within an on-premises OpenStack cloud system
  • Extending a traditional on-premises HPC cluster with OpenHPC to instantiate additional HPC resources with an OpenStack environment
  • How to run an HPC application in an OpenStack cloud
  • Additional development areas to enhance HPC within OpenStack
  • How to contribute to OpenHPC development and integration

schedule.title: To OpenStack or not OpenStack; that is the question
schedule.description:
Today - the diversity of choice a CIO / Architect has to make is staggering. From programming languages, to databases, to Public/Private Cloud providers, let alone the diversity of just building an underlying, private infrastructure.

Within and outside the OpenStack community, the complexities, failures, and successes of OpenStack are parodied, leading Enterprises to wonder - should we invest?

This lightning talk outlines how OpenStack vendors "qualify" and decide to "invest" in an Enterprise for building a Private Cloud, and then outline (3-5 scenarios) where I believe OpenStack is the "right choice" and when OpenStack is the "wrong choice" (for now). 

This talk is based on personal experiences of

  • Working for Mirantis: Pure-Play OpenStack Firm:
  • Working for RedHat: OpenStack, Containers, Automation, Virtualization, Linux
  • Speaking and talking to hundreds of Enterprises
schedule.social_description: This lightning talk has a technical/business decision-framework on investing in OpenStack or not.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how to build a technical and business framework to make the decision whether to invest or not in OpenStack.

schedule.title: Enabeling a Serverless mindset :  Unpacking ‘Function as a Service’ on OpenStack
schedule.description:
We believe that the future of business lies in leveraging & supporting cloud services. Do more with less, and focus on delivering creative solutions for your users.

One of the joys of serverless "FaaS" (Function as a Service)  is that 'horizontal scaling is completely automatic, elastic, and managed by the provider'. There are several benefits to this but on the basic infrastructural side the biggest benefit is that you only pay for the compute.

This project brings the benefits of serverless computing to large enterprises. Developers will be able to write logic as Docker images and allow for event-driven processing without the need to provision infrastructure. Ease of use and adaptability are indicative of the developer-first nature of the serverless computing that are now
available to the OpenStack community.
schedule.social_description: Enabeling a Serverless mindset :  Unpacking ‘Function as a Service’ on OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Workshop/Recorded-Demo Planned :

Workshop #1: Serverless Architectures Tested to Destruction

One of the key benefits of serverless architectures is their ability to scale when sudden and unexpected load arrives… but do they really? In this workshop you will first build and deploy a simple event-driven serverless architecture using the new Serverless Framework Once your service is up and running, you’ll then use serverless-artillery to quickly and inexpensively generate massive amounts of load.

Workshop #2: Building a Serverless Messenger : Patform and the Serveless Framework

Demo/Hands-on with the technology required to build a serverless Messenger on OpenStack.

Workshop #3: Hands-on! Learn how to build event-driven serverless applications with OpenStack

Today's leading enterprise (mobile) applications are being composed of loosely coupled, cloud-based microservices, to provide powerful end-to-end capabilities that leverage the growing ecosystem of microservice providers. Events-on-demand technologies are driving a new level of simplicity and scalability in wiring these disparate microservices together, providing a distributed compute service to execute application logic in response to events, while hiding the complex infrastructure aspects.

schedule.title: Big Data as a Service at Mass open Cloud
schedule.description: We describe the Massachusetts Open Cloud (MOC) Big Data as a Service (BDaaS) solution we built on top of OpenStack. BDaaS allow users access public data sets and stand up Hadoop and SPARK environments on-demand to work on these datasets. We use Cloud Dataverse, an open-source framework that can store data in Ceph, as our data repository. Ceph’s RADOS gateway (RGW) is used as a gateway between the Big Data analysis tasks and the Ceph storage service. To improve the performance of the Big Data environments, we modified RGW to cache data in SSDs attached to a server local to each rack. All requests for data are automatically directed by the network to the nearest RGW. Users can browse, investigate, and download datasets at MOC Dataverse and run analytics on any of the datasets by clicking a button to provision a Big Data processing environment. BDaaS will prefetch the data from Ceph into caches, and then invoke OpenStack Sahara to create the on-demand environment.
schedule.social_description: We will describe the Massachusetts Open Cloud Big Data as a Service (BDaaS) solution.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: We describe the high-performance Big Data as a Service (BDaaS) framework we built on top of OpenStack for use in the Massachusetts Open Cloud.  Our BDaaS framework enables Hadoop and Spark Jobs to compute on large datasets on-demand without downloading them to local storage a priori.  Users can browse datasets, select relevant ones, and run analytics on them at the touch of a button.  It avoids slow accesses to remote storage by caching frequently-used datasets (or portions of datasets) in per-rack SSDs and re-directing requests to the closest one.  It uses Cloud DataVerse, an open-source framework that stores data in Ceph, as its data repository and implements the caching tier within Ceph’s RadoS gateway.

schedule.title: Neutron: Where did my packets go ?
schedule.description:
Neutron is a key component of openstack, through which all network traffic flows. Understanding neutron's components is key to effectively operate and troubleshoot openstack deployments. In this presentation, we will focus on explaining the key parts of openstack neutron and how they interact.

The presentation will detail how packets flow inbound/outbound to/from a tenant instance. It will explain the functionality of different pieces of neutron and introduce the audience to where L3 and L2 routing/switching decisions are made for traffic. This will include explaining the functionality of neutron agents (ml2, L3, dhcp & briefly metadata) and how they are physically deployed in an openstack environment ( network namspaces, dnsmasq...). The presentation will beirfly cover network namespaces in linux

The presentation will end with a live demo of tracing an instance traffic inbound/outbound to give the audience a hands-on experience and to solidify the understanding
schedule.social_description: Neutron: Where did my packets go ? Explaining neutron components for Openstack starters
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The presentation will focus on explaining neutron, and mapping neutron components to native linux technologies/services (network namespaces, dnsmasq, linux bridge...) The attendes should expect to learn 

- An understanding of neutron key componenets (neutron-server & agents) and how they interact

- Network namespaces in Linux

- How traffic flows from and to instances in openstack (tap devices, linux bridges..)

- How routers are deployed in openstack using the l3-agent (network namespaces creation and routing rules)

- How dhcp works within openstack using dnsmasq

schedule.title: Distributed Monitoring and Analysis for Telecom Requirements
schedule.description:
Many telecom companies have started using OpenStack for NFV, MEC and RAN. During this experience, additional requirements have come from the telecom environments due to strict quality criteria and their diverse services. KDDI Research has been led "Recover first, Resolve next" PoC project for closed-loop operation in TM Forum ZOOM.

We focus on monitoring statistical data in a huge scale OpenStack environment with less performance impact, then we evaluate the gap between the current situation and our expectations. In this research, we came up with a solution - the distributed monitoring framework: collecting, aggregating and real-time analysis, with a centralized Ceilometer.

In this presentation, you will learn about the gap, our evaluation of Ceilometer, Congress and Monasca, and our approach for distributed monitoring with its benefits: scalability, agility and flexibility. In addition to the architectural challenges, we will cover various use cases based on telecom operations.
schedule.social_description: Distributed Monitoring and Analysis for Telecom Requirements: Background, Evaluation, Design.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Overview of monitoring and real-time analysis for cloud operations.
  • Detailed requirements for scalability and high-performance in telecom (applicable to other purposes!).
  • Evaluation results of monitoring various metrics with Ceilometer/collectd/Congress/Monasca.
  • Actual use cases and applications.
  • Operation scenario of "Recovery first, Resolve next".
  • How you can participate this activity.

schedule.title: Scaling to 100 nodes and beyond
schedule.description: Enterprises have elicited concerns about the availability and performance of OpenStack as workload and deployment size increases. In this session, we want to promote adoption by showing you that with OpenStack, horizontal scaling is not only possible, but a straightforward and replicable process.
