We will discuss the environmental considerations necessary prior to scaling, then demonstrate our successful process of scaling a 22 node environment to 100 nodes and beyond.
schedule.social_description: Scaling from 22 to over 100 nodes: A discussion and demonstration of the straight-forward process.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Operators and leaders will learn that scaling on OpenStack is a straight-forward, replicable process. Attendees will walk away with knowledge on what must be considered prior to scaling, and what the scaling process entails.

schedule.title: Project Update - Octavia
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Octavia and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Octavia plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term. 

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Octavia PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: The Practice of OpenStack landing in State Grid Corporation of China
schedule.description: State Grid Corporation of China(SGCC) is the NO.2 company in global F500 list(Y2016) and the largest electric utility company over the world. There is a large infrastructure pool with 600+ types of applications running on 6000+ hosts to provide service for 1.1 billion people in China. By the end of 2016, we had successfully deployed OpenStack-based cloud in 31 datacenters from 26 provinces .The presentation will give the case study of OpenStack practice in SGCC in the past 2 years to transform the distributed legacy architecture to an unified cloud. We will share our BKMs to solve challenges to deliver OpenStack in such a large organization. There are also challges in security-domain compliance, legacy virtualization environment integration and the upcoming demands on operation automation. This presentation will go through them and give the solution which we had done in SGCC Cloud Resource Management Platform based on OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: OpenStack landing sharing from China State Grid, the world’s largest electric utility company
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The architecture of SGCC Cloud Resource Management Platform based on OpenStack; The experience of building OpenStack based Cloud in large and complexity enterprises; The sharing of design on heterogeneous resources management,  automatic operation and maintenance in OpenStack environment, etc.

schedule.title: Privacy: 10 Facts to handle Cross-border data traffic with openstack = International + EU + Germany
schedule.description:
General data protection regulation will apply from 25 May 2018

International authority on data protection is not a technical problem of openstack. International court of jurisdiction. The US, German and European data protection laws do not contain any special rules on the question of which courts are competent in international matters. German law is generally applicable to facts and events in Germany (principle of territoriality). This is also the data protection point of departure.

When dealing with personal data, national borders play an important role today. Each country is subject to legal violations of high fines. The technical solution openstack offers possibilities to implement the specifications internationally.

conflict

“…Google has to leave FBI outside of the US stored customer dat"

New Risk EU

Data controllers can face fines of up to €20 mio or 4% of their global annual turnover. These administrative sanctions will be imposed by the national data protection authorities.
schedule.social_description: data traffic with openstack = International + EU + Germany
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
* Privicy data International + EU + Germany

* Cross-border data traffic with openstack = International + EU + Germany

* solutions for International + EU + Germany

schedule.title: What makes it possible to run OpenStack Community for three generations
schedule.description:
This is the third peaceful regime change in our community in 5 years. Korea User Group has founded in early 2011, and become one of the most active user groups in the world. We started from 10 people gathering together, and now we have more than 5,000 people registered in our main community website, running three consecutive OpenStack Days since 2014. In this talk, three current/ex-leaders will share what we experienced and overcome problems for three uniquely different eras in our community.

First Era: Rising - It is newly starting small group of people.

Second Era: Expanding in size - It tries to expand its size and have a big event. It also introduces new kinds of fun, as well as difficulties and misunderstanding among people. 

Third Era: Expanding in diversity - Once you grow in size, it faces conflict of interest. In addition, people start having more specific needs. Community needs to embrace more diversity considering these different needs. 

Lastly, how to run OpenStack Days.
schedule.social_description: Korea User Group sharing their 7 years of experiences running user group to help community to grow.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees learn what are the problems and difficulties running User Group in various size. In addition, where all the fun is coming from. We hope our experiences and materials we share help user groups across the world.

schedule.title: test presentation2
schedule.description: test presentation 2
schedule.social_description: test presentation 2

schedule.title: Kuryr-Kubernetes: The seamless path to adding Pods to your datacenter networking
schedule.description:
In a world where application increasingly are architected into microservices, it is important to find the right way to network your datacenter choosing among solutions originally from the virtualization world and those that arose with simpler container native scenarios.

Kuryr offers Container Orchestration engines, e.g. Kubernetes, the network facilities from OpenStack Neutron, with its rich ecosystem of mature networking implementations.

With pod-in-VM support, Kuryr-Kubernetes networking enables a whole slew of new hybrid workload configurations, like bare metal or in-VM pods accessing pre-existing services that run on VMs, multiple Container Orchestration Engines (e.g. Docker Swarm to Kubernetes), and more. Unified networking simplifies deployment, configuration and provides single pane of glass into management and troubleshooting.

In this session we will dive into Kuryr Kubernetes and demo Pods running on Nova instances consuming VM workloads via OpenStack Neutron.
schedule.social_description: Unified OpenStack Neutron networking for VMs and Kubernetes pods (bare-metal and in-VM)
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn about the solution’s design and key features, as well as primer to getting mixed workload environments up and running.

schedule.title: Enterprise Cloud Offering Models and Service Strategies
schedule.description: In this session, we will explore Cisco IT’s deployment of OpenStack and how to offer an internal cloud service. As our deployments, have grown we will show the progression of our offering and support model to provide Infrastructure as a Service with true business value for our company. As the clouds continue to grow the capacity management and evolving cost model will be explained with our lesson learnt and challenges overcome. As we look to the future our Feature enablement strategy and automated ordering, provisioning and consumption capabilities will provide the best experience for our application owners, developers and users.
schedule.social_description: Explore Cisco IT’s deployment of OpenStack and how to offer an internal cloud service
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Cisco IT's experience on the following items:

  • Offering Models
  • Cost Models
  • Support models and the move to Devops
  • Capacity management
  • The change in application requirements

How these are combined for a business case to use OpenStack and the Return on Investment possibilities.

schedule.title: Container as a Service on GPU Cloud: Our Decision among K8s, Mesos, Docker Swarm and OpenStack Zun
schedule.description:
To meet the rising demand of machine learning workload, cloud providers as AWS, Azure, and GCP begin to offer GPU instances. When providing GPU resources for users who want to concentrate on machine learning tasks, easy environment setup is important. On the other hand, for administrators, multi-tenancy and fairly sharing GPU resources are essential to manage resources efficiently.

For environment setup, container technology as Docker and nvidia-docker enable us to deploy fast without considering dependency and combinations of guestOS, libraries, and even device drivers. For multi-tenancy, OpenStack Magnum can be a solution. But fairly sharing GPU resources is not easy for now because GPU container scheduling is not yet mature in the major container orchestration engines (COEs).

Through building our in-house container as a service on a GPU cluster, we surveyed and compared among kubernetes, mesos, and OpenStack Zun, on a PoC environment with Nvidia DGX-1 machines.
schedule.social_description: Current situation of GPU container scheduling and how to provide GPU using COEs + nvidia-docker.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this session you will learn

- The advantage and use-case of container technology when using GPU resources.

  • Docker (nowadays, nvidia-docker is released for Nvidia GPU) enable us to deploy fast without considering dependency and combination of libraries, guestOS, and even device drivers.

- The current situation of GPU resource scheduling in some major COEs.

  • You will learn our survey results on major COEs including mesos, kubernetes, and OpenStack Zun (next-generation nova-docker) in terms of GPU container scheduling.

- How to provide GPU resources using COEs + nvidia-docker.

  • You will learn the details of our experimental environment including two Nvidia DGX-1 machines with 16 GPUs. Our experiment results on the behavior of scheduling functionality of each candidate, lead us to mesos at last.

schedule.title: Prevention and Detection of Orphaned Resources
schedule.description:
System and network resources are finite in nature, properly managing these resources is essential to maintaining a healthy cloud.  These resources are consumed when an openstack component is created, for example VMs consume disk space memory and cpu from their host.

One type of resource stands out as an area we can improve: orphans.  Orphans are items such as networks, VMs, routers that are associated with a tenant, but are not removed at the time a tenant is deleted.  We focus on two methods in order to reduce the number of orphans in an OpenStack cloud.

We will demonstrate the impacts different orphaned components can have on your cloud, how to prevent them using OSPurge, and how to identify them for removal.
schedule.social_description: A practical example of orphan management in OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn what constitutes an "orphan" in OpenStack and the processes in which they are created.

Additionally we will illustrate the impacts orphans can have on an OpenStack deployment, how to prevent new orphans, and how to identify and remove existing orphans.

schedule.title: GUTS: Simplifying the move to OpenStack
schedule.description:
In this presentation, Bharat will show you how to simplify the migration process with a workload migration engine, making the move to OpenStack easy. This talk will address the various difficulties operators and administrators face when migrating workloads and resources between various cloud platforms, including removing time consuming, repetitive and complicated steps.


This tool can be applied to many cloud migrations, including between Virtual Machines and OpenStack, between Public and Private clouds, as well as between OpenStack and OpenStack. This tool integrates completely with other OpenStack projects minimising deployment and maintenance efforts. So whether you’re looking to upgrade from your existing traditional virtualisation platform, setup a new OpenStack instance, or upgrade to a newer version of OpenStack, we will show you how to simplify this process using GUTS.
schedule.social_description: GUTS: Simplifying the move to OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn how to migrate existing resources to an OpenStack cloud environment from other clouds using a reliable and automated method. Attendees will also learn an alternative approach to moving resources from older OpenStack clouds to more recent versions.

Topics covered during this presentation and demonstration will include:

  • Architecture and design
  • Other cloud to OpenStack migration scenarios
  • OpenStack to OpenStack migration scenarios
  • Demo showing single and multi instance migrations from VMware to OpenStack
  • CLI and GUI demos

schedule.title: Project Update - OpenStack-Ansible
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of OpenStack-Ansible and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements OpenStack-Ansible plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term. 

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the OpenStack-Ansible PTL for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Unlocking the Performance Secrets of Ceph Object Storage
schedule.description:
Object storage is clearly the simplest, most flexible, and most scalable way to store tons of unstructured content. In the last few months we were on a journey to discover "The Unknowns" from the world of Object storage. We have conducted an extensive testing with more than 1500 unique benchmarking tests across a wide range of hardware/software configuration. We have a ton of interesting things to share , so that you can design the best in class Ceph object storage solution for your workloads.

Join the experts to unlock the performance secrets, and take away answers to some of the most fundamental questions :

  • How to achieve max small/large, object (throughput/bandwidth) on fixed cluster size?
  • What happens at workload saturation point and how does the machinery behaves ?
  • What effect does a caching layer have on performance ? ( Hint : Never seen before results )
  • How much effect does reducing or eliminating index operation overhead have on small object throughput ?
schedule.social_description: Ceph Object Storage performance tuning,  benchmarking and best practices.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn the skills of benchmarking, tuning and best practices for Ceph Object Storage performance tuning. They will also take away answers to some of the most fundamental questions :-

  • How to achieve max small object operations on fixed cluster size?
  • How to achieve max large object throughput on fixed cluster size?
  • What happens at workload saturation point and how does the machinery behaves ?
  • What effect does data protection schemes have on price/performance?
  • What effect does total cluster object count have on workload performance?
  • What effect does a caching layer have on performance ? ( Hint : Never seen before results )
  • How much does performance improve with large numbers of small objects when using
  • Bucket index sharding
  • Indexless Buckets
  • Bucket Index on Flash Media vs. Spinner

schedule.title: StoryBoard 101: Survival Guide to the Great Migration
schedule.description:
Community members are uneducated about the state of StoryBoard and are unaware of how to make the transition from Launchpad to StoryBoard. In order to get all of the projects moved, they need to learn how to migrate all existing feature requests and bugs over to the new tool and, of course, how to use the new tool.

The process of migrating from Launchpad to StoryBoard is not a complicated one, but it not a well known path. Only a few projects have made the switch at this point and many that haven't moved don't have any real barriers to moving, they just don't know how. This presentation will educate attendees on the migrations scripts that exist, how features in StoryBoard map to the features community members are used to using in Launchpad, and how to begin using this new task tracking tool.
schedule.social_description: The Great Migration from Launchpad to Storyboard. Are you ready?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: By the end of our session, attendees will be familiar with the process the project will need to go through to make the switch and have a basic understanding of how to use StoryBoard for all their task tracking needs.

schedule.title: Event Correlation & Life Cycle Management – How will they coexist in the NFV world?
schedule.description:
As Service Providers utilize OpenStack to move into the Network Function Virtualization (NFV) world, it is evident that the cloud can not operate in a vacuum. To make NFV a reality, there will be Management and Orchestration (MANO) capabilities added to the OpenStack environment. Then there will be further automation and integration with existing BSS/OSS systems. 

Not only will it be vital for the different environments to be integrated but it will be necessary for them to work together in order to understand the end to end picture and how events outside their area of responsibility can have impacts on the services within their purview.

Correlation of events across all environments will be key to successful life cycle management of VNFs. Lack of good correlation will result in inappropriate actions being taken by systems and people to address issues, leading to potentially longer service outages.
schedule.social_description: Event Correlation and Life Cycle management two keys to success in NFV
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Monitoring & Correlation within the cloud (VIM)

1 - Has state of the infrastructure but no information on the services that utilize the infrastructure.

2 - Can recover a VNF but what about its configuration?

3 - What happens when there are issues outside the cloud that impact the service the VNF provides?

 

Monitoring & Correlation within MANO (NFVO/VNFM)

1- Has state of the services but does it truly know the infrastructure to correlate infrastructure events into service outages and recovery.

2 - Can recover and configure a VNF but can it really determine when the VNF is having issues versus underlay network issue? 

3 - Does it understand how the customer connects to the cloud and can it isolate issues to prevent taking inappropriate actions?

 

Monitoring & Correlation in Legacy Assurance Systems (NOCs)

1 - Integration of the environments

2 - Will these systems understand the virtual world enough to determine when a customers service has been disrupted?

3 - Will these systems be able to have a complete end to end view of the customer’s service?

 

Life Cycle Management - will it be clear who own what components or will multiple orchestrators and systems attempt to “Heal” the same components?

schedule.title: OpenStack: pushing to 5000 nodes and beyond
schedule.description:
Mirantis and Intel partnership in area of performance and scalability researches started almost two years ago, and since that time we went a long way from running OpenStack on 200 nodes to most recent 1000 nodes researches on daily basis. Achieving cloud maturity on all layers of this complex system made us look on every aspect and every component, and lead to creation of OpenStack Performance Team, publishing lots of researches and gaining community around this effort.

Join this presentation to go through our journey - starting from our first activities to latest researches answering the question: how can we push vanilla OpenStack to 5000 nodes and beyond?
schedule.social_description: OpenStack Scale and Performance researches: community, methodologies and most recent experiments.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Methodology of scale and performance testing
  • Results of Mirantis / Intel investigation activities
  • Most recent experiments and latest recommendations

schedule.title: Fire Up the Build: A Hands-On Workshop with the Heat Orchestration Service
schedule.description: So you finally had a chance to create some instances, networks, and volumes.  How do you bring it all together with a single click? Join us as we take OpenStack beginners on an immersive interactive journey through Heat, the OpenStack orchestration service.  This workshop provides an easy-to-understand introduction to the world of Heat by not only presenting a fun look at the history of cloud orchestration, but a step-by-step walkthrough on leveraging the power of Heat Orchestration Templates to easily fire up an OpenStack application in seconds!
schedule.social_description: Get the confidence to edit and deploy Heat templates!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will first learn about the history of cloud orchestration and the origin of Heat.  A comprehensive review of Heat infrastructure will show attendees how the project fits into the overall OpenStack ecosystem.  Each participant will then gain hands-on Heat experience by accessing a live OpenStack environment where they will learn real-world use-cases to create Heat templates and orchestrate cloud resources, including images, instances, volumes, networks, routers, and load balancers.   By the end of this workshop, participants will walk away with the confidence to edit and deploy Heat templates in their organization's OpenStack environment!

schedule.title: I18n-101: Introduction to translation and contributing qualified translation with useful tips
schedule.description:
Are you new to OpenStack i18n or using I18n tools is still difficult? Are you looking for tips on qualified translation contribution to OpenStack Community? Then come here to attend to this hand-on workshop with experienced I18n team contributors.

You will learn basic overview of how I18n team makes use of Zanata - OpenStack translation platform. One language coordinator will demonstrate how more than 80 translators in one language collaborate each other for translation and review activities through Zanata and other OpenStack tools such as Wiki, Etherpad, and IRC.

Hands-on lab includes the overall workflow of I18n translations and exercises of translation contribution with practical step-by-step procedures in Zanata. Also, a Zanata team developer and I18n PTL will share common troubleshooting techniques and the best strategies for more qualified translation by cooperating with global translation teams and interacting with other OpenStack teams.
schedule.social_description: Come hear an introduction to translation platform and useful tips
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The hands-on lab is mainly designed for I18n translators and contributors, but not limited to them. The workshop is also useful for newbies who would like to join to I18n team and also anyone who are interested in OpenStack internationalization.Although translation contribution in OpenStack has been continuous for years and I18n team has become an official team for the latest four cycles, using translation contribution tools with useful tips has not been shared with globalized people relatively too much. Speakers hope that more people who are interested in translation contribution will come here and more translators who are geographically distributed so unable to come to Summit will see the workshop video content and materials which will be available after the Summit.

schedule.title: Netforce: Extending neutron to support routed networks at scale in eBay.
schedule.description: This talk will be a walk-through of how we integrate Netforce (eBay’s cloud network infrastructure automation service) with Neutron routed Network to support on-demand subnet provisioning and dynamic L2 segment binding for Hypervisors and Ironic Baremetal provisioning. It’s very challenging to drive network infrastructure changes through Neutron in such a large scale environment. We will discuss the architecture of Netforce, the extensions we made to Neutron, challenges faced to make Netforce work with different vendor switches, and also highlight the changes in Nova and Ironic to achieve the end-to-end data center automation.
schedule.social_description: Netforce: Extending neutron to support routed networks at scale in eBay.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Good walk-through for Netforce:eBay’s cloud network infrastructure automation service. How Netforce can be plugged in to Neutron and can also be used as a RESTful service to push ports, dynamic L2 segment binding for hypervisors and Ironic Baremetal with vrf support, and subnet configurations across thousands of network devices with drivers for different vendors.  Extensions needed in Neutron along with changes in Nova and Ironic to achieve the end-to-end data center automation.

schedule.title: The Open Open Open Cloud
schedule.description: The combination of OpenStack and OpenPower servers allows a truly open cloud from OpenStack at the top to the open chip architecture at the bottom. This presentation will describe how the marriage of open technologies such as OpenStack, OpenStack-Ansible, Ceph, ceph ansible, Ubuntu, and OpenPower servers allow you to set up a cloud stack that is truly open at every layer of the stack from software to server design.
schedule.social_description: Using OpenPower, OpenStack-Ansible, OpenStack, and Ceph to create a truly open cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The combination of OpenStack and OpenPower servers allows a truly open cloud from OpenStack at the top to the open chip architecture at the bottom. This presentation will describe how the marriage of open technologies such as OpenStack, OpenStack-Ansible, Ceph, ceph ansible, Ubuntu, and OpenPower servers allow you to set up a cloud stack that is truly open at every layer of the stack from software to server design.

schedule.title: Saving up to 98% time updating Firewall using Netlink (Including demo)
schedule.description:
Currently, FWaaS uses conntrack [1] to control network connections [2]. However, in a large scale system, which requires updating, adding or deleting up to thousands of firewall rules, it takes a long time to execute thousands of conntrack commands to delete conntrack entries. In a performance test, conntrack costs up to 458.40 seconds to apply 10.000 firewall rules [3]. That puts updating firewall – which directly related to system security into a significant threat.

We would like to introduce a new method to improve above problem: Using Netlink solution [4]. This patch saves time by developing a Netlink library to avoid running thousands of conntrack commands (which need to open a Python subprocess for each) from iptables_fwaas driver. The performance test [3] shows that our solution costs only 5.41 seconds (up to 98% time saving) to apply 10.000 firewall rules.

Our solution's been applied to FWaaS v1 in Ocata cycle, and it is beeing applied to FWaaS v2 and Neutron.

(Demo included)
schedule.social_description: Openstack FWaaS performance improvement by using Netlink solution.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
•  How FWaaS close network connection?
  • Current problem when FWaaS apply a large number of firewall rules
  • An approach to improve FWaaS performance

schedule.title: Organisation Culture : A catalyst for Openstack Community
schedule.description:
Openstack community development in traditional organization requires change in culture. Such changes are difficult to drive and nurture in organization which promotes open source as well as closed source. This paper talks about key motivators for organization to go for Open Source. Further once decided, how to create and promote such culture in organization. 

In NEC Technologies India we started journey in Openstack in 2012 in small way. Gradually we nurtured Openstack community by providing enablers at organization level. As a result, since last 4 years, many members started contributing in Openstack community at various levels and so far we contributed more than 300,000 LoC across 6-7 openstack release and many reviews in openstack community from India center. This paper will talk about experiences in driving such change in culture of organization and its impact in community. We will also talk about challeges faced by us in recruiting, training and retaining Openstack team.
schedule.social_description: Making organisation culture as catalyst for Openstack Development
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can learn about importance of organization culture for promoting open source community development. They can learn about process which can help in creating and nurturing openstack teams in mixed kind of organization.

schedule.title: DefCore to Interop and back again: OpenStack Programs and Certifications Explained
schedule.description: Openstack Interop (formerly DefCore) guidelines have been in place for 2 years now, and anyone wanting to use OpenStack logo must pass these guidelines. How are guidelines created and updated? How would your favorite project be added to it? How can you guarantee that your OpenStack deployment will comply with the new guidelines? In this session we will cover OpenStack Interop guidelines and components, as well as explain how they are created and updated.
schedule.social_description: OpenStack Interop guidelines and components explained.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how the guidelines are created and updated. They will also learn how new projects can be added to exsisting guidelines.

schedule.title: Being a Project Team Lead (PTL): The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly
schedule.description:
Interested in one day taking up the Project Team Lead (PTL) mantle for your project? This talk is for you!

As OpenStack has evolved, so has the PTL role. It used to be a largely technical role (it was actually called Project Technical Lead!), but has since evolved into a demanding role with various undocumented responsibilities. Hear from Matt (3 time Nova PTL), Armando (3 time Neutron PTL), and Steve (3 time Keystone PTL) about the good, the bad, and the ugly parts of the role. We will take you on a light-hearted ride through strategies and stories that can lead you and the team around you to success, as well as strategies that can lead to a painful crash and burn.

Spoiler: the good outweighs the bad and the ugly :)
schedule.social_description: Interested in becoming PTL for your project? Hear the good, the bad and the ugly!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees (folks interested in becoming future PTLs) will learn about the roles a PTL must fulfill, as well as strategies for dealing with the demands.

schedule.title: Kuberneterize your Baremetal Nodes in OpenStack!
schedule.description: I am pretty sure we just invented a new word: Kuberneterize. Everyone should start using that since Kubernetes is all the rage these days with it's incredible ability to automate the deployment, scaling and management of containerized applications.  We realize in the cloud-space that there's a need for containers and traditional cloud instances as well. Let us show you how you can enjoy the best of both worlds deploying containers on bare metal nodes using OpenStack's Project Ironic. We will dazzle you and amaze you with reasons why you might want to do this type of deployment.  We will then wow you with our amazing (not really) flowcharting skills as we talk about the architecture.  Lastly we will leave you in awe as we drop the mic and walk off stage.
schedule.social_description: Kubernertize your baremetal deployments using OpenStack and Project Ironic!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
You'll learn:

  • Why do this?
  • Why deploying to bare-metal is improtant for containers
  • How to architect this solution for the future
  • What kind of performance should you expect?
  • What to expect once you're actuall able to deploy to bare-metal
  • How to tweak Kubernetes for the best performance possible
  • Common pitfalls to bar-metal deployments
  • Common pitfalls to Kubernetes deployements

schedule.title: Baremetal to running Openstack on kubernetes in 2 mins
schedule.description:
There are currently many parallel efforts to deploy and run Openstack as containerized services on top of Kubernetes. Deploying and configuring a Kubernetes Cluster in its own is a challenge, let alone doing it on-premise. In this talk we will walk you through the steps to create a service that will interoperate with your network boot environment to produce and render configurations, metadata and images to network boot a Kubernetes cluster on baremetal and run Openstack services on top of it.

We will also highlight the different ways available to bootstrap a Kubernetes cluster as well as some lessons learned and best practices to deploy Kubernetes on Baremetal.
schedule.social_description: Network booting your baremetal servers to run Openstack on Kubernetes cluster.

schedule.title: Syntribos - Automated API Security Kung fu for OpenStack
schedule.description: With each release of OpenStack, the need for automated security scanners are ever-increasing. The pace of upstream development of OpenStack mandates the need for a tool that is highly configurable and quickly deployable. This talk is on Syntribos, which is an automated API security testing tool created and supported by the OpenStack Security Project. Syntribos aims to automatically detect common security defects such as SQL injection, XXE injection, authentication & authorization defects, buffer overflow etc. and possible new defects by automated fuzzing. With release of the latest version, the tool has been augmented with a set of features focussing on new tests, ease of automation, minimal configuration efforts and usability. During the talk, we would like to discuss about API security in the RESTful world, emphasize on the reasons for the existence of a tool like Syntribos, its implementation and on automated scans against OpenStack APIs.
schedule.social_description: Educate developers on API security and role of Syntribos in making APIs secure.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees would get informed about API security in the RESTful world and how to automatically identify possible security vulnerabilities before the application is being deployed to the wild.

schedule.title: Project Update - OpenStackClient
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of OpenStackClient and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements OpenStackClient plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the OpenStackClient PTL Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Making Monasca monitor more – extending Monasca's data gathering and reporting capabilities
schedule.description:
Monasca is a powerful and flexible monitoring-as-a-service solution. These capabilities can be extended even further through the use of several powerful mechanisms:

1.  Adding new notification methods so that Monasca can inform other monitoring systems of alarms it raises
2.  Developing agent plugins to extend the effective reach of Monasca into more hardware and software systems to generate richer measurement data
3.  Allowing third-party access to Monasca APIs to fully integrate with external systems

The purpose of this talk is to cover how these techniques can be used both to add new features and capabilities to Monasca, and to help customize Monasca to the needs of individual customers.
schedule.social_description: Integrate cloud monitoring into an existing alarm and performance management system.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: During this talk we'll show how easy is to extend monasca to check systems and how it can be integrated with others systems

schedule.title: Use Kolla for Better Life: A real case study for Kolla
schedule.description: Kolla provides containers and deployment tools for operating OpenStack clouds. This topic includes a real Kolla case study from the Intel and 99cloud's collaboration to deploy Kolla in a production environment. We would like to show the benefits from Kolla as a container based solution to compare with the traditional way to deploy and run OpenStack services. There are many advantages from Kolla including ease to maintain, immutable environment, and quickly upgrade the version of OpenStack. But we still would like to highlight the pain points we experienced and what the solutions or alternatives we implemented to solve or avoid those issues. In addition to the latest Kolla release, there are many new features release as well as many improvements that not only target for bug fixing but also bring better integration with other OpenStack services. Thru this real case study, you can understand more from Kolla and also know why Kolla can bring the life of dev-ops easier and better.
schedule.social_description: This is a real use case for OpenStack Kolla in the production environment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. The introduction of OpenStack Kolla
  2. An Use Case in production environment for Kolla
  3. Our pain points/experience you should avoid when using Kolla
  4. Future Plan in Kolla

schedule.title: OSIC Exposed (again) - Making our cluster more user- (and operator-) friendly
schedule.description: While some clusters remain static from deployment to retirement, most evolve through a process of hardware and software upgrades.  At the OpenStack Innovation Center, our clusters see monthly changes by design as we onboard and offboard bare metal installations from around the community.  In this session we will discuss what we have learned over the past eighteen months of supporting a diverse set of use cases, and how we've evolved our platform and processes in an effort to more efficiently incorporate new requirements. Attend this session to learn how OSIC is increasing turnover speed in the cluster, and to see how you can use the OSIC cluster as a proving ground for your next project.
schedule.social_description: A clean slate every month - how OSIC supports rapid turnover for #openstack community projects.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attend this session to learn how OSIC is increasing turnover speed in the cluster, and to see how you can use the OSIC cluster as a proving ground for your next project.  We'll give details about how new tools, configurations, and processes have allowed us to move effectively onboard and offboard cluster participants from the OpenStack community.

schedule.title: You Have Hundreds of Clouds Deployed, Now What, Genius?
schedule.description: You have hundreds of clouds deployed or in various states of being deployed, now what?  This is a conundrum AT&T has been wrestling with for the last couple of years, a challenge which produced enough heroic tales to fill a legendary tome of engineering.  In this talk, we will focus on the problems of designing, deploying and operating a continuously growing number of Openstack clouds and our approach to "automate the hell out of it".
schedule.social_description: You have hundreds of clouds deployed or in various states of being deployed, now what?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Understanding of AT&T's experience and approach to automating at massive scale.  You will learn how we automate everything from intial design to the baremetal nitty gritty deployment, plus automation for tenant management.  Learn from our trials and tribulations and how we went from a few data center deployments to clouds everywhere.  Or you can see how far you get doing it all manually.

schedule.title: Neutron Port binding and impact of unbound ports on DVR Routers with FloatingIP
schedule.description:
The Distributed Virtual Routers ("DVR") implementation in Neutron heavily depends on Neutron port binding to identify the DVR service virtual ports to effectively configure routers on host and to route traffic both on East-West and North-South.

Some of the advanced features such as Allowed_address_Pairs that are extensively used in the case of VRRP scenarios have direct impact on the distributed nature of the ports that are bound/unbound with Floating IPs.

This session will focus on the basics of Port binding with DVR routers and design considerations for use of unbound Allowed_Address_Pair ports with respect to the DVR routers to achieve the respective use cases (especially VRRP applications)

This session will also target the relationship between the FIP and the bound/unbound ports and the placement of the FloatingIP functionality on the host nodes based on the bound/unbound nature of the associated ports.
schedule.social_description: Discuss the use of unbound Allowed_Address_Pair ports with respect to the DVR routers.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees would expect to know the port-binding details in Distributed Virtual Router.

How port-binding determines the scheduling logic for the instances that are connected to the Distributed Virtual Routers network.

How unbound ports that are inactive are handled today.

How unbound ports that are active and distributed but associated with FloatingIP will be handled in Octavia/Pike.

schedule.title: Towards a Platform for Science - Initial Lessons from the Science Accelerator Platform at LBL
schedule.description:
Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory is developing an OpenStack environment to support improved Research Data Management practices as well as support improved development of tools, and collaboration by our global scientific community of partners.  The goal for early development it to get capabilities into the hands of our science partners early so we can identify needs and build a brand. The target is to unveil the ScAP prototype at LabTech 2017, using this as a forcing function for outreach and progress.

This talk will focus on lessons learned from initial development and test of ScAP.  As new partners to the OpenStack community, I will discuss what we've learned, how what we are learning has shaped longer term plans, and how we see the role of OpenStack as part of US National Laboratory scientific infrastructure.
schedule.social_description: Scientific use of OpenStack and lessons learned for research data management.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Talk provides an overview of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory is designing and deploying OpenStack to support a global science user base.  The presentation will offer some lessons learned as well as input to the community on future possible use cases and capabilities.  Also discussed, are some activities underway to support multi-Laboratory collaboration on data management, applications, and other uses for OpenStack capabilities.

schedule.title: Keystone and SAML2 for multitenant environments - two concepts get together
schedule.description:
Keystone as OpenStack’ s identity service provides a lot of functionality and extensibility to enable an extensive Identity and Access management (IAM) service including identity federation. Support for identity federation (mostly based on SAML2 protocol) is an increasing demand for public cloud service providers. This requires the extension of keystone to enable scalable multi tenant support.

In this presentation you will learn about the concepts/use cases of identity federation and join a journey into the extended keystone and SAML2 implementation at Deutsche Telekoms OpenStack based public cloud implementation Open Telekom Cloud.

This presentation will cover a number of interesting topics including:

  • IAM front ends
  • Cached proxy to accelerate IAM/keystone core services
  • Keystone extensions:
    • Identity Federation at domain/tenant level and multiple Identity Provider (IdP) support
    • Identity Federation through console or API
    • support of SAML2 metadata and token information on API
schedule.social_description: OpenStacks's keystone is extended to support scalable multitenant identity federation based on SAML2
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees of this presentation will learn how keystone can be used and extended to support a modern IAM service suitable for a multitenant public cloud. This includes domain/tenant level support for identity federation based on the SAML2 protocol.

schedule.title: Hyper Cool Infrastructure
schedule.description:
While HCI has been a tech buzz-word for at least a decade, the implementation details of hyper-converged infrastructure based systems and clusters are left up to an architect's imagination and can vary widely based on hardware inputs, high availability needs and integrated management components.

At Red Hat, we've been focusing on HCI for two distinct use cases:  1) Red Hat Virtualization with Gluster storage and 2) OpenStack Platform with Ceph storage.

But what if we combined these two HCI use cases and morphed them into a unique hybrid cloud offering consisting of six standalone x86_64 physical systems offering the best-of-breed opensource virtualization, cloud computing, software defined storage, and software defined networking - all with ease of automation, management and performance in mind!?

This talk will cover the architecture considerations, implementation details, and benefits of such a "Hyper Cool Infrastructure".
schedule.social_description: "Hyper Cool Infra" - a hybrid virt + cloud solution for use as your branch office, POC, or sandbox.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The hyper-coverged infrstructure (HCI) solution does not have to be limited to just "virtualization infra" or just "cloud infra".  When we combine the two and add a few great automation and management components we get the best of both worlds.

A detailed "Hyper Cool Infra" solution architecture will be presented.  The minimum hardware, networking, and storage requirements will be discussed.

Automation and management components will be identified with links to automation code.

The pros/cons of the solution will be discussed, especially as it relates to performance managment, component placement and isolation.

schedule.title: Upstream Contribution – Give Up or Double Down?
schedule.description:
Ever since I’ve been involved with OpenStack people have been complaining that upstream is hard. The number one complaint is that it takes forever to get your patches merged. I thought I’d take a look at some data and attempt to visualize it. Could we learn anything? Perhaps banging our heads against some graphs could allow us to answer questions such as:

  • How long does it take to merge patches in a given project over time? Looking back, did governance changes affect anything?
  • Is there a correlation between the size of a patch and the length of time it takes to merge it? (Spoiler: The answer is… Kind of)
  • Looking at an author: Does the time to merge patches trend down over time?
  • Looking at the average length of time it takes to merge patches per author, how does it look like when we graph it as a function of the author’s number of patches? Reviews? Emails? Bug reports? Blueprints implemented? Do people that have authored more work get it merged quicker than the rest of us?
schedule.social_description: How to get your code merged quicker? Let's use statistics and see what we can learn!

schedule.title: The Amazon Effect on Open Source Cloud Business Models
schedule.description: In order for open source to continue to thrive, there needs to be some ability for the creators to profit from their projects - which is where the freemium model stands right now. However, it seems we are quickly seeing the “Amazon Effect” take hold. In essence, a huge enterprise finds an open source project it likes, commits a little code, and then packages and sells it as a their service. How will open source survive in the long run if only the big players benefit from the open source community’s hard work?
schedule.social_description: The Amazon Effect on Open Source Cloud Business Models
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will hear experts talk about the effect Amazon is having on the open source market and how we can work together to make open source better and prevent this trend from continuing.

schedule.title: Going Beyond Siri: Applying Machine Learning to Network Automation
schedule.description:
Global organizations are adopting programmable networks as a first step towards network automation, but this can be advanced more quickly with machine learning.

 

Machine learning applications span a wide variety of use cases, including perceptual tasks such as image search, object and scene recognition and captioning; voice and natural language recognition and generation; self-driving cars and automated assistants such as Siri; as well as various engineering, financial, medical, and scientific applications.

 

The recent progress of machine learning and deep learning in particular has been nothing short of spectacular. It’s a new area for networking, but one that is growing incredibly fast.


This presentation will provide insight into the intersection of machine learning, networking and DevOps as well as an overview of recent advances in machine learning with an eye toward network applications and next-generation network automation.
schedule.social_description: Dive into Machine Learning, networking and DevOps.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This presentation will provide insight into the intersection of machine learning, networking and DevOps as well as an overview of recent advances in machine learning with an eye toward network applications and next-generation network automation.

schedule.title: Project Update - QA
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of QA and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements QA plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the QA PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: What shall we do with Tacker in NFV orchestration
schedule.description:
China Mobile have built public cloud using openstack. We have introduced SDN and NFV technology to implement VPC、vFW、vLB、VPC. But there are a lot of things to do with the management of SDN and NFV, such as how to decouple SDN and NFV? How to manage open source and deferent vendors’ VNF? In the past, we have been using neutron to manage both SDN and NFV. Perhaps using tacker to manage NFV can solve these problems.

   China Mobile have built the world's largest 4G communication network, with more than 800 million users. Now 5G and NFV have been becoming the trend of development, which will be commercially available in 2020. NFV management and orchestration will be core element of the next generation network manage system. Maybe tacker will succeed in NFV field of the next generation communication network.
schedule.social_description: China Mobile's  problems and solutions in NFV management. Tacker will be introduced.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• The SDN&NFV solution of China Mobile’s public cloud
  • The NFV management difficulty and problem in cloud-computing
  • The SDN&NFV manage system architecture after using tacker as NFV manager
  • The plan of introducing tacker of China Mobile

schedule.title: Strategic distributed and multisite OpenStack for business continuity and scalability use cases
schedule.description:
CIO and other executive level business leaders are constantly challenged to provide alway-on solutions to their customers at the highest levels of performance, scale and availability. As OpenStack continues to mature and gain credibility for use in the production datacenter, these same leaders who have chosen or who are considering OpenStack as a trusted infrastructure are now facing the next wave of strategic decisions around business-critical topics such as disaster recovery, scalability, compliance and overall cost of ownership. Can they provide the same service level agreements, regulatory compliance, and cost savings for the new systems and applications they entrust to OpenStack that they provide on other traditional platforms?

In this interactive session, we will discuss personas and user stories that need answers to these questions. We'll also explore other questions that need to be considered when promoting OpenStack for critical systems and applications.
schedule.social_description: Building a strategy for business continuity and scale using distributed OpenStack deployments.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this interactive session, we will identify personas, user stories and use cases that need to be considered when promoting OpenStack for business-critical systems and applications. Attendees will learn about the current multi-site deployment capabilities in Ocata and how they apply to Disaster Recovery and Scale. We will present some basic and targeted reference architectures to help drive an interactive discussion and attendee participation. We will also look ahead to Pike and beyond to explore some of the key enabling upstream projects and the gaps that need to be addressed and filled for a complete distributed OpenStack solution to be realized in these critical operational areas.

schedule.title: Optimized Workload Placement Using A new Batch Scheduling Algorithm
schedule.description: VNFs usually have more placement constrains than general cloud applications. Although NFV workload requests reach operator as a batch, NOVA scheduler only works on a first come first serve basis. This generally results in sub-optimal placement and stranding resource usage. In this talk, we will present a new offline placement algorithm. The tool dynamically collects resource usage of the cloud and takes the batch workload requests as inputs. All the special requests of each VNF, such as affinity, anit-affinity, NUMA, CPU, SR-IOV, memory and so on, will be used as constrains. Then the tool generate an optimized placement plan for cloud operators using Genetic Algorithm. In the end of presentation, we also compare the new algorithm with different heuristic approaches.
schedule.social_description: Optimized Workload Placement Using A new Batch Scheduling Algorithm

schedule.title: Accelerating OpenStack Swift with RDMA for Building Efficient HPC Clouds
schedule.description: OpenStack Swift is an object storage service for cloud applications. Although Swift has become extremely popular recently, its proxy server based design limits the overall throughput and scalability of the cluster. Swift is based on the traditional TCP/IP sockets-based communication which has known performance issues such as context-switch and buffer copies.  Modern high-performance interconnects such as InfiniBand and RoCE offer advanced features such as RDMA and provide high bandwidth and low latency communication.  In this talk, we will present two new designs to improve the performance and scalability of Swift. We propose changes to the Swift architecture and high-performance implementations of network communication and I/O modules based on RDMA to provide the fastest possible object transfer. Besides, we use efficient hashing algorithms to accelerate object verification in Swift.  Evaluations reveal up to 2x and 7.3x performance improvement with our two proposed designs.
schedule.social_description: Swift-X; Accelerating OpenStack Swift with RDMA for Building Efficient HPC Clouds
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees can learn from following aspects:

a. What are the performance characteristics and bottlenecks of the current Swift design?

b. How can high-performance and scalable RDMA-based communication schemes be designed to reduce the network communication time for Swift operations and further improve overall Swift performance?

c. In addition to communication, what else can be done to accelerate Swift performance and scalability further? For example, how to improve the designs of I/O and computation in Swift?

schedule.title: Contributing to OpenStack: Doing the Dirty Jobs
schedule.description:
Sure, we understand that you have a great idea for a new feature in OpenStack, one that will change the world and bring you fame and glory. But what your favorite service team really needs is someone to do the Dirty Jobs. These are the needed tasks that don't have much glamor, dutifully performed by the unsung heroes and greatly appreciated by everyone. We're talking about writing tests for features that aren't being covered in Tempest or Functional Tests. Reviewing large, complex patches. Manually testing new features to verify that they actually work. Checking to see if documentation is up to date and fixing what isn't current. Triaging bugs. Attending cross project meetings for QA, the API working group, or Oslo.

If you'd like to make great contributions, fill in areas that are neglected, and be valued by your team, consider doing one of the Dirty Jobs!
schedule.social_description: If you'd like to make great contributions and be valued by your team, do one of the Dirty Jobs!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn how to identify areas where they can contribute to OpenStack. An emphasis will be given for areas that are neglected but highly needed, with specific advice applicable to these valued tasks. Advice will be offered on finding roles within a service team to contribute on a regular basis.

Examples and anecdotes will be given, as well as advice and mentoring. Q and A will follow the presentation.

schedule.title: Practical case of GUI and Infrastructure development for public cloud service utilizing Horizon
schedule.description:
NTT Communications is now providing public cloud service "Enterprise Cloud 2.0" since Mar 2016 using OpenStack as main component of this service.
We have some original components that do not exist in OpenStack, but the components are also providing API basically has compatible with similar services of OpenStack.

In this service, my team's development part is user interface part.
Main component is GUI application, and also providing CLI, SDK for this service.

At the begining of this project, we do not have enough time for GUI development but utllizing Horizon's design consept helped us much to complete this development in a short time.

We are also focusing on efficiency of deployment of Horizon.
We are utilizing Docker as infrastructure of Horizon to simplify release and rollback procedure.

In this presentation, we will explain the design of both web application(Horizon) and infrastructure with practical case on public clouds from over 1 year experience in production.
schedule.social_description: Practical case of GUI and Infrastructure development for public cloud service utilizing Horizon
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Horizon is an extremely convenient framework to realize high efficient web application development.
Also we could utilize OpenStack python clients and sdk, cli as a main part of user interface.

However, we need to deploy these application to multiple location in the world, we had to cleared many problems that can not find only by application development layer.

I hope I can help similar cloud service developpers by introducing how we development application and infrastructure layers.

schedule.title: Per API Role Based Access Control
schedule.description:
To do things at cloud scale, you need to design for cloud scale.  The access control mechanism in Keystone was built with large scale in mind, but earlier implementations made it hard or implossible to use.  We're working to fix that.

Current work in Keystone is moving to an  Role Based Access Control (RBAC) check based on the URL of the resource requested.  This will allow such sought after features as:

1. A read only role for audit purposes

2. Delegation of a single API to a service user

3. Discover what role is required to perform an action

4. Split a role into smaller roles

This talk is an over view of the mechanism, the method, and the madness of RBAC in OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: Role Based Access Control at cloud scale.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How to create a new role,
  • how to integrate that new role into an OpenStack deployement
  • How to link the Role to an API
  • How to set up default access for new Services

schedule.title: Common networking operations across Kubernetes and OpenStack​ with Calico
schedule.description:
Join this session to discover how you can use a common, fully Open Source networking layer across both OpenStack and Kubernetes to deliver robust and scalable networkng to your containers and VMs.

Developers love the flexibility and speed of development and operations that containers promise.Yet as many discover as they push into production; real live implementations require solid and scaleable underlying infrastructure, especially networking. In this session we will show how Calico with its pure layer 3 approach to software defined networking offers a simple solution that spans both OpenStack and Kubernetes helping you manage your networking in a consist way.
schedule.social_description: Networking Containers, Kubernetes and OpenStack together with Calico, a fully opensource L3 SDN
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learnm how to use a single Open Source SDN to manage the networks for your VMs and containers.

schedule.title: Managing lifecycle of micro-services - The what, why and how
schedule.description:
As more organizations transition from a monolith to a more micro-services architecture, organizations are finding increasing challenges around governance and lifecycle management of micro-services. For ex, how often have you (developer, ops) asked one or more of the following questions?

1. What does it take to create & manage a new micro-service? (Governance)
2. How do we identify micro-services canonically across infrastructure/platform services? (Identity)
3. How do we allocate resources for micro-services? (Resource provisioning)
4. What does it take to operate a micro-service? (Deploy Orchestration, Monitoring)
5. How do we measure resource utilization and cost of operating a micro-service?

I will share how we addressed these problems at companies like Twitter & Pinterest. I'll share details on systems we built (ex, Service Directory & Metadata Manager, Identity Manager, Resource Manager and Metering & Chargeback) that simplified create, manage, deploy & operate micro-services.
schedule.social_description: Manage the lifecycle of micro-services at scale - Identity, Resource Management, Meter & Chargeback
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Here are few things:

1. What is micro-services oriented architecture? What are the pros/cons when moving from a monolith to micro-services? What is the lifecycle of a micro-service?
2. In this talk, I intend to describe challenges that accompany during a migration/adoption of micro-services. For example, When there is a proliferation of micro-services in an organization, it becomes difficult to track who owns what services and its relevant metadata. Once of the first things to solve is build a service directory.
3. How to enable teams to move faster when building & launching services? For example, It doesn't make sense for every developer to provision & manage public/private cloud resources by themselves. Abstracting resource provisioning enables governance & clear accountability on who owns what leading to better cost & utilization efficiency.
4. How to incentivize teams to utilize resources effectively & make cost-conscious design decisions? Ex, Detailed Metering & Chargeback reporting.
5. How to implement a service lifecycle manager?

schedule.title: How to Manage Multi-location/Multi-component Cloud-Services : Take Control of Your Alerts!
schedule.description:
Do you have difficulties troubleshooting complex systems with numerous alerts?
This presentation is for you.

Our company, NTT Communications, provides public/hosted private cloud service "Enterprise Cloud" with OpenStack.
Our cloud service spans across multiple Data Centers all over the world, consisting of tens of thousands of physical/virtual machines(network-devices, servers and storage) and external service connections such as VPN and Other-Cloud services.

We will share our operational know-how gathered from our large-scale multi-location/multi-component cloud service.

This presentation covers the following using Network Management System and Runbook Automation tools (Zabicom, TeMIP and HPOO).

Excluding maintenance-related alerts by network configuration analysis.
Analysis of root cause by correlation of relevant alerts.
Fix issues automatically using pre-defined workflow.
We avoid complex log analysis and focus on alert relevance to obtain maximum benefit with minimal effort.
schedule.social_description: We will share operational tips for large-scale cloud services--especially operational automation.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about following things.

  • Operational know-how of our OpenStack-based cloud service in production with multi-location/multi-components including physical layer.(9 Data Centers all over the world and tens of thousands of physical/virtual machines including network-devices/servers/storage.)
  • Challenges we have faced in the operation of a multi-component cloud environment(especially in root cause analysis).
  • Monitoring and automation tools for troubleshooting.
  • Use-cases, root cause analysis and troubleshooting automation.

schedule.title: Lessons learned from running 1000 application deployments a day on OpenStack at Paddy Power Betfair
schedule.description: At Paddy Power Betfair we started our OpenStack jouney in late 2015. In 2017, we now run over 100 micro-service customer facing applications on OpenStack in production, and have migrated 25% of our estate onto OpenStack so far. The number of applications we run is growing daily as we migrate all our apps onto OpenStack, with the target end state of 1300 KVM compute nodes, split over 2 datacenters, which will make up 100,000 cores and 2.08 petabytpes of storage. We run a continuous delivery self-service model against our OpenStack API's, where we do over 1000 deployments a day to test and production environments using Ansible -- this deployment figure is growing each day. Running OpenStack at such a scale has challenges which need to be addressed as the platform is scaled out. In this session we will walk the audience through our OpenStack reference architecture and share info on the configurations and services we had to change to solve each problem we encountered.
schedule.social_description: Lessons from PPB building their OpenStack cloud to doing 1000 application deployments a day in 2017
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this session we will share what worked and what didn't openly and our future plans for the platform and how it differs from our initial day 1 architecture so other users can learn from our experiences as they tackle similar projects. We will focus on architecture design considerations for onboarding stateless and stateful applications and which OpenStack projects we decided to use to tackle each use case which was used to form design patterns to standardise the way we deploy applications using OpenStack. Attendees will learn about a real life reference architecture and a blue print reference architecture that has been proven to work at huge scale. We will share a timeline of problems we encountered from 2015 to 2017 so they can avoid these gotchas when they scale OpenStack, which will save them huge amounts of time. They will learn how the architectural design of OpenStack is integral for supporting a 24/7 business and different application patterns and what OpenStack services they can use to allow all their applications to be deployed onto OpenStack.

schedule.title: NFV performance test  result analysis  in ChinaMobile NovoNet Project
schedule.description:
In this speech, we will introduce the network performance test of NovoNet, which is the core project of China Mobile's NFV strategy. NovoNet architect is a three-layer decoupling architecture based on ETSI.The focus of this speech to share some performance testing conclusions and reflections for cloud platform.
1, Introduces the performance test scenarios, describe a variety of common performance acceleration technology scenarios, including CPU binding / SRIOV / DPDK / NUMA and so on.
2，Describes the experimental test environment, including network architecture and various testing tools.
3, Introduce the test results, summarize the test data of multiple cloud platforms and compare and analyze the test scenarios, and give the comparative analysis of the performances of various performance acceleration technologies, include bandwidth, delay, jitter and other dimensions.
4. Summarize and analyze the maturity, advantages and disadvantages of various performance acceleration technologies.
schedule.social_description: Introduce the network performance test of China Mobile's NFV project NovoNet
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The audience will learn some test senarios for NFV application, and some test result analysis, understand the performance of NFV acceleration technology and the actual test result, through comparative analysis to understand the rate of performance enhancement and promotion of various performance acceleration technology, and the current maturity of various technologies. We hope that the audience can understand that different VNF performance requirements are different, the actual design of the cloud platform needs to consider the specific needs of VNF business.

schedule.title: Real Time KVM with DPDK - HOWTO and Results
schedule.description:
With every new release of OpenStack you find more interoperable options to help improve performance.  This session will focus on how OpenStack has advanced in the spaces of real time kernel, DPDK, and OPNFV certified hardware enabling the attendee to see where the industry is at and where is it going.

We will cover what's needed at the HW (BIOS/UEFI) and SW layers to enabled then deploy this type of solutions.
schedule.social_description: HOWTO Realtime & DPDK
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendee will leave this session with a solid understanding how what's needed to start deploying clouds with RT-KVM and DPDK along with things to consider before starting the journey.

schedule.title: Project Update - Rally
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Rally and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Rally plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Rally PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Horizontal Scaling 101: A Hands-On Workshop with Heat & Ceilometer
schedule.description: Although Autoscaling has certainly been one of the buzziest buzzwords, what's the real magic that makes it all work?  Join us as we setup OpenStack autoscaling with the help of the Heat and Ceilometer services.  This workshop provides an easy-to-understand introduction to autoscaling in OpenStack by not only presenting a fun look at the history of the feature, but a step-by-step walkthrough on how to setup your very own autoscaling application!  Learn how to prepare your application for world-wide popularity as demand begins to spike and decrease your capacity during those less busy times!
schedule.social_description: Join us as we create Heat autoscaling groups, policies, and alarms!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will first learn about the history of autoscaling and the origin of the Heat and Ceilometer projects.  A comprehensive review of Heat and Ceilometer infrastructure will show attendees how the projects fit into the overall OpenStack ecosystem.  Each participant will then gain hands-on Heat experience by accessing a live OpenStack environment where they will learn how to create autoscaling groups, policies, and alarms.  They will finally deploy their application, replicate resource usage to trigger the creation of additional instances, and automatically downscale when resources become free!  By the end of this workshop, participants will walk away with the confidence to setup autoscaling in their organization's OpenStack environment!

schedule.title: The case of the missing packet
schedule.description:
A talk about how to troubleshoot OpenStack neutron with ML2/Openvswitch.
Experiences are taken from running a public cloud built on OpenStack for several years.
A number of issues encountered in real life will be discussed starting with a description of the issue followed by the process of identifying the problem and how it was fixed. Some general advice on troubleshooting will also be provided as well as examples of tools that can and should be used.
schedule.social_description: A talk about how to troubleshoot OpenStack neutron with ML2/Openvswitch.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Including but not limited to:

* General information on sources of information
* Making VPNaaS work
* Intermittently lost network connectivity when L3 HA enabled
* Packets into infinity - loops that make you dizzy.
* Sorting out the bad apples - misbehaving customers.
* Repopulating - one namespace at a time.
* The MuTUal agreement - more than you want to know about MTUs.
* Finding issues before the customer does.

schedule.title: Performance and Scale Analysis of OpenStack using Browbeat
schedule.description:
Browbeat is an Open Source framework focused on performance and scale testing of a deployed OpenStack cloud.  It can provide the following benefits to operators, developers and businesses running OpenStack.

  • Orchestrate workloads for performance and scale testing.
  • Make run-to-run, cloud-to-cloud and build-to-build comparisons by sending test results bundled with metadata about the cloud to Elasticsearch and visualized via Kibana.
  • Automate deployment of common collection and data analysis tools.
  • Provide performance data and metrics in common tools like Grafana and Kibana

In this talk you will hear an overvierw of Browbeat and Performance results from Browbeat.  Based on the performance work over the last cycle and previous cycles, we will share best practices for performance and scale of OpenStack. We will also share how our workflow of Test->Analyze->Tune using Browbeat can help you get the most out of your cloud.
schedule.social_description: Performance Analysis of OpenStack using Browbeat: Overview of Browbeat and Performance Results
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should be able to learn what Browbeat is and what it does from a high level.
