Performance and scale results covering a variety of OpenStack services like Nova, Neutron, Telemetry, Keystone etc obtained from Browbeat will be discussed. Based on these results some best practices for optimum performance and maximum scale of your cloud will be shared. This session is going to help anyone who wants to get the most of their existing OpenStack cloud.

schedule.title: Advanced Use Cases for Root Cause Analysis
schedule.description:
Vitrage is the official OpenStack project dedicated to root cause analysis (RCA) and deduced insights into the behavior of the Cloud. With the help of a graphical model representing the different relationships between system entities, and a friendly UI, Vitrage perfectly organizes, analyzes and visualizes a holistic view of the system.

Fault management in cloud systems is complex. With a mix of virtual & physical resources interacting, problems at one layer can have ripple effects throughout the system, especially when applications can be widely distributed over different physical entities. Achieving clarity of such connections is critical for high-performance systems, such as in NFV

In this session, we will present advanced RCA abilities of Vitrage that tackle real-world problems. With in-depth modeling of the way the virtual and physical entities interact, we will demonstrate how Vitrage traces the impact of problems on the physical layer on virtual machines and applications.
schedule.social_description: Vitrage advanced RCA tackles problems by tracing interactions between virtual and physical
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Fault management in cloud systems is complex. With a mix of virtual & physical resources interacting, problems at one layer can have ripple effects throughout the system. This is extremely apparent when trying to connect low-level events, such as NIC failures, with high-level events, such as application problems, especially when applications can be widely distributed over different physical entities. Achieving clarity of such connections is critical for high-performance systems, such as in NFV.

Participants will gain an understanding of how Vitrage, the OpenStack root cause analysis engine, uses its latest data sources to give insights into application-level faults as well as in-depth hardware problems. We will demonstrate how Vitrage provides a clear and holistic view of the system, from physical infrastructure to virtual application, which can then be used to drive application management policy.

schedule.title: Need for Speed - using DPDK and SR-IOV
schedule.description:
In this talk we will be presenting a new feature that can be introduced in OpenStack by integration of DPDK PMD drivers using SR-IOV for NFV workloads. The VMs will be attached to hostdev devices which will increase the throughput for the NFV applications and help get as close to wire-line speed as possible for virtual machines. This implementation provides better performance, PMD accesses the RX and TX descriptors directly without any interrupts. With this set of features operator could achieve a boost to the networking performance and can leverage the Layer 2 switch on NIC for virtual machine traffic. The operator can configure advanced features for the VFs on supported NICs like VLAN filtering, mac spoofing, multicast mode, QinQ, insert tag, strip tag etc.

This proposed solution will allow operators to configure VFs at a more granular level with all the features available on cards and provide more flexibility to the NFV users.
schedule.social_description: In this presentation we will show how to improve the performance of OpenStack with SR-IOV and DPDK.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. Attendees will learn the networking performance benefits of integrating DPDK with SR-IOV.

2. Attendees will learn how to use the power of advanced networking features provided by the NIC they may already be using in OpenStack.

3. Attendees will learn about the flexibility users can gain when operators can configure virtual functions at such a granular level.

schedule.title: Nova Scheduler: Optimizing, Configuring and Deploying NFV VNF's on OpenStack
schedule.description:
A deep technical discussion on how to best leverage Nova scheduler to configure and deploy applications for NFV.  Virtual Network Functions (VNF’s) typically have critical performance targets and need to predictability get the performance they expect every time they are launched.  The scheduler is a complex beast and knowing how to best leverage its wonderful capabilities to maximize performance will be demonstrated.  We will compare performance with and without leveraging the scheduler parameters that are available and highlight the delta.

Providing predictable access to resources for VNFs is a critical part of a successful NFV deployment and we will show you how to accomplish this important goal.
schedule.social_description: Nova Scheduler: Optimizing, Configuring and Deploying NFV VNF's on OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How to best configure and deploy an app on an openstack cloud to ensure the best possible performance

schedule.title: Scaling Nova: How CellsV2 affects your deployment
schedule.description:
Early in Nova development, the "cells" functionality was added to the
project, allowing operators to shard their deployments to help with
scaling the database and message queue, as well as segregate failure
domains and help eliminate single points of failure. While useful (and
used by some of the largest clouds), this initial implementation had
many drawbacks, missing features, lack of testing and brought a lot of
complexity and duplicated code paths.

Recently the Nova project has been working on "cells version 2", a
different approach to solve the same problem, integrated into the main
code from the beginning, and simpler to understand and deploy. Unlike
version 1, everyone is running version 2 code all the time, even if
they have not sharded their deployment. Changes in Ocata bring us
closer to being able to use the new implementation for production
deployments, and they introduce a number of changes that every
operator needs to understand.
schedule.social_description: An overview of the architecture and changes in Nova's CellsV2 as of Ocata
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This talk will go over the design, approach, and cover what operators
need to know about the technology, regardless of whether they're
deploying a small single-cell system or a large multi-cell cloud.

Attendees should expect to learn about the architecture and design of Nova's CellsV2 architecture, how it affects all clouds big and small, as well as some information about how we got here, status as of Ocata, and outlook for the future.

schedule.title: Ambassador Community Report
schedule.description:
Meet with the ambassadors on this session where they will introduce the improvements of the last half year and share their feelings and experience about the community.

If you are a user group organizer you must be there, and feel free to share your thoughts and feelings with us!

OpenStack Ambassadors connect the user groups to the Foundation. They help initialize the groups and guide them to grow.

Ambassadors launch some actions during the last release cycle:
- New ambassadors introduction
- OpenStack community report
- Status update on official groups
- What is the size of the community
- Global and regional trends
- Introduce new groups
- Updates on speaker bureau
- Recommended practices for starting and running communities
- Process
- Updates on user groups since Barcelona
- Groups portal
- Overview
- Results
- Welcome pack and OpenStack shop
- Q&A
schedule.social_description: Meet with the OpenStack Foundation Ambassadors on this community session.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will discover how to grow communities and get help from the OpenStack Foundation.

schedule.title: Project Update - Sahara
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Sahara and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Sahara plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

 

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Sahara PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: What does OpenStack bring to a containers world ?
schedule.description:
The success of the container technologies resides in their capacity to isolate application developers from the base infrastructure. It is therefore easy to fall in the trap of considering that OpenStack, as an infrastructure provider, is not relevant in a containers world. However, container technologies still require someone to provide flexible infrastructure for that abstraction layer to live on.

OpenStack provides programmable infrastructure (bare metal, VMs, container orchestration engines, networking or storage services) that can then be used by application developers. In this talk, we'll explore how complementary Openstack is to container technologies like Docker or Kubernetes, and how they answer orthogonal questions in a harmonious way. We'll expose what key issue (and which stakeholders) each solution actually answers to, then dive into examples of where that complementarity already shows: Kuryr, hyper.sh, OpenStack itself using Kubernetes for its own deployment...
schedule.social_description: Learn what makes OpenStack still relevant (or even necessary) in a containers age.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Container technologies are transforming our industry, and a lot of people erroneously consider them as a replacement for OpenStack. While you can certainly use container technologies without OpenStack, they are complementary solutions and there is a lot to gain by using them together. This talk dives into this complementarity and should help dissipate the replacement myth.

schedule.title: OpenStack Acceleration Service - Introduction of Cyborg Project
schedule.description:
Following a great session at Barcelona Summit, we created a new project called Cyborg, which aims to provide a management framework for dedicated devices (e.g. FPGA, GPU, NVMe SSD) as well as various accelerators (e.g iNIC, ip-sec card, dpdk) in OpenStack, in addition to Nova. The case Cyborg targets is vital for HPC cloud implementation which usually requires a lot of such devices/accelerators, especially FPGA and GPU cards. Public and NFV cloud implementation also has similar requirements.

In this talk we will first introduce the background story of Cyborg project, and then demonstrate the current status (architecture, code development,..) of the project, and finally give an example of how Cyborg working with Nova and other OpenStack component could help HPC cloud implementation.
schedule.social_description: This talk introduce Cyborg project which provides a management framework for dedicated devices
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees could learn the state of the art of Cyborg development,  how we form a new project from ground zero with so many developers coming from different companies, and how we are working to tackle the technical issues around the management of devices such as FPGA and GPU

schedule.title: Functions-as-a-Service: A modern way to build applications with OpenStack.
schedule.description:
Serverless or FaaS architectures are one of the hottest trends in cloud computing this year, and for good reason. There are several technical capabilities and business factors coming together to make this approach very compelling from both an application development and deployment cost perspective. By breaking down monolithic applications into smaller services, you can develop, manage, and scale each service independently. FaaS takes this a step further by breaking things down even smaller.


So, what is Serverless/FaaS? What are functions and how they are related to microservices development? In this talk we present a new OpenStack service, Picasso, for building and handling distributed workloads using functions.

 

This talk addresses the following

  • Limitations of monolithic applications in today’s  world
  • Moving from monoliths to microservices to functions
  • Distributed workloads with and without functions
schedule.social_description: From monoliths to microservices to functions. What is FaaS and why is this new paradigm important?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• What does serverless actually mean?
  • What are functions?
  • How does Picasso provide a FaaS solution for OpenStack?
  • Benefits for developers and operators using FaaS
  • Best practices to develop FaaS applications

schedule.title: Extending OpenStack-Ansible with Automated Operational Management
schedule.description: The IBM Systems Cloud Solutions Group helps many customers realize their own private OpenStack Cloud infrastructure. Recently we considered how to best handle this task using exclusively open source solutions. For provisioning we settled on OpenStack-Ansible. We have used it heavily and became familiar with its strengths and how to leverage the framework to provide additional value to the end user. We have added our own playbooks to this solution with open DevOps tools to fulfill Operational Management aspects, such as Monitoring, Log Collection & Analysis, Performance, Scalability, Discovery and Inventory Management. In this session, we share our findings. We show our approach to integrate a stack of Ops tools with OSA for automated deployment and configuration. We also discuss how we are enhancing our solution to adjust the Ops configuration elastically to achieve coverage after our Cluster scales or is reconfigured. We expect that our experience and ideas will help other endeavors.
schedule.social_description: Extend OpenStack-Ansible to automate the install of Operational Management Tools in your cloud
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
OpenStack Ansible and how it can be extended
The value of automating solutions with Ansible to monitor cloud environments to create consistent environments with less manual work.
Nagios and the ELK Stack

schedule.title: Summit Registration
schedule.description: OK. It's actually the last day. If you are just now picking up your badge, you totally missed out! Get on over to the Lobby!
schedule.social_description: Summit Registration

schedule.title: A Novel Service Modeling Framework for NFV Networking
schedule.description:
NFV Networking Service on-demand requires quick development and deployment of new APIs. Gluon provides a model-driven, extensible framework to fulfill such requirement and enable the visibility and control of specific functionality of NFV networking services.

The core of Gluon framework is a novel modeling method to define new services at micro-service level. Its extensible object model enables flexible composition of formally monolithic services with right-size functionality, based on which APIs are generated and deployed on-demand. Services can be dynamically created and bound to infrastructure resources according to fine-grained deployment requirements. Thus service providers will achieve not only the service on-demand but also the desired scalability of specific functions within a service.

This presentation talks about the detailed design and implementation of this novel service modeling framework for telco's NFV networking.
schedule.social_description: The design and implementation of a novel service modeling framework for telco NFV networking.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The audience is anyone who is interested in NFV networking and micro-services, especially how to model and architect NFV networking at a micro-service level. The audience will learn (1) the high level design of Gluon framework; (2) the components including Gluon, Particle Generator, Proton, and Shim Layer; (3) the work flow of how components interact to fulfill a new service model; (4) details of service modeling method at micro-service level; (5) service modeling language and exemplary service models; and (6) an overview and demonstration of a Proof-of-Concept.

The audience will also learn how to participate in and contribute to further development and maturity of the Gluon project. All audience members are welcome to join the group, contribute to the work, and be part of the open community.

schedule.title: Advanced Tuning and Operation guide for Block Storage using Ceph
schedule.description:
For successful OpenStack deployment, It’s very important to properly deploy and tune block storage service, because a performance and durability of VM is completely dependent on it.

We researched about performance, durability, HA, reliability and scalability of block storage service from many OpenStack deployments. We want to share experience and knowledge gained through variety test and research. Especially, we performed test both on HDD-base and AF (All-Flash) based ceph cluster. Each environment has its unique characteristics and issues in every aspect from hardware to software. Having said that, we will not only cover ceph software configuration tuning but also include storage hardware optimization, hypervisor and guest os tuning. We will also share all of our test scenarios and tools with the community.

 

Environment:

  • Openstack Release
  • Ceph Release

Architecture

  • Physical Architecture
  • Logical Architecture

Tuning Point

  • Performance
  • High Availability
  • Scale out
  • Migration
  • Upgrade
schedule.social_description: This talk will share experience deploying a ceph-based storage service and how to tune.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Pragmatic Deployment Guide for Block Storage Service
  • Tuning Block Storage Service in many ways
  • Advanced Operation Techniques in Production Environment
  • Additional Tips for Get Low Impact of System Failure

schedule.title: Examining different ways to get involved: A look at OpenSource
schedule.description: The technology industry has come to the point that OpenSource is a household term. While less intimidating, becoming more involved in the community can be a daunting task. Join OpenSouce industry leaders Toby Ford (AT&T) and Rob Wilmoth (Red Hat) to find out how they got their start with Open Source, as well as gather a few recommendations on how to begin getting more involved within the communities that impact your own industry. We'll take a brief look at the history, how the communities have evolved, and the stages that communities can exist in so that you know where impacts stand to be made, and how to best align yourself and your teams of engineers to help drive projects to new heights.
schedule.social_description: OpenSource involvement at various org. and technical levels (Toby Ford, AT&T; Rob Wilmoth, Red Hat)
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Those in attendance will leave with a better understanding of the vairous ways that both technical and non-techincal individuals can influence and become more involved in the Open Source communities impacting their industries. They will also garner an introduction to the various levels, users groups, and standards bodies impacting a few example organizations today, and how this involvement has helped the overall direction of these industries.

schedule.title: Project Update - Security
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Security and core contributors for a project update reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Security plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Security PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Multicloud monitoring and analytics with Gnocchi and Ceilometer
schedule.description:
In this amazing session we will show how to use Gnocchi and Ceilometer to provide a centralized pane of glass of your metrics, these can be gathered from different cloud providers like Openstack, AWS, Azure, VMware etc.
Going trough architectural details of the implementation to a LIVE DEMO of this environment working we expect to encourage the audience to go full opensource using Gnocchi and Ceilometer in order to provide advance multicloud analytics. 
This session will provide the audience the guidance on how they should deploy Gnocchi and Ceilometer in a fully HA architecture to be production ready.
schedule.social_description: How to use Gnocchi and Ceilometer to provide a centralized pane of glass of your multicloud metrics
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
- Gnocchi

- Ceilometer

- General cloud telemetry

- Monitoring and analytics

- Multicloud

schedule.title: OpenStack + Kubernetes + HyperContainer = The Container Platform for NFV
schedule.description: How to containerize NFV? Hypernetes (h8s) may be a nice answer. As an multi-tenant and secure Kubernetes distribution powered by OpenStack core components, h8s creates hypervisor-based containers (HyperContainer) directly on physical servers instead of wrapping containers inside VMs. Comparing to OS containers, kernel features of this HyperContainer is completely isolated from "noisy neighbors" but still have all benefits of cloud native deployment (e.g. Docker image, container api, sub-seconds startup time). VNFs in this case will be deployed in highly secured sandboxes, while still with agility and scalibility. This is the key challenge of containerizing NFV. This talk will compare service agility, performance, isolation, portability and scalability of VNFs deployed by VM, container, and hypervisor-container stack. And demonstrate how h8s containerize NFV with both container level efficiency and VM level security.
schedule.social_description: Hypernetes: containerize NFV with both container level efficiency and VM level security.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. Attendees is expected to learn that the differences between VNFs deployed by VM, container, and hypervisor-container stack in aspects including service agility, performance, isolation, portability and scalability.

2. Attendees is expected to learn that a better way to integrate Kubernetes with OpenStack is probably not simply install it on OpenStack and use full-blown VMs to run containers. Hypernetes is trying to solve this problem from another side and compose OpenStack components directly as part of Kubernetes. In this case, OpenStack user does not need to upgrade the existing system to support k8s cluster. And at the same time, provide multi-tenant and secure container service without wrapping anything inside VMs.

3. Attendees is expected to learn implementation of h8s and how it use the power of OpenStack core components to bring k8s ochestration with Neutron networking, Cinder volume and Keystone multi-tenancy to containers running on this platform.

schedule.title: ChatOpsing Your Production Openstack Cloud
schedule.description: At TubeMogul/Adobe we have a core ethos of doing alot with alittle. This has proven true with how we run our production Openstack cloud. After going production with 4 clouds and 2 more being deployed at the moment. The one area where the team has not grown is in head count. With more cloud nodes going on line we have found there are alot of tasks that are repeatable and need to be automated. To keep us focused on our core platform we decided to use Chat as a way to create our virtual team member Serge. Serge allows us to extend basic Openstack tasks in a repeatable and safe way.
schedule.social_description: Learn how to ChatOps your production Openstack cloud safely and gain a virtual team member.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Learn how to get started and what are good use cases for ChatOps 

What tools do i need to administrate my Openstack cloud?

ChatOpsing control plane and data plane 

Things to watch out for and lessons learned

schedule.title: K8s or Die
schedule.description:
There is Kubernetes this way, that way, and the skater way.  As organizations flex to find the right space, place and pace to bring Kubernetes into the fold, we explore the different ways to kick it, flip it and ride it home with OpenStack.

We'll compare and contrast of various Kubernetes-OpenStack integration approaches.  We'll even attempt to describe when and why an organization should use Kubernetes for application infrastructure.
schedule.social_description: K8s or Die! Kubernetes -- explore different ways to kick it, flip it or ride it home with OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• A brief overview recent and prevalent Kubernetes deployment methodologies and guides.
  • How to easily roll out and use Kubernetes on top of OpenStack, and on bare metal.
  • A compare and contrast of various Kubernetes-OpenStack integration approaches.
  • When and why an organization should use Kubernetes for applications.

schedule.title: OpenStack's Digital Transformation Opportunity
schedule.description:
As customers across all industries are responding to evolving customer behaviors, market opportunities, and competitive pressures, IT organizations must adopt a more strategic role in delivering greater business value and ensuring competitive differentiation in their designated markets.

Al Sadowski of 451 Research forecasts that OpenStack ecosystem revenues will exceed $5bn by 2020. But what will the return look like for those who invest in these technologies with the desire to save money, increase operational efficiency and innovate faster? What obstacles stand in they way of digital transformation?

Join this session to find out!

Panelists:

Al Sadowski, Research VP for the Infrastructure Practice at 451 Research

Kip Compton, VP of Cisco's Cloud Platform and Services Organization

Tim Yeaton SVP, Infrastructure Business at Red Hat

Moderated by Niki Acosta, Cloud Evangelist at Cisco
schedule.social_description: OpenStack for digital transformation? Panelists from Red Hat, Cisco, and 451 Research weigh in!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn:

  • The perils of one-size-fits-all and piecemeal strategies
  • What role OpenStack plays in the path to digitization
  • How companies are addressing cultural change necessary to innovate faster
  • Strategies for keeping up with the pace of change and minimizing technical debt
  • How rapidly evolving market conditions and open source technolgies are changing how companies deliver value inside and outside of their organizations

schedule.title: Create your VM in a (almost) deterministic way -- A hands-on lab.
schedule.description:
It may sound counter-intuitive to the basic concept cloud-computing but several use cases in the virtualization world require the VM instances to be spawned on specific types of compute nodes or sometimes on specific compute nodes. 

There are various solutions to do this depending on your workload and usecase. Some provide solutions to segregate cloud resources, for example Regions, Cells, Availability Zones etc. Others are the based on the policy based filtering/scheduling like AffinityGroups and Anti-AffinityGroups.

During this lab will focus on Availability Zones and Host Aggregates, which are the ways to segregate computational workloads. Users will learn how to:

1. Create Host aggregates 

        --- associating with availability zones, adding hosts, setting meta-data

        --- A look at various scheduler filters in nova.conf

2. Create and update flavors

        ---  learn setting flavor-keys and what they mean

3. Create a VM instance using the new flavor and Host aggregate.
schedule.social_description: A hands on look at  VM instance creation using the Availability Zones and Host Aggregates.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This lab is targeted for the openstack users and operators with begginer to intermediate level knowledge. The audience will learn about various mechanisms(Availability Zones and Host Aggregates) to segregate compute resources through a presentation followed by the Hands-on lab exercises.

schedule.title: How ElasticSearch, LogStash and Kibana ease OpenStack cluster’s pains
schedule.description:
DreamHost’s public cloud based on OpenStack has received an operational boost with the introduction of a comprehensive system to run log analysis based on Elasticsearch, Kibana and Logstash (ELK). Before the introduction of this system, the Operations team had to ssh to each service to read logs. This has been slowing down both operations and customer support, often leaving team members frustrated.

With a bit of search and lots of community help from other OpenStack operators, we put in place the new system. We deploy the system as Docker containers on our cockpit nodes and since it’s been in production the Infrastructure team at DreamHost has been able to detect small errors in logs that used to go unnoticed. Among the advantages of running our own ELK stack, is our capability to pick out patterns that we can use to fix issues before they become customers concerns.
schedule.social_description: All OpenStack logs in one place: #bigdata done open source style with ELK
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This talk will detail how the Infrastructure team at DreamHost implemented the ELK stack and how it solves day-to-day operational problems.

schedule.title: OSprofiler: evaluating OpenStack
schedule.description:
OSprofiler is a lightweighted OpenStack-centric profiling library, that provides functionality to generate one trace per API request, that goes through all involved services and clients. This trace can then be used to build a tree of calls which can be quite handy for a variety of reasons (e.g. in isolating cross-project performance issues).

During a long trip from PoC to Oslo library, OSprofiler has been interated to lots of OpenStack projects (Nova, Neutron, Cinder, Glance, Heat, etc.), allowing to evaluate OpenStack behavior and find issues on REST API, RPC and DB usage layers. Newest driver model allows to store API requests profiling information in various storage options - starting with classic OpenStack-telemetry to MongoDB, Elasticsearch, Redis and Log Insight solutions.

Please join us on this presentation to learn more about the library, its architecture and possible use cases, that can make OpenStack development and debugging step on the new level.
schedule.social_description: OSprofiler Oslo library: introduction, architecture and use cases
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Reasons to create a specialized library for OpenStack profiling
  • Use cases, tips and "how to"s
  • OSprofiler architecture: what is profiled and how
  • Adding OSprofiler support to the new OpenStack ecosystem project

schedule.title: OpenStack Mentoring: The Ninja Becomes the Sensei
schedule.description:
In many martial arts, the way to progress beyond a black belt is to teach others, and thereby give back to the art and become a leader in the process. It is one thing to learn something for yourself; it is quite another to teach it to someone else. So it is with OpenStack. You’ve been building skills and connections along your OpenStack journey. Why not progress from OpenStack ninja to sensei? OpenStack mentoring is relatively new (it started just before the Austin Summit), and provides a great way to build the OpenStack community, help newcomers on their journey, and build leaders in the process. The OpenStack mentoring program is sponsored by Women of OpenStack.

 

Come join us for a panel discussion on the benefits of OpenStack mentoring featuring the program coordinator and past and present mentor/mentee pairs.
schedule.social_description: Benefits of OpenStack Mentoring
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Come join us for a panel discussion on the benefits of OpenStack mentoring featuring the program coordinator and past and present mentor/mentee pairs.

schedule.title: Why Enterprises Want Containers Now (And Why You Should Too)
schedule.description:
It took enterprises a decade or more to embrace virtualization. It was a massive, quantum leap from the mindset of one server, one OS, one workload. Virtualization was a relatively easy sell: cost compression was the name of the game, and no one played the game better than VMware.

But once the public cloud (AWS, etc.) and open source options (OpenStack, etc.)  came along, enterprises had to fundamentally shift the way they thought about application development and deployment, as well as infrastructure operations. It was a big shift. It took time. But once enterprises “got it,” things started to change.

  • Why have containers caught on faster than VMs?
  • Do enterprises want both?
  • What lessons can we learn from early mistakes the pioneers have made in containers deployment?

This session will provide a better understanding on how enterprises—in growing numbers—have crossed the barrier and are thinking “cloudy” about app dev and ops, leading them to ask, “Do we even need VMs?”
schedule.social_description: Enterprises crossed the barrier and thinking “cloudy”, leading them to ask, “Do we even need VMs?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Why containers are important to the enterprise, not just about the technology, but about the cultuer change required to drive success for the long term.

schedule.title: How to manage Known State (consistency) in Large/medium Openstack Deployments
schedule.description:
• It is important that Openstack deployed across multiple production environments, all nodes must be at same code level, kernel level, security, configuration etc.
  • Consistency across all type of nodes helps is avoiding various issues to the end user and it also helps in identifying and troubleshooting in case of any issue.
  • Large openstack deployment have multiple computes, and having some of them on different code level could result in missing new feature or defects.
  • Known state can be achieved by regular analysis/audit and maintenance of environment using automation scripts.
  • Automation can minimize error and results in faster implementation across large or medium deployments in openstack nodes. This results in high openstack performance result in customer confidence.
schedule.social_description: This will help in understanding Known State (consistency) in Large/medium Openstack Deployments.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Audience will gain an understanding, importance of maintaining consistency in openstack production environments. Potential impacts of version mismatch and security concerns.
  • Cloud tenants/end users are a key stakeholder in the OpenStack cloud platforms. Known state (consistency) play a vital role in proper functioning of the product and deploying new features across similar nodes. This session will explain how the consistency can be plan, achieve and maintain in the future. Also, with the growth of OpenStack there is a new category of OpenStack community members & stakeholders – applications business owners, tenants that will have a keen interest in this topic

schedule.title: Continuous Delivery of stateful applications using Cinder at Paddy Power Betfair
schedule.description: When deploying databases such as mysql or informix and stateful applications such as Kafka on OpenStack then persistance of state between deployments is vitally important. This presentation will show how Paddy Power Betfair uses Ansible to carry out immutable deployments of stateful applications on OpenStack by seperating out the data onto Cinder volumes while the application version sits at the OS level. This talk will consist of a live demo showing one of our stateful production applications being immutably deployed and we will walk users through each step of the deployment pipeline showing how we automed this process.
schedule.social_description: Live immutable deployment of a stateful application at Paddy Power Betfair using Ansible
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how to deploy stateful applications using Cinder on OpenStack while keeping the deployment immutable. They will learn what Ansible modules can be used to achieve this and how we designed the deployment pipeline.

schedule.title: OpenStack-Helm: Managing the life-cycle of OpenStack deployments on top of Kubernetes
schedule.description:
The openstack-helm project provides an incredibly customizable framework for operators and developers alike to deploy OpenStack on top of Kubernetes. This framework will enable end-users to deploy, maintain, and upgrade a fully functioning Openstack environment for both simple and complex environments. Administrators or developers can either deploy all or individual Openstack components along with their required dependencies. The project is intended to be a collaborative project that brings Openstack applications into a Cloud-Native model.

OpenStack is a very complex and interconnected application with a large number of inter-dependencies.  This presentation will demonstrate how the Kubernetes primitives, combined with Helms template and release management capabilities can simplify this process and demonstrate a better way to manage the life-cycle of OpenStack components and the required infrastructure needed to run OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: OpenStack-Helm: a cloud-native solution to manage the life-cycle of OpenStack on top of Kubernetes.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
During this session we will:

  • We’ll review the current state of the project, discuss what our long-term goals are, and walk through deploying, changing, upgrading, and scaling a resilient OpenStack environment running on top of Kubernetes with no impact to the OpenStack services themselves. We’ll also review how this open and flexible framework can be extended to include other control plane components production sites must run along side OpenStack using the same tools and approach.
  • Demonstrate how openstack-helm can deploy the required infrastructure for OpenStack as well as OpenStack itself.
  • Show how configuration management and upgrades are done under a Kubernetes/Helm workflow.
  • Demonstrate scaling the OpenStack control plane leveraging Helm as our interface to Kubernetes.
  • Discuss the gaps we are working to close in the project.
  • Review how the openstack-helm project has also been working closely with the Kubernetes/Helm CNCF community ensuring that we are closing the gaps necessary to manage the life-cycle of such a complex application within Kubernetes/Helm natively.
  • Examine the patterns in the openstack-helm charts and discuss how this project may differ from other approaches as well as how the openstack-helm approach could be applied to other control plane applications running along side OpenStack for a single release strategy.
  • Describe how we will leverage this approach for more then 100 OpenStack production deployments at AT&T.
  • Gauge interest in this approach and solicit community feedback.

schedule.title: Dynamic and continuous auditing, controlling, and monitoring of all tenant network flows in OpenStack at scale
schedule.description:
OpenStack Neutron provides powerful self-service and micro-segmentation capabilities. However, the full potential of Software Defined Networking (SDN) in OpenStack has not been realized. The modern Enterprise requires additional capabilities around auditing, monitoring, and policy-based governance of network flows inside the OpenStack cloud and in a way that is cloud-aware, highly-available, high-performance, and with negligible impact to production.

Solution: Cloudvisory’s Security Platform integrates with OpenStack’s native security controls to strike an optimal balance of visibility versus impact. Time Warner Cable worked with Cloudvisory to deliver automated provisioning of native OpenStack security controls. Visualization and alerting allowed operations to become aware of minute by minute business changes, non-compliant activity and potential malicious network flows. Continuous monitoring and enforcement ensures strict compliance. The result has been improvement in speed of operations and an ability to meet critical compliance goals.
schedule.social_description: Dynamic/continuous auditing, controlling, and monitoring of all network flows in OpenStack at scale
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn how Time Warner Cable leveraged Cloudvisory to fill auditing, monitoring, and policy gaps in its OpenStack cloud network infrastructure. First, understand the benefits and shortcomings of self-service network policies (i.e. Neutron Security Groups) as currently implemented in OpenStack. Second, compare and contrast competing approaches to filling Network Security Policy gaps in order to operate an OpenStack cloud that meets the network security and compliance needs of the modern enterprise. Lastly, learn the Cloudvisory approach to monitoring OpenStack networks without sacrificing flexibility, performance, or scalability. This talk will end with a demo of Cloudvisory’s dynamic governance of OpenStack workloads.

schedule.title: OpenStack Newton on OCP hardware - perfect together
schedule.description:
The Open Compute Project (OCP) is a collaborative community focused on redesigning hardware technology to efficiently support the growing demands on compute infrastructure. The designs have been optimized to lower cost of infrastructure and operations e.g. by removing non-essential components, disaggregating rack level solution with common resources, and simplifying server serviceability.

OpenStack provides the foundation for the NFVI and MANO components within OPNFV. OPNFV releases Colorado and recent Danube have been successfully integrated to OCP hardware and running smoothly. Also hardware acceleration is supported. The concept itself has gained a lot of interest from mobile operators, some of them are running OPNFV on top of OCP hardware in their test laboratories too.

This presentation will introduce how OpenStack, OCP and OPNFV open source projects fits perfectly together.
schedule.social_description: Introducuction how OpenStack, OCP and OPNFV open source projects fits perfectly together.

schedule.title: Project Update - Solum
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Solum and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Solum plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

 

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Solum PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Public? Private? Hybrid?  What is the optimal deployment strategy for your applications...
schedule.description: Determining where an application or workload should run in the cloud is one of the top considerations for an organization.  This sessions will go into deeper detail and provide insights on the business, technical, ecosystem, and deployment considerations when determining where to deploy solutions.  Understanding workload attributes (performance, security, integration, and data volume) and the cumulative importance for each is critical when making cloud hosting decisions.  Summarizing research and case studies we will go into detail on the differences in workloads and how to guide your organization to the optimal cloud solutions given the many options available today.
schedule.social_description: Determining where your application should run in the cloud - private, hybrid, or public!
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn the key areas to consider for Busines, Technical, Ecosystem, and Other when determing where to land workloads.  They will get an understanding of key areas of importance by workload and be equipped with additional research and case studies to clarify the on-premises affinity by workload characteristic.  At the end of the session those attending will have the fundamentals to define a successful cloud strategy for their orgnanization.

schedule.title: How to run 100,000+ cores Openstack private cloud and still sleep at night !
schedule.description:
Creating your first VM on DevStack is undoubtedly very satisfying, but it's very different from running a multi billion dollar production site on Openstack. Reliable execution is the key. In a DevStack setup restarting Openstack services and VMs multiple times is not unusual, but with a live business the stakes are so high that such downtimes are unacceptable.

We will be sharing our experiences running snapdeal.com infra services on a 100% open-source, no-license Openstack private cloud.

  • Provider or tenant network ?
  • What's better - 3 or 5 controllers ?
  • Control plane is like food and dataplane is like oxygen. How to improve dataplane reliability ?
  • Should you overcommit resources in Production ?
  • Why/How to keep RabbitMQ happy ?
  • How much latency to expect from your OS cloud ? How to improve ?
  • Should you care about vCPU affinity, numa awareness, OVS-DPDK etc ?
  • Local or shared storage ? Reliability vs ease-of-use vs perf.
  • SSD or magnetic storage ?
schedule.social_description: Successfully running a live production site on a 100,000+ nodes Openstack private cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
We will be sharing our experiences in building a 100,000+ nodes Openstack private cloud from scratch and what we learnt along the way.

We hope it'll be helpful to people working on building similar cloud platform so that they can take well informed and correct architectural decisions and they don't need to revisit things very often.

We will be sharing practical tips which would be helpful to anyone managing a reasonably large Openstack private cloud.

schedule.title: Advanced threat prediction and orchestration for service chains in SP cloud
schedule.description:
Problem Statement

Organizations are susceptible to security threats targeted at the weakest point in the systems which can be scaled east-west into the organization. This requires the cloud to have the capability to predict possible threats and seamlessly orchestrate policies to address them.

Proposed Solution

A controller placed in the SP cloud which performs deep packet inspection on the traffic. Since traffic inspection of packets is a memory overhead, the controller has ability to maintain a label for each packet class and use it to rule out overlapping inspections for subsequent packets. The controller logs threat data and provides input to the operator to design and insert security rules seamlessly. It provides capability to monitor the rate of traffic passing through the NFVs and provide clustering and load balancing capabilities. It also provides capability to spawn network functions on demand or modify the existing network functions based on refined security policies.
schedule.social_description: An adaptive controller to predict and auto learn security rules in SP cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The key takeaways for cloud developers and designers are

  • Different kinds of possible threats in a cloud environment.
  • Implementation of Virtual Network Functions like ASA, WSA, CSR.
  • Deep packet inspection and prediction algorithms.
  • How to Clusterise NFVs and load balance traffic across them?
  • How to design security rules based on zero trust policy?
  • Insight into the seamless orchestration of NFVs

schedule.title: RDO's continuous packaging platform
schedule.description:
Have you contributed to Openstack during this cycle, or do you intend to do so in the next? If so, thanks for helping improving upstream! But do you know how your contribution gets to make it downstream in distributions like Centos, Fedora, Red Hat® Enterprise Linux®? Packaging for these distributions is what Red Hat distribution for OpenStack (RDO) does.

After the OpenStack Tokyo Summit in november 2015, the RDO community transitioned to a delivery workflow inspired by OpenStack's own continuous integration infrastructure ("OpenStack Infra"). The platform relies on Software Factory to automatically set up the tools from OpenStack Infra together, and a few additional tools specific to RDO to ensure the quality of their packages.


In this presentation, we will introduce the main components of RDO's delivery platform, the problems they help solve, and how they can be adapted to set up your own "RPM Factory".
schedule.social_description: Introduction to RDO's tools and workflow ensuring the quality of OpenStack's RPM packaging
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• What upstream merges imply for RPM packaging downstream
  • How RDO ensures the quality and speed of delivery for its RPM packages of Openstack
  • How RDO's workflow can be generalized into a "RPM factory"

schedule.title: OpenDaylight Network Virtualization solution (NetVirt) with FD.io VPP data plane
schedule.description:
Opendaylight is an industry recognized SDN controller and it provides various infrastructure and applications needed for Cloud administrators. "NetVirt" is a key component of OpenDaylight and it provides a rich set of Network Virtualization L2 and L3 services needed for OpenStack Cloud admins. The current version of OpenDaylight "NetVirt" offers Network Virtualization features in OpenFlow based OVS data plane environments.

FD.io VPP (Vector Packet Processor) platform, an open source project, is an extensible, rapid packet-processing stack for highly performing network applications, with very high forwarding performance.

To offer the best of both worlds, a new activity is initiated in OpenDaylight community to enhance OpenDaylight "NetVirt" module to support Netconf based FD.io VPP data plane devices in addition to OVS switches. This talk provides an overview of the OpenDaylight NetVirt and FD.io VPP architectures and explains integration between these two architectures.
schedule.social_description: Overview of OpenDaylight Network Virtualization solution with high performing FD.io VPP platform.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: A high level overview of OpenDaylight Network Virtualization solution and how it offers different network virtualization layer 2, layer 3, L3VPN...etc services in FD.io VPP data plane environment.

schedule.title: My 3 years with an OpenStack startup: How to bridge the gap between the technical and business sides
schedule.description:
3 years ago, I joined Ormuco, a Montreal-based cloud technology provider based on OpenStack. As a young engineer, I was eager to contribute to my community and I went through a steep learning curve.

At Ormuco, I experienced many facets of the industry: first in technical support, then in research and development, and finally in sales and business development… all under just 3 years! I learned valuable lessons which I will share with you here.

Specifically, I will discuss:

  • The challenges of working with OpenStack and getting engaged in the community
  • A detailed plan to quickly gain relevant IT skills and certifications that will allow you to work alongside senior system administrators and developers
  • How can advanced IT skills help you navigate in the business world and be successful with clients

Use cases and projects will also be highlighted. Whether you are an engineer or a manager, you will benefit from insights into working on both the technical and business sides of OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: Lessons learned from working with an OpenStack startup on both the technical and business sides.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This talk will give new engineers useful information on how to get started with OpenStack and gain advanced technical skills. Similarly, it will give managers insights into the process of mentoring and training employees. Finally, the talk will provide an interesting analysis on the interdependence of the technical and business sides of the OpenStack cloud industry. An overview of my own career progress and development at Ormuco will be provided with real-life examples of use cases and impact on the community.

The talk takeaways can be divided in 3 main parts:

  • How to get started with OpenStack:
    • The challenges of working with OpenStack
    • How to navigate through the documentation
    • How to get involved and contribute
  • Detailed step-by-step plan to gain required technical skills:
    • Relevant technical training and certifications
    • Importance of a mentorship program
    • Working alongside senior system administrators and software developers
  • Using your technical skills to navigate in the business world:
    • How can your technical skills help you succeed in the business world
    • Example of projects and use cases
    • Tips and lessons learned

schedule.title: OpenStack cluster Zero-downtime upgrade with Kolla
schedule.description: Currently, zero-downtime upgrade is highly demand feature from OpenStack users. Current implementation status in OpenStack is variable between projects and almost projects have not fully implemented rolling upgrade. One among Kolla's deliverables is OpenStack container-based deployment tool, thus adding zero-downtime upgrade support in Kolla is reasonable. Our approach is to implement in Kolla natively without needing support from individual OpenStack service. We propose 2 solutions for this problem. First approach achieve real "zero-downtime" from user PoV if upgrade time is short enough, but fail if upgrade time is too long, and it consumes much memory if system is under heavy load during upgrading. Second approach requires more resources than the first one and user will see a short downtime but does not suffer timeout problem. So we can combine two solutions to get advantages from each. The spec and demo for the 1st solution has been proposed and in review queue of Kolla community.
schedule.social_description: We propose the spec and PoC demo for one approach to OpenStack zero-downtime upgrade by Kolla.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
- Rolling upgrade implemenation status in OpenStack eco-system.

- Two approaches for achieving zero-downtime upgrade in Kolla (with container technologies).

- Demo for one approach.

schedule.title: Scheduler Wars: A New Hope
schedule.description:
Over the last 18 months, the OpenStack Nova development team has dramatically refactored some of the foundational parts of the core Nova software. As an operator, deployer or systems architect, you might have heard about "resource providers" or the new "Placement API" but haven't had the time to really dig in and find out what all the fuss is about.

Not to worry! Jay Pipes, a Nova core developer and old hat in the OpenStack ecosystem, will explain everything attendees need to know about the new Placement service and how resource tracking and scheduling decisions have been fundamentally transformed with the new resource providers modeling. Attendees will learn what specific deployment and configuration changes were optional in Newton but now required in Ocata and how to smoothly upgrade their existing OpenStack deployments and enable the new subsystems.
schedule.social_description: BREAKING NEWS: New OpenStack scheduler service breaks the Internet.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees can expect to learn:

  • What problems is the new Placement service designed to solve?
  • What does the new Placement service mean for deployers, operators and architects
  • What do you need to do to smoothly transition from Newton to Ocata and enable new resource tracking functionality
  • How the new Placement service integrates with other OpenStack services like Ironic and Neutron
  • What features are planned for the Placement service near and long term

schedule.title: How Paddy Power Betfair Uses OpenStack Manila to Manage Stateful Data in the DevOps Process
schedule.description:
Paddy Power Betfair started its OpenStack and DevOps journey a few of years back, and has some lessons learned to share with the community. In this talk we will share our latest experience with OpenStack Manila and File share services in OpenStack.

We will describe in detail the use cases and the kind of applications that consume file-share services at Paddy Power Betfair, by showcasing how OpenStack Manila has enabled us to offer our developers access to File share services through APIs. Moving away from spreadsheets and manual provisioning, now file shares can be managed centrally and offer self-service. We will also describe how we are on-boarding existing applications to OpenStack with Manila.

As part of this session we will also shed some light on how we deployed the Manila service in our OpenStack environment and talk about how to take advantage of advanced data management features like replication.
schedule.social_description: How Paddy Power Betfair Uses OpenStack Manila to Manage Stateful Data in the DevOps Process
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1) Use-cases for OpenStack Manila

2) Deploying OpenStack Manila in an enterprise environment

3) Manila for persistent/state-full applications

4) On-boarding existing applications to OpenStack

5) Self-service file share services

schedule.title: Senlin, an ideal bridge between NFV Orchestrator and OpenStack
schedule.description: Resource Management is a top requirement in NFV field. Usually, the Orchestrator take the responsibility of parsing a virtual network function into different virtual units (VDU) to deploy and operate over Cloud. Senlin, positioned as clustering resource manager since the born time, can be the ideal bridge between NFV orchestrator with OpenStack: it uses a consolidate model which is directly mapped to a VDU to interact with different backend services like Nova, Neutron, Cinder for compute, network and storage resources per Orchestrator's demand; it provides rich operational functions like auto-scaling, load-balancing and auto healing. We use a popular VIMS typed VNF to illustrate how to easily deploy a VNF on OpenStack and manage it in a scalable and flexible way.
schedule.social_description: Senlin is an ideal resource manager for NFV orchestrator with rich LCM and operation support.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this presentation, we use a VIMS typed VNF as an example to show how Senlin works with the orchestrators to deploy and operate this VNF. The VNF is consisted of different VDUs. Some of the VDUs should be auto-scaled to handle elastic workload and others should be auto-healed:

(1) how to use VDU profile to deploy the NFV including all required resources like Virtual Machine with user_data, security_group, floating_ip, and Volume.

(2) how to customize which availability zone/region to place a new VDU or which one to delete by policy.

(3) How to use the scaling and health policy to realize auto-scaling and auto-healing of the example VIMS.

(4) how to run custom action like shell or Ansible playbooks directly on a specific or group of VDU.

schedule.title: Project Update - Swift
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Swift and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Swift plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Swift PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: The OpenStack Technical Committee Vision for 2019: Updates, Stories, Q&A
schedule.description: After the Pike Project Team Gathering, the OpenStack TC (with the help of the Stewardship Working Group) began drafting a vision for what the TC, its work, and OpenStack will look like in the future. 2019, to be exact. We'll present both the vision and the process that got us to our draft, and we'll talk about what comes next for OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: Presenting the 2019 vision for OpenStack's Technical Committee.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: You'll learn about where the TC is going, and about what a vision is and how we were able to draft one. You'll also learn about how to participate in future visions for OpenStack.

schedule.title: Practice to Bare Metal Multi-tenant Solution Combined with SDN
schedule.description:
Bare Metal Multi-tenant Solution has been implemented in the Newton cycle. We have already applied the solution in commercial practice and form a complete bare metal life-cycle management solution.
In this session, we will introduce this solution and network deployment schema cooperating with SDN.
schedule.social_description: Practice to Bare Metal Multi-tenant Solution Combined with SDN
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: bare metal multi-tenant solution combined with SDN

schedule.title: Automating noisy neighbor detection with OpenStack Watcher
schedule.description: When taking advantage of a Compute as a Service offering in a private or public Cloud, developers are at the mercy of the behavior of workloads that are running on the same shared resources on the servers (CPU cycles, memory, bandwidth, etc.)  An application's performance can be greatly negatively impacted by its co-located applications. This problem is known as the "noisy neighbor problem". We present a strategy for automatic noisy neighbor detection and mitigation in the form of VM migration or deletion. Our algorithm uses metrics forwarded to Ceilometer by the Cache Monitoring Technology and Memory Bandwidth Monitoring to determine if a specific VM is a noisy neighbor. We implemented the algorithm as a strategy in OpenStack Watcher which does continuous optimization for multi-tenant OpenStack-based clouds and will demo the strategy at the summit during the session.
schedule.social_description: We present a strategy for automatic noisy neighbor detection implemented in OpenStack Watcher.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about various approaches for noisy neighbor detection as well as actions that can be performaned through OpenStack Watcher in an automated fashion.

schedule.title: Securing OpenStack clouds and beyond with Ansible
schedule.description:
You successfully pitched an OpenStack cloud to your company. Great! But wait -- here comes the security team and the auditors! What do you do now?

Help is on the way (in the form of an Ansible role)!

The openstack-ansible-security role, first unveiled at the Austin Summit, applies security controls from the Security Technical Implementation Guide (STIG) across OpenStack clouds using Ansible. The highly configurable design arms cloud operators with a flexible tool to secure hypervisors, control plane hosts, and other non-OpenStack Linux systems. It comes with an audit mode that allows deployers to preview their deployment and provide evidence of configuration when the auditors come knocking.

The Ocata release applies Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 and 7 STIG releases on CentOS 7, Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, Ubuntu Trusty and Ubuntu Xenial.

Major Hayden, principal architect at Rackspace, will bring attendees along for a live demo of the role in action during this vendor-neutral talk.
schedule.social_description: Make OpenStack conversations with the security team easier with the OpenStack-Ansible security role.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will start by learning the problems that companies of all sizes face when they secure large infrastructure deployments. This brings the whole audience together -- from the security experts to the novices -- into a common story.

From there, we will take a deep dive into the design and configuration of the openstack-ansible-security role. The audience will learn how to reconfigure the role and re-apply certain configurations to an environment.

Toward the end of the talk, the audience will learn how to develop new capabilities for the role and contribute to documentation.

schedule.title: Marketing Community meeting
schedule.description:
The Marketing Community Meeting is our semiannual, in-person opportunity to gather marketing leaders throughout the ecosystem and discuss our projects and priorities. The OpenStack Foundation's marketing team will present a short recap of recent projects and our plans for future projects through the next Summit, but will be looking for your input on these projects to shape our priorities. 

You should come with the intention of: 

  • Evaluating OpenStack's proposed marketing plan for the next six months
  • Sharing a current project or problem for group feedback
  • Sharing your company's priorities to help the foundation better align to your goals
  • Taking part in collaborative campaigns led by the marketing community, if you wish, and
  • Networking with your counterparts at other organizations.

Please contact heidijoy@openstack.org if you would like to suggest agenda items and a specific project/problem you would like to see on the agenda.
schedule.social_description: OpenStack's marketing community meeting calls for your input on plans & priorities
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• OpenStack's recent marketing programs/accomplishments
  • OpenStack's projected marketing plan through the Sydney Summit
  • Discussion of your priorities and of those in the ecosystem, to better guide our future endeavors

schedule.title: Hands-On Workshop: Learn how to deploy OpenStack on Kubernetes.
schedule.description:
Hands-On Workshop: Learn how to deploy OpenStack on Kubernetes. OpenStack is awesome and so is Kubernetes. These days we see more and more integrations and support between those two great OpenSource projects. For instance, you can get a better experience with Kubernetes when you running it on top of OpenStack and can take advantage of OpenStack capabilities to provide persistent storage via Cinder or LoabBalancing via LbaaS of the Neutron. On another hand, you can get a better experience of running OpenStack on top of Kubernetes and take advantage of scaling OpenStack services and performing seamless rolling upgrades.

In this workshop you going to learn how to deploy and upgrade OpenStack on top of Kubernetes for development needs and testing, using official Kubernetes packaging tool - Helm.

Attendees simply need to come in (with their laptop). Workshop speaker/organizer will provide instructions and will be available to answer any questions.
schedule.social_description: Learn how to deploy and upgrade OpenStack on top of Kubernetes using Helm Charts.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this workshop you will learn:

  1. Overview how to deploy the application on K8s using pods, labels, deployments and services.
  2. Learn what is Helm and how to develop, use and deploy Helm Charts.
  3. Learn how to deploy State full application like Mysql and Rabbit using Helm Charts.
  4. Learn how to deploy and upgrade OpenStack services like Keystone, Glance, Neutron and Nova using Helm Charts.

schedule.title: Help telecom operators save energy and reduce cost of data center with Openstack Watcher
schedule.description:
The mobile communication network traffic tidal [1] is an actual phenomena in the telecommunication. For example, during the daytime, large amount of users gather in the CBD[2] area and the workload of network traffic system is high. When they get off work, the user numbers declines rapidly and so does the network traffic workload. The problem is how to fulfill user network service requirements with minimal energy consumption given the changing network traffic workloads.
As a real case from ZTE corporation, this problem is addressed by the following way. When the workload is low, we consolidate VMs (virtual machines) to several hosts by live migration, and power off the hosts without VMs to reduce power consumption. Correspondingly, when the workload boosts, we power on those hosts again and lively migrate the VMs back to them. 

We will present the above algorithms and implement them as a strategy in Watcher.
schedule.social_description: Energy-saving strategies in Watcher which does continuous optimization of an OpenStack Cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about how Watcher is used to accomplish resource optimization by a strategy example.

schedule.title: Saving one cloud at a time with tenant care
schedule.description:
Because many of the early OpenStack deployments focused on proof of concept scenarios and use cases, they mostly provided capacity to early adopter end users.  As a result, the focus on user experience, or “tenant care”, has been lacking, and is a common barrier to broader end user adoption.  

Without a tenant care strategy, end users commonly struggle to get regular communications regarding cloud availability or features, proactive support, recommendations on how to best utilize the capacity and features of the cloud, and overall guidance on how to optimize their experience on a private cloud.  Consequently, a lack of tenant care impedes the long-term success of a private cloud strategy.

In this talk, we’ll explain what quality tenant care is and why it's necessary.  We'll also summarize common obstacles to a successful user experience, as well as strategies and solutions that can solve these problems. We'll finish with actual planned tenant care strategies at Comcast.
schedule.social_description: Early OpenStack deployments are mostly for early adopters; focus on “tenant care” has been lacking.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about:

  • What kind of tenant care private clouds must provide to be successful
  • What to watch out for when crafting a tenant care strategy
  • Successful strategies they can take back to their own organizations
  • A real life case study of how Comcast is improving tenant care

schedule.title: A Field Trip in the Cloud
schedule.description:
Deploying and managing an application using OpenStack Python SDK or the Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Cloud SDK is challenging because of their inherent design constraints. In this talk we show one way to overcame these challenges by refactoring the design to exploit the best from both worlds, OpenStack Python SDK and GCP Cloud SDK.

We will share our approach to this refactoring, its outcome on the design, our benchmark results for various design choices, the resulting performance gains, and the pain points of using different API’s (OpenStack Python SDK and GCP Cloud SDK).

After this talk, you will have an insight on how to use the OpenStack Python SDK and GCP SDK effectively. We will also show you how to easily create and manage an application server with the help of the Rest API’s provided in the SDKs.
schedule.social_description: Re-Imagining the use of OpenStack Python SDK and Google Cloud Platform Cloud SDK in the 21st century
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Basics of OpenStack Python SDK and the Google Cloud Platform Cloud SDK.
  • How to deploy and manage their application and infrastructure.
  • Identify problems and how they can be solved using the API's and save time.
  • Pros and cons of using OpenStack Python SDK and GCP Cloud SDK.
  • Major differences between the networking components of OpenStack Python SDK and GCP Cloud SDK.

schedule.title: Gnocchi and collectd for faster fault detection and maintenance
schedule.description:
Collectd is a system statistics collection daemon that reads system metrics and writes them to various formats. Much work has been done to expose more platform statistics as well as statistics from software applications (enabled by OPNFV barometer). These stats were previously made available to OpenStack via Ceilometer, and now via Gnocchi.

Gnocchi provides a times series metric storage service which enables users to capture OpenStack resources and the metrics associated with them. Aodh provides alarms and notification based on metrics.

The telemetry data available to OpenStack is mostly limited to virtual resource metering. In order to ensure continuity of service, it is vital to monitor the physical infrastructure as well. Collectd provides visibility to what’s happening in the system and this data can be consumed by Aodh to notify and act when faults are detected. All this is the result of collaboration within several open source projects (DPDK, collectd, OpenStack, OPNFV).
schedule.social_description: Collectd can provide metrics to OpenStack to monitor physical resources and maintain system up time.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
What should attendees expect to learn? (1000 chars)

  • How collectd’s statistics can be used in OpenStack for better integrated monitoring capabilities.
  • How collectd can be used in conjunction with OpenStack services to provide fault monitoring and detection capabilities.
  • How gnocchi deals with large datasets and can be used to provide insights into the health of your system.
  • How aodh can be used to react to system faults.

schedule.title: Enabling Federated Cloud Networking: the BEACON project
schedule.description:
BEACON is a Research and Development project, funded by the EU through its H2020 framework programme, focused on techniques to federate cloud network resources, and derive the integrated management cloud layer that enables a secure and automatic deployment of applications and services across federated clouds.

BEACON provides enabling mechanisms, by defining and implementing a cloud networking framework that enables the provisioning of federated inter-cloud infrastructure.

One of the key points of this project is that it is fully driven by real industry uses cases proposed by different cloud actors, such as cloud providers, cloud technology developers, and cloud-user companies and institutions, that are represented by the different partners of the project consortium.
schedule.social_description: A cloud networking framework for the secure provisioning of federated inter-cloud infrastructure
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
A number of mechanisms, either fully developed or in-progress, will be explained and demonstrated (where feasible), possibly including industrial use cases from project partners, where relevant, among the following:

 

- OpenStack/OpenNebula-based federated SDN (featuring OVN)

- brokered orchestration (also featuring Heat)

- extensions to public Clouds (e.g., AWS)

- hierarchical LBaaS (featuring Octavia)

- federated SDN monitoring (featuring SkyDive)

- secure service function chaining (SFC) (featuring Tacker)

- federation with IoT/Edge nodes (IoTronic)

schedule.title: Scale-out RabbitMQ cluster can improve performance while keeping high availability.
schedule.description:
Deploying OpenStack in a large scale environment, we can regard Message Queue(MQ) as a bottleneck.
To solve this, OpenStack operators typically tune MQ or separate the MQ into multi clusters. However, operators suffer from managing and tuning multiple MQ clusters and investigating which OpenStack projects have heavy workloads for the clusters.

NTT Communications is planning to expand its cloud environment to 1000+ nodes per region. Therefore the better way to improve performance on MQ becomes one of the essential considerations.

In this session, we will first provide our findings from the operators' side that, a single RabbitMQ cluster can improve its performance while keeping High-Availability by scale-out without any tuning. We also show the bottleneck issues in Nova conductor queue found in the survey.

Then based on the operator's feedbacks, the developers made efforts against the issues and eventually succeeded to relieve the bottleneck in Nova with separated conductor message bus.
schedule.social_description: RabbitMQ can improve performance while keeping high availability by cluster scale-out.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This presentation has two parts. First part shows operators side's feedbacks for deploying high-performanced HA RabbitMQ clusters. Another shows devloper side's efforts that knock down heavy workloads in RabbitMQ messaging bus caused by OpenStack projects.

As operator's experiences:

  • Details of messaging bottleneck in OpenStack
  • Best practices configuration for high available & load balanceable message queue
