  • Performance benchmark results under different configrations on an inhouse OpenStack production environment
  • RabbitMQ distributed cluster specification, issues and solutions.

As developer's efforts:

  • Advantages of separated conductor message bus that reduces messaging bus workloads at least 2 times among nova-compute and nova-conducter
  • Architecture and implementations of separated conductor message bus
  • Current status of upstream in OpenStack community

schedule.title: Hardware Interoperability Learnings from AT&T Integrated Cloud
schedule.description:
This presentation describes Best Practices to ensure hardware planned for OpenStack deployments provides expected OpenStack performance.  Key integration tests are described for new hardware being considered for AT&T Integrated Cloud (AIC).  Interoperability testing is essential since we found hardware from leading vendors that delivered unacceptable OpenStack performance.

Mobile AT&T traffic continues to grow exponentially, 150,000% in the last 7 years.  To meet this demand, there is a need to transition from purpose built network appliances to open white-box commodity hardware virtualized and controlled by AIC.

Vendor claims of OpenStack support may not meet your needs. Failure to perform adequate HW certification within your own environment can lead to production outages, missed deadlines and significant cost both in time and resources.  This presentation will explore AT&T’s strategy to close these gaps, and streamline the integration of new hardware into AIC.
schedule.social_description: Hardware Interoperability Learnings from AT&T Integrated Cloud
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn how this team validates the interoperability of new hardware in the AT&T Integrated Cloud.

We will explore the following topic:

  • Knowing the hardware pipeline
  • Interoperability verification process
    • OpenStack API Calls
    • Heat Templates
  • Firmware, BIOS settings
  • Lab setup
    • Native OpenStack
    • Mirantis Fuel AIC OpenStack
  • Test Case Automation
  • How to manage hardware differences between versions 
  • How to manage multiple concurrent AIC releases
  • Managing interoperability of different hardware components
  • Performance Testing
  • Real life experiences

schedule.title: The OpenStack Advantage for Hybrid Cloud Architectures
schedule.description: While AWS is great for public cloud services, OpenStack is emerging as a significant advantage for companies that require more specialized computing tasks delivered from very large private clouds and/or hybrid clouds. Many businesses are now turning to OpenStack, which offers the flexibility to run dynamic workloads for mission-critical applications in these environments. Interoperable solutions and seamless scaling are key advantages for many vertical industries selecting OpenStack solutions, including Financial Services, Healthcare, and Education. In this discussion, Juniper Networks’ Jonathan Davidson, EVP and GM of Juniper Development and Innovation, will speak to how industry collaboration will drive enhanced performance and how standards and automation are critical to easing operations and driving innovation across the networking industry.
schedule.social_description: Companies turn to OpenStack for specialized computing tasks delivered from hybrid clouds
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: During this session, attendees will learn why industry collaboration will drive enhanced performance and how standards and automation are critical to easing operations and driving innovation across the networking industry. Attendees in vertical industries including Financial Services, Healthcare, and Education will be inspired to re-think their cloud computing platform.

schedule.title: OpenStack Discovery and Networking Assurance
schedule.description: Network administration overhead is currently one of the major obstacles preventing customers from moving OpenStack into production for wider adoption and efficient utilization by applications. Cloud facilities might experience lack of visibility to common operations of underlying workers and coherent representation of physical and virtual network elements and their interconnections. They might find it hard to estimate impact of micro failures in their infrastructure and react fast to failures. Some might overcome complexity in operations, discovery and monitoring of their cloud by manual processes and/or complex batch operations. I'm offering a journey of troubleshooting and discovery cycles in a typical Cloud that we run today, suggest elegant ways to overcome overheads. Substantially simplifying networking operations, troubleshooting and monitoring might happen through unified Operations API and operations agent, those concepts will be presented, accompanied with practical demos.
schedule.social_description: Learn about micro failures, experience troubleshooting cycles, see elegant ways to lower overhead.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. How micro failures in OpenStack workers can be detected and monitored.
  2. How-to operate, troubleshoot and support virtual networking in OpenStack environments, spanning multiple distributions and plugins.

schedule.title: Using OpenStack Orchestration for Big Data Workloads
schedule.description:
According to the April 2016 User Survey, Big Data is a major use case for OpenStack deployments. At Cisco, we're seeing multiple customers using OpenStack for Big Data workloads.

In this talk, Hart will walk through the OpenStack Orchestration project (project Heat), demonstrating how it can be used to manage cloud deployments. This will include giving you an understanding of what Heat is, an overview of how to use it both server-side and client-side, key terminology, and Heat template concepts.

The talk will then go into the architecture of Big Data workloads, specifically Hadoop. Hadoop components will be mapped out and discussed. Finally, the presentation will conclude with a live demo of a deployment based on the latest Big Data reference architecture from the OpenStack Enterprise working group.
schedule.social_description: Learn how to use OpenStack Orchestration for Big Data Workloads
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should walk away with knowledge of the Orchestration service including how to write templates, knowledge of Hadoop and other big data use cases, as well as how to deploy a Big Data workload on an OpenStack cloud.

schedule.title: Project Update - Triple0
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Triple0 and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Triple0 plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

 

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Triple0 PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Compose Hardware Resources On The Fly with OpenStack Valence
schedule.description:
In the face of ever-growing data processing requirements, existing data center infrastructures struggle to deliver on flexibility and TCO expectations. Intel Rack Scale Design Technology is to evolve the data center design methodology from physical resource aggregation to resource pools and eventually target for future’s service aware orchestration. Meanwhile, as a ubiquitous cloud OS that able to control/orchestrate large pools of compute, storage and network resources, OpenStack can take advantages of it to deliver more optimized flexibility and performance against cost in areas such as deep learning, big data, telecom, etc.
Valence is a new OpenStack project announced in Barcelona Summit which is a collection of all things about RSD for OpenStack. In this session, we’ll elaborate valence’s mission, user cases and status. And then, we’ll discuss how other projects can leverage RSD by integration with valence. Finally, we'll show some live demos about how valence works right now.
schedule.social_description: Compose Hardware Resources On The Fly with OpenStack Valence
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• What's OpenStack Valence?
  • How does valence integrate with other OpenStack project?
  • What's the use case and key value by using valence?

schedule.title: OpenStack 360° - A holistic approach to finding "your" OpenStack
schedule.description:
In this talk we like to outline some patterns that are common across all the different distributions and deployment tools available in the market. Having deployed numerous OpenStack environments with different distributions and tools, we have found some interesting points that you will find on all on them.

This is not meant to be as an evaluation or benchmark of these distributions and tools, but we try to give you some important hints on where you should look and which questions you should ask on your journey to finding the perfect distribution and management tool for your own environment.
schedule.social_description: Common patterns found across various tools and distributions
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Learn where to look, what questions to ask and how to build your decision matrix when it comes to choosing your OpenStack distribution and/or deployment and management tool.

schedule.title: OpenStack in Motion: Live Migration
schedule.description: Live migration is a feature that many companies moving their applications into OpenStack clouds are requesting. Persuading enterprise customers to embrace OpenStack as their IaaS solution requires highly available VMs for their workloads. OpenStack developers insist that live migration is continuing to evolve with additional components being added and in turn, becoming more dependable. We, the Operations team inside the OpenStack Innovation Center, embraced the opportunity to test and demonstrate the high availability of virtual machines during live migration and provide feedback to the OpenStack community on areas that have opportunity to make further strides. Come join us in this session to see how we benchmarked live migration, our discoveries, projected next steps, and the ideal setup for your cloud to have an exceedingly available environment.
schedule.social_description: Benchmarking live migration in OpenStack: tool, tests and results
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
a demo on how to use the live migrator tool.

Live migration status in OpenStack and best setup for a reliable live migration experience.

schedule.title: Why Does My Volume Attach Fail!?!
schedule.description: Attaching and disconnecting Cinder volumes to Nova/Ironic instances is a complex process that can go wrong for many reasons. Problems arise from issues from the cinder backends to discovering volumes showing up on the host. Problems with the underlying Operating System or Iscsi subsytem affect os-brick. Corner cases like Nova live migration, shelf offload, and boot from volume complicate matters. We will take a deep dive into where the common problems come from and how to look for them.
schedule.social_description: Why Does My Volume Attach Fail!?!-Debugging Cinder Volume attachment and detachment failures.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees can expexct to understand the code flow that is exected between Cinder, Nova and os-brick during a volume attachment or detachment.  They will be introduced to the relevant log files to debug failures in that code path and the meaning of the debug messages they may see.  Finally examples of how to recover from problems during attachment and detachment will be covered.

Note that this presentation adds to and updates the content covered in link #1 below.

schedule.title: Tricks of the trade to achieve 5 9’s of data plane availability on OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description:
Virtual Network functions leveraged by Telco and enterprise demands 5 9’s of availability (5.26 Minutes downtime per year) and also higher data plane throughput per VM.

SR-IOV is commonly used method to support maximum possible throughput by the Server and Network interface card in the Server. SR-IOV bypass the hypervisor and takes away the Live and offline migration features which can be used during server failures to move VM to another server.

In addition; AT&T used several tricks of the trade to achieve higher availability ( 5 9’s) of VNFs on 3 9’s OpenStack cloud instance such as automated placement of Virtual functions, Control loop fault detection and auto recovery, etc.,

In this talk, we will share all the methods we have tried so far to achieve higher reliability of virtual network functions using one of the large OpenStack cloud deployment in the world.
schedule.social_description: Tricks of the trade to achieve 5 9’s of data plane availability on OpenStack Cloud
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn all the methods AT&T has leveraged to run highly reliable virtual network functions on top of OpenStack Cloud.

schedule.title: Panel From The Trenches: Will Containers Save Us?
schedule.description: Given the rate of adoption of container based infrastructure platforms, will there be a second renaissance for OpenStack? Our panel of experts will debate containerizing the world in the context of operations, deployment, and the more-important conference circuit. Given the options, wouldn't you rather see four people argue?
schedule.social_description: Panel of experts talks containers, scotch, and argues operations and deployment.

schedule.title: NTT West – How to operate efficiently OpenStack Provider Networks to leverage Ansible Network module
schedule.description:
Ansible is often used for automation and configuration management of OpenStack clouds.
We NTT West expand range in application of Ansible, not only servers but also physical network equipments.
It enables developers to manage whole resources of OpenStack clouds simply.
 
“Provider Networks” are likely to consists of physical network equipments which are not managed by OpenStack.
In environment like that, auto-healing and auto-scaling of instances are difficult.
The combination of Ansible and OpenStack makes it easy to connect configuration changes of instances and physical network.
 
This session introduces efficient way for management Provider Networks environment using Ansible.
schedule.social_description: This session introduces efficient way for management Provider Networks environment using Ansible.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
We can set up physical network equipment using Ansible.

  • VLAN settings and port settings of layer 2 switches
  • Port settings and routing settings of routers
  • ACL settings of firewalls
  • Load balancing control settings of load balancers

We can obtain the following effects by utilizing automation / configuration management function of Ansible.

  • Abolition of procedure manuals on the premise of manual work
  • Elimination of unintended settings by ensuring idempotency
  • Implement on-demand setting of physical NW devices in cooperation with orchestrator such as OpenStack

schedule.title: Challenges in Contributing OpenStack Support to Spinnaker
schedule.description: Last year Veritas engineers, in conjunction with Target engineers, worked to extend the multi cloud deployment tool Spinnaker to support deployments into OpenStack. Both teams use OpenStack for internal development. Our goal was to contribute a Spinnaker provider for OpenStack to leverage a hybrid cloud environment in our continuous delivery pipelines. We have completed this Spinnaker provider and have turned it over to other OpenStack users to test out. Along the way we encountered many challenges working within the OpenStack environment - such as documentation, feature deprecation and support of replacement features, and the configuration of single node OpenStack environments. We would like to share these challenges with the community so that others looking to add support for OpenStack in their tools can learn from our experience. We look forward to sharing our story and opening up the opportunity to collaborate further.
schedule.social_description: Extending tooling (Spinnaker) to support OpenStack is challenging and rewarding. Here's our story.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Along the way to contributing the OpenStack provider to Spinnaker, we encountered many challenges working within the OpenStack environment – such as documentation, feature deprecation and support of replacement features, and the configuration of single node OpenStack environments. Attendees will learn what problems we encountered, how we decided to mitigate them, and how the OpenStack ecosystem could evolve in the future to make building support for existing tools on top of it easier.

schedule.title: Participating in translation makes you an internationalized OpenStacker & developer
schedule.description:
Are you afraid to be involved in OpenStack community? Are you still hesitating to be an OpenStacker as you might think it’s too difficult for you to be a code contributor? Here is an opportunity for you to be an OpenStacker RIGHT NOW, RIGHT HERE.

You can start as an I18n translator if you 1) are comfortable with your native language and 2) have passion for localization. We have hands-on demonstrations and guidance on how to be a translator for your native language.

By starting your contributor path with I18n team, you will not only just contribute to translations, but also deal with translation bugs and bugs from original source strings, and get more knowledge on your favorite OpenStack official projects which support translation.

We are sure that starting your contributions from and with translation will make you an internationalized OpenStacker and developer.
schedule.social_description: Here is an opportunity for you to be an OpenStacker RIGHT NOW, RIGHT HERE.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The talk targets the people:

- who really would like to participate in translation

- who already found some original text/terms/expressions bugs and want to fix them

- who would like to report translation bugs via OpenStack Launchpad

- who want to know how to mingle translation and OpenStack projects development

- who will be an internationalized developer with I18n support

schedule.title: Project Update - Telemetry
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Telemetry and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Telemetry plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

 

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Telemetry PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: ironic and SDN integration in large-scale bare metal servers cloud
schedule.description:
This topic focus on the challenges we have faced in Ironic and SDN integration.
Recently we undertook several projects in order to build an enterprise private cloud with about 5K+ bare metal servers. The most challenge is Ironic and neutron network integration:
1. NOT support vxlan & port group.
3. We evaluate network-generic-switch driver, so far only support parts of the switch vendors with a limitation of the functionality.
4. Switching from provision network to tenant network is not easy.
In order to meet the core networking requirement, we evaluate SDN solutions with several major SDN vendors, including HUAWEI, ZTE, H3C and Nuage Network. Thanks to our deep cooperation, from Solution Selection to Proof of Concept and finally to Final Acceptance Test, we finally integrated Ironic with SDN solution, thus enables network automation and provisioning. Besides, we successfully used dynamic port group and flexible security group to enable high availability and high security features.
schedule.social_description: How to integrate Ironic with SDN solutions.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. The key considerations when ironic integrated with SDN.
2. The key changes when ironic integrated with SDN.
3. The difficulties and solutions when ironic integrated with ZTE SDN solution.
4. The difficulties and solutions when ironic integrated with HUAWEISDN solution.
5. The difficulties and solutions when ironic integrated with Nuage SDN solution.
6. The difficulties and solutions when ironic integrated with H3C SDN solution.

schedule.title: Get hands-on with Vitrage, the fault management service for Root Cause Analysis and Deduced Alarms
schedule.description:
Are you a cloud admin managing a large deployment, struggling with fault management in your system? Or an OpenStack distro vendor seeking to help your customers deal with increasingly complex fault scenarios in their production environments?
Vitrage is an official OpenStack project, designed to organize, visualize and analyze faults in your Cloud. To do this, it provides features like Root Cause Analysis and Deduced Alarms, in a clear, user friendly interface that makes complex networks easily and visually understood.
In this hands-on lab, our core developers will present an overview of what Vitrage is all about and provide an update on all the new features and technologies since the last release. You will be guided through the process of installing, configuring and experimenting with Vitrage on your own laptop. By the end of this session, you will know how to personalize Vitrage for your own system structure and needs; Enough to "make it your own".
schedule.social_description: Get hands-on with Vitrage, the fault management service for Root Cause Analysis and Deduced Alarms
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this deep dive, hands-on lab session, participants will learn all about the Vitrage OpenStack project, and will get up to speed on actually installing, configuring and experimenting with Vitrage on their own laptops. By the end of this session, participants will know how to personalize Vitrage for their own system structure and needs; Enough to "make it their own"

schedule.title: Control Plane Architectures: Design Solutions
schedule.description:
Building an OpenStack private cloud can be very complex.  Underpinning the entire operational capabilities of your cloud is the Control Plane.  It's common knowledge you should treat your cloud resources "like cattle" and not "pets", yet most clouds treat the control plane like a favored pet.
How should the modern cloud architect choose to design the control plane aspect of your private cloud? 
Attendees of this presentaion should walk away with a grasp of various architectures for managing the design and build out of your Control Plane, and know where each architecture would best fit depending on your needs and cloud scale.
We will discuss designs for building and managing your Control Plane: 
  * standalone single server
  * active/passive 
  * multi-node active/active
  * distributed 
Each has their own trade off and relevance depending on your goals.  This presentation will help guide you in considering the models available and help you to make a decision for your cloud platform.
schedule.social_description: Control Plane Architecture can make or break your cloud - learn the best architecture for your C.P.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn various different design patterns that can be applied to Highly Available system.  How each of these patterns relate to the OpenStack Control Plane and help guide the decision process to select an architecture that will provide the benefits based on the pros/cons of each design.

schedule.title: Who reads books anymore? Or writes them?
schedule.description:
Writing a book is an unbelievably daunting task. In a world of 140-character communication, why bother churning out 200 pages of technical content? In this session, we'll talk about why people still write technical books, what the process looks like, and why these books are still worth reading. If you're thinking about writing a book about OpenStack (or even just reading a book about OpenStack), this session will offer essential tips on everything from chosing a topic to working with a publisher.

We faced a number of challenges while writing our book, "OpenStack for Architects," which was recently published by Packt. We'll walk through the hard parts, the lessons that we learned, and what we'd do differently the next time around.
schedule.social_description: In this session we talk about why people still write technical books and how they do it.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How to choose a compelling topic for a new technical book.
  • How to go about actually writing the book.
  • When and how to get help from friends and colleagues.
  • How to work efficiently with a publisher.

schedule.title: Openstack and VMware getting the best of both.
schedule.description:
Come and understand the true value to your organisation of combining Openstack and VMware. In this session you will understand the value of having a defcore / Openstack powered solution to enable your developers to provision IaaS, in a way that they want, using the tools that they want. In addition you will be able to enable your operations team to continue to utilise the tools, resources and methodology that they use to ensure that your organisation has a production grade environment to support your developers.

Deploying Openstack, and getting the advantages of Openstack does not need to be a rip and replace strategy. See how other customers have had their cake and eat it.
schedule.social_description: Come and understand the true value to your organisation of combining Openstack and VMware.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: They will understand that Openstack and VMware are not conflicting worlds that can never meet. By combining the two they get something that Openstack and VMware cant deliver on their own.

schedule.title: Dirty Clouds Done Dirt Cheap
schedule.description:
The OpenStack mission statement lists the goals of OpenStack as: "easy to use, simple to implement, interoperable between deployments, works well at all scales" Yet, most of the attention gets placed on large deployments and how OpenStack is used for massive clouds. But, how does it work for an individual wanting to deploy a cloud with their own resources?

I've wanted to build a small cloud at home for some time, mostly to serve as a testbed for my development on OpenStack, but also as a platform to virtualize my growing home infrastructure. So I allocated a budget of ~$1500 USD (the price of my first desktop computer) and set out to build a cloud.

This talk will provide an overview of my experience building a small compute cloud from scratch, on essentially a shoestring budget; from hardware acquisition, through installation and configuration of the cloud, to my use cases for the cloud. I will also highlight some pain points for the small deployer and discuss how we can fix them.
schedule.social_description: Can OpenStack be used to build a personal cloud at home for ~$1500 USD?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can expect to learn the requirements and steps for building a small OpenStack cloud by hand. From the acquisition of hardware, through the installation of software and configuration of the cloud. As part of this some potential pain points for the small deployer will be highlighted.The talk will also cover some of the potential applications and advantages of having a home cloud, and the reasons why someone would (or wouldn't) want to do this.

schedule.title: A road to open-source: from a closed space to outside world
schedule.description:
The journey of opening a source code is always a challenge. It's like getting out of an escape room, a winding road with twists and turns. And like an escape room, it demands quite an effort and gives lots of fun.

In this presentation we open the door, share our experience and lessons learned during opening a proprietary Cinder driver. We review OpenStack open source policy in general and its implementation for specific projects. We discuss the reasons for opening the source code, and address the community discussions pertinent to the decision process.

The presentation includes the caveats and obstacles for such a move. Some of them are common to all new drivers, and some are unique for transition from a closed to open source. Step by step we overcome the obstacles (legal, business, standards, CI) and change of work flows. We conclude with a discussion of the benefits of being part of the community and adhering to its standards. Together we unlock the door to an open new world.
schedule.social_description: Opening source code is like getting out of an escape room, a winding road with many twists

schedule.title: Pushing the Boundaries of OpenStack – Wait, what are they again?
schedule.description:
Have you ever been curious as to how much of a workload the OpenStack control plane can handle before needing to scale horizontally?  Based on the load how will the API performance adjust?  How much overhead will load on the OpenStack API’s add to my application deployment timeline?  What behavior should I look for to determine its time to add more control plane resources?

These are just a few questions I have been asked and/or have come to my mind while operating OpenStack clouds.  While performing API benchmarking can be measured in so many different ways, it does feel like a good idea to have some high level frame of reference.  I will start off stating that there are about a million ways to measure performance.  Your approach may differ from what I have done and that is actually expected.  The tests conducted are meant to provide a starting reference for you to possibly build upon.
schedule.social_description: Test the boundaries of OpenStack by conducting a series of test against the OpenStack API's.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Learn how to create OpenStack API test scripts
  • Determined what metrics matter the most
  • Possible tools you can use to run your tests
  • Finally share my results from the tests run earlier

schedule.title: Hotfix a 1000+ node Openstack cluster serving huge volumes of PRODUCTION traffic, within minutes!!
schedule.description:
Cloud deployments, specially the private ones, can have one or more unique requirements, which might not be coming default with Openstack. It will definetly need some customization and once we start customizing, we inherently need a way to update the cloud as and when required, be it to fix something nasty or to introduce a new feature altogether. Now imagine applying a fix across a datacenter comprising of 1000+ infra nodes hosting tens of thousands of VMs and IN PRODUCTION. Thats scary!

But at Snapdeal.com - India, we do this with ease. We exploit the loosely coupled nature of Openstack services and some cool features of Ansible to make it happen, in a matter of few minutes, that too without any application downtime.

In this session we will be sharing the best practices and our experiences on how we incrementally update our customized Openstack cloud in Production, with fixes as and when we want to, without the users really knowing that something is being fixed backstage.
schedule.social_description:
Roll out updates/fixes to Openstack Cloud deployments.
#UpdateOpenstack #NoDownTime
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will be getting a glimpse on how we roll out updates to our production cloud being run using Openstack without any application downtime. They will get to learn the tips and tricks of the update process which can help them update their deployments as well.

schedule.title: High availablity and scalability management of VNF
schedule.description:
Now network function virtualization(NFV) is growing rapidly and widely adopted by many telcom enterprises. In openstack Tacker takes the responsibility of building a Generic VNF Manager (VNFM) and a NFV Orchestrator (NFVO) to deploy and operate Network Services and Virtual Network Functions (VNFs) on the infrastructure platform. For the VNFs which can work as a loadbalancer or a firewall, Tacker needs to consider the availability of each VNF to ensure they are not overloaded or out of work. To prevent VNFs from being overloaded or down, Tacker need to make VNFs HA and auto-scaling. So in fact the VNFs of certain function should not be a single node, but a cluster.

That comes out a problem of cluster managing. In OpenStack environment there is a Clustering service called Senlin which provides scalability management and HA functions for the nodes, those features are exactly fit for Tacker's requirement.

In this talk we will give you a general introduction of this feature.
schedule.social_description: This presentation introduces how to use Senlin service to manage VNFs in Tacker.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this talk we introduce a way to build a high available and auto-scalable VNF cluster by integrating Senlin to Tacker project.

schedule.title: Strategies to Foster Diversity and Inclusion in the OpenStack Community
schedule.description: The technology industry has been a major source of innovation and economic growth, but its ability to encourage diversity among its ranks lags. In 2016, women and underrepresented minorities accounted for 30% of the larger tech industry, while comprising 11% and nearly 10% of the OpenStack and Linux communities, respectively. On the upside, data suggests that this same population accounted for 9% of all OpenStack activity, as compared to 6.8% of all Linux activity. To harness the full power of technology to tackle a broader set of societal challenges will depend, in part, on our ability to encourage a diversity of ideas, experiences and talent. Join us for an interactive panel discussion as we explore the numbers and what they mean, and in turn, discuss concrete, actionable steps that we can collectively take to foster a diverse, inclusive environment within the OpenStack community.
schedule.social_description: Gain actionable steps to foster a diverse, inclusive environment within the OpenStack community.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees should expect to gain:

1. Clear insight into the data that indicates that the technology industry continues to languish in its ability to encourage diversity among its ranks.

2. An understanding of the numbers, specifically in relation to diversity & inclusion in the OpenStack community, as compared to the Linux community. For example, where is diversity flourishing vs. lagging in the OpenStack community, along with some potential causes.

3.  An interactive discussion of concrete, actionable steps that we can collectively take to foster a diverse, inclusive environment within the OpenStack community.

schedule.title: Helping Customers Migrate Workloads from Amazon Web Services to an OpenStack Private Cloud
schedule.description:
IT organizations are implementing and defining their strategy around which cloud is most appropriate to host what workload. However, a cloud-first strategy and a desire to consume infrastructure as a service has led to many workloads being deployed on clouds that may not be the ideal choice. With many facets to the financial costs of hosting workloads including physical compute/networking/storage resources and human expertise, we have found that many customers are seeing significant savings when they migrate their long running or always on workloads running in public clouds back on-premises.

This session focuses on how an OpenStack private cloud has distinct cost advantages over an AWS given certain workload requirements.  More specifically, we’ll highlight a customer use case leveraging Rackspace Private Cloud powered by Red Hat in the data center of their choosing to host their heavy utilization and high network bandwidth workloads with significant cost savings compared to AWS.
schedule.social_description: Learn how a managed OpenStack private cloud can have distinct cost advantages over AWS.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How the analysis was performed
  • Considerations in technological differences
  • Migration strategy
  • Life after migration

schedule.title: Project Update - Trove
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Trove and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Trove plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Trove PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Snap this!  Making snapshots vastly more useful in Manila & Cinder
schedule.description:
Both Cinder and Manila have always supported creating snapshots of volumes & file shares. But the only action users could take with snapshots was to create new volumes/shares from them. While a valuable use case, other scenarios demand alternate snapshot workflows.

We will explore and demonstrate three primary cloud snapshot semantics in Manila and the use cases they satisfy. We will also note progress in Cinder towards the same.

  • Create share from snapshot. Useful for DevOps, testing, cloning from templates, and training.
  • Revert share to snapshot. When widespread issues occur, such as filesystem corruption or malware infection, the best solution is to turn back the clock to before the problem occurred.
  • Mount share snapshot. For quickly accessing and restoring previous versions of your files without any additional resource consumption.

We will cover the pros and cons of these approaches, as well as best practices to ensure data can be recovered in the most efficient way.
schedule.social_description: Learn how to best use the newly introduced snapshot semantics for file shares in Manila.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn several things:

  • What snapshots are and what use cases exist for snapshots in cloud storage
  • What has always been possible with Manila and Cinder snapshots, and why that does not satisfy all use cases
  • How Manila and Cinder have evolved to support additional snapshot-based workflows
  • How to use the new snapshot semantics available in Manila

schedule.title: Verizon Case Study: The illusion of infinite capacity
schedule.description: The total cost of ownership for an OpenStack private cloud can be half of other infrastructure alternatives. The key to achieving such a goal is to capture relevant metrics and watch them closely.  Such metrics become new word KPIs in the enterprise; it is these metrics that support the evolution for cloud services to becoming mission critical.  Allowing such metrics to manifest as KPIs in pleasant and intuitive ways encourages good behavior of tenants and their supporting business unit as the business maximizes the potential of the investment.  At scale, this can be realized with real-time dashboards, self-service workflows, tools to assist in right-sizing resources, and reporting for operators, financial managers, and executives. Tenants need cost estimates for budget forecasts, while executives need chargeback data to justify additional investment in the OpenStack environment.
schedule.social_description: Verizon Case Study: The illusion of infinite capacity for OpenStack private cloud
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
An agile, cost effective cloud deployment must maintain the illusion of infinite capacity while maximizing the effective utilization and potential of the underlying infrastructure.  Tenants expect to be able to spin up and spin down resources on demand with no concern for the underlying physical build. Operating an efficient OpenStack cloud requires total visibility into historical trending for resource requests and capacity balancing to support active workloads, passive workloads, migratory workloads and capacity planning for projections of current workloads as well as future workloads.

Verizon and Talligent will share lessons learned managing cloud use, distribution, costs and growth for the tenants in a hyperscale global OpenStack private cloud environment.

schedule.title: Testing & Tuning Hyperconverged OpenStack
schedule.description:
OpenStack clusters are most often built with servers for Nova compute VMs and servers for storage, with Ceph storage requring 3 or more nodes. It can be more cost-effective to "hyperconverge" Nova and Ceph on to the same servers, and rising processor core counts and RAM density have made this feasible. But it is important to understand the resource demand patterns of each and protect against corner cases where one starves the other. We will present an empirical approach to:

  • Generating realistic system & storage loads using open source test suites
  • Collecting and analyzing results quantitatively
  • Optimizing hardware configuration and resource partitioning

We will present data, analysis, and lessons learned from our hyperconverged infrastructure work.
schedule.social_description: Tune your hyperconverged OpenStack to run smoothly using open source testing tools.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the technical challenges of hyperconverged OpenStack, about means of testing and stressing hyperconverged, and about tuning resource protections to provide a well-running OpenStack.

schedule.title: Cloud orchestration made easy - Getting started with HEAT
schedule.description:
Heat is the OpenStack orchestration component similar to CloudFormation from AWS. Heat is providing the ability to deploy instances, volumes and other OpenStack services using YAML based templates. It allows to describe your infrastructure as code.

This session will give an brief introduction on how to get started with Heat. We will explain some terminology and fundamentals first.
And then show how to build simple OpenStack Heat Templates (HOT).
We will  demonstrate how easy it is to deploy your own Application like  typical LAMP stack with Wordpress.


In a short live demo, we will show how to deploy a template to public OpenStack clouds, like our Open Telekom Cloud.
schedule.social_description: Cloud orchestration made easy: Hands-on session for Heat beginners
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
* Introduction to Heat

* Writing Heat templates (HOT syntax)

* How to deploy simple Heat stacks from the command line and dashboard

schedule.title: Requirement Analysis of VIM Platform Reliability in a Three-Layer Decoupling Environment for NFV
schedule.description:
In an NFV scenario, the VIM platform needs to cooperate with other components under the ETSI-MANO architecture to achieve the same level of reliability assurance as traditional hardware equipments.

NFVI/VIM should detect hardware health status and VNF health status directly or in-directly. It is on demand to integrate all these information to MANO. At the same time the platform needs to be able to receive fault-handling decisions from MANO and take action accordingly.

Faults of the platform components should not have impact on the VMs and business-related processes.

As for fault-handling for hosts VMs and business networks, the platform should be combined with the protection mechanism of the business VMs themselves and ensure the relocated VMs to enjoy the same enhanced features (such as CPU pinning IO-NUMA etc) as before.

The presentation will also analyze the impact of several different types of failure and several solutions according to our test results.
schedule.social_description: NFV brings new challenges for openstack to achieve the same level HA as traditional equipments.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Common reliability strategy of traditional telecom network elements
  • The general HA mechanisms of VIM (openstack) platform for now
  • What new requirements are brought to VIM platform in the ETSI-MANO structure for a telecom-level high availability
  • The impact of various types of failures on the VMs and business programs. And some fault handling strategies performed by VIM and MANO according to our test results.

schedule.title: OpenStack on Kubernetes - one year after
schedule.description:
When we started preparing our demo of Stackanetes for Austin Summit, we had a simple goal - “show the community it is possible.” So we started from the kolla-mesos project (who even remembers that now?) and somehow brought it to the Kubernetes world.

Right now, there are several community projects around the deployment of OpenStack on Kubernetes: Stackanetes, Fuel-CCP, openstack-helm, kolla-kubernetes and more. As we were involved in all of them we would like to show that all of those projects are more similar than different. During this presentation we will show how the “kubification” of complex solutions like OpenStack is defined by the development pace of Kubernetes rather than the application itself.
schedule.social_description: How Kubernetes is defining OpenStack deployments - from kolla-mesos to production.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendes will learn why OpenStack on Kubernetes gaines so much friction. We will cover the evolution of this technology and how Kubernetes new features define the deployments of OpenStack. We will show that projects aiming at deploying OpenStack on top of Kubernetes are more alike than different.

schedule.title: The past, the present, and the future of "OpenStack Interoperability"
schedule.description:
If OpenStack wants to the define THE standard for open source cloud interfaces, interoperability between multiple OpenStack implementations is key. But it's also been one of the most challenging areas.

At the last OpenStack summit in Barcelona, Jonathan Bryce hosted a live demo of 16 vendors running the same workload on various OpenStack clouds (both private and public) on stage during his keynote. The demo was well received and marked a significant milestone of the community achieving the vision of OpenStack Interoperability. However, a lot more work remains to be done.

In this panel, we will have some community leaders who are deeply involved in interoperability work and large cloud customers/users join the panel and share their views on what we have done as a community in the area of interoperability, the current state of interoperability, the gaps that need to be addressed, and brainstorm on how we can address them in order to reach the next level of OpenStack interoperability.
schedule.social_description: We will discuss Openstack interoperability, the current state, the gaps, and how we address them.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees who care about interoperability, hybrid cloud type of issues in Openstack should attend. This panel will give some overview on what we're doing in Interop WG (formerly known as Defcore) and interoperability challenge;  and discuss what customers/users are looking for in Openstack interoperability.

schedule.title: Verisign's production cloud upgrade journey from Icehouse to Liberty
schedule.description: Growing from a proof of concept cloud platform to a multi-region production grade offering, Verisign’s OpenStack cloud has become a key infrastructure for the business. Transitioning from a package based deployment of the Icehouse release, to a stream lined containerization of all the Liberty control plane components, this was the only natural progression to tackle such a complex upgrade.While containerization gave a huge over haul to the control plane operations, there was an urgent need to offer higher availability at the network layer. Seeing the need to spread the failure domain at the physical network layer, we moved to a horizontally scalable topology using VXLAN on the TOR switches.Between the upgrade of OpenStack components and network changes, the upgrade methodology exercised helped us maintain an average downtime of 15 mins across thousands of instances. This talk covers our upgrade methodology, architecture changes and lessons learned as Verisign plays amongst the clouds.
schedule.social_description: Verisign covers deployment methodology/architecture changes/lessons learned upgrading to Liberty.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will come away with an understanding of how the Verisign operations team performed an in place upgrade of production regions from Icehouse to Liberty without taking extended outages.  The presentation will relay the pit falls that were seen during the upgrade process, the technology challenges that were experienced jumping between releases and how containerization played a key role in getting over these hurdles.

Additionally attendees will gain an understanding of the restrictions of a network rack centric topology to a horizontally scalable design using a VXLAN overlay.

schedule.title: How an Interop Capability becomes part of the OpenStack Interop Guidelines
schedule.description: OpenStack Interop Working Group (formerly DefCore) produces the OpenStack Powered (TM) Guidelines (a.k.a. Interoperability Guidelines). But, how do we decide what goes into the guideline? How do we define these so called "Capabilities"? And how does the team "score" them? Attend this session to learn what we mean by "Capability", the requirements a capability must meet, the process the group follows to grade those capabilities... And, you know what, lets score $your_favorite_thing live.
schedule.social_description: Capabilities are the base for the Interop Guidelines. Learn the what and how to score them

schedule.title: Behind the Scenes with Placement and Resource Tracking in Nova
schedule.description:
The Placement API service was introduced in Nova in Mitaka and in Ocata is now a required part of an OpenStack deployment. This presentation will cover the design of the resource provider data modeling that acts as the foundation for new scheduling and resource tracking functionality designed to serve Nova and other OpenStack service projects.

Attendees will walk through the different resource tracking subsystems in Nova, learning how information is passed between Nova compute agents, the Placement API, the Nova scheduler and conductor, and the hypervisor systems. Understand how providers of shared resources, such as shared storage pools, work with the system to reflect accurate resource reporting and scheduling decision-making.
schedule.social_description: Want a master class on Nova scheduler and resource tracking contribution? Attend this class.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about the following:

  • How and what information is passed between Nova's many internal subsystems that track resource inventory and usage
  • The implementation of Placement API service; how it's different from the Nova API service and how it's similar
  • The data modeling schema behind the Placement service
  • Crazy Acts of SQL Science: see the SQL Join-fu behind the Placement service's decision-making queries
  • The way that accounting of resources is made in a transactional manner that tolerates multiple concurrent decision-makers

schedule.title: Building Efficient HPC Clouds with MVAPICH2 and OpenStack over SR-IOV enabled InfiniBand Clusters
schedule.description:
Single Root I/O Virtualization (SR-IOV) technology has been steadily gaining
momentum for high-performance interconnects such as InfiniBand. SR-IOV can
deliver near-native performance but lacks locality-aware communication support.
This talk presents an efficient approach to building HPC clouds based on MVAPICH2
over OpenStack with SR-IOV. We discuss high-performance designs of the virtual
machine and container aware MVAPICH2 library over OpenStack-based HPC Clouds
with SR-IOV. The talk will also present a high-performance virtual machine
migration framework for MPI applications on SR-IOV enabled InfiniBand clouds.
A comprehensive performance evaluation with micro-benchmarks and HPC
applications on NSF-supported Chameleon Cloud, which is developed on OpenStack,
shows that our design can deliver near the bare-metal performance. The MVAPICH2
over OpenStack software package presented in this talk is publicly available
from http://mvapich.cse.ohio-state.edu.
schedule.social_description: Building Efficient HPC Clouds through MVAPICH2 and OpenStack with SR-IOV enabled InfiniBand
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees can learn from following aspects:

a. What are the performance benefits of SR-IOV and its limitations on locality-aware inter-VM communication within the same physical node?

b. How to design a high-performance MPI library to efficiently take advantage of novel features such as SR-IOV and IVShmem provided in HPC clouds?

c. How to build an HPC Cloud with virtual machines and containers to deliver near-native performance for MPI applications over SR-IOV enabled InfiniBand clusters?

d. How much performance improvement can be achieved by our proposed design on MPI point-to-point operations, collective operations and applications in HPC clouds?

e. Can a high-performance virtual machine migration framework for MPI applications on SR-IOV enabled InfiniBand clouds can be designed? How fast is it?

schedule.title: Henan Province Health Cloud Platform: Multi-Region Management
schedule.description:
Henan province locates in the central of china, it was once the original place where Chinese culture was born. And now it’s also a big province in china with the population exceeds 100 million.

Henan Province heath cloud platform adopted “1+18” mode, which means one central primary cloud platform and 18 secondary cloud platform. The central cloud platform will host the core application, monitor all the other datacenters in a unified way, besides the central datacenter will also provide the backup resource for the secondary sites. The secondary sites were distributed across multiple cities in Henan province, and running the application of the local site. In case of single failure of the central site, the customer also built a backup site on the same city, and a DR site on the 3rd city.
schedule.social_description: Henan Province Health Cloud Platform: Multi-Region Management
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Each datacenter has at least one OpenStack platform deployed, and all the OpenStack platform were connected through the open standard API. There were numerous “old” equipment existed in traditional datacenter, to save the cost, the cloud datacenter also integrated these devices by developing plug-in.

Henan province health cloud platform benefits the public a lot, making it easier for the people to get the information and share the medical service.

schedule.title: State and future of the Chargeback using the OpenStack's integrated solution : cloudkitty
schedule.description:
Cloudkitty is the rating and chargeback component of OpenStack. Since it has entered the Big Tent a few cycles ago it is a good time do do a full review of it current state and future.

In this talk we will introduce :

  • A global description of Cloudkitty's architecture and capabilities
  • Introduction to built-in plugins (collectors, rating, storage)
  • Demonstration of Horizon integration and configuration scenario
  • Description of future changes and features for the Pike cycle

CloudKitty is getting integrated by more and more OpenStack clouds around the world so why not yours?
schedule.social_description: State and future of the Chargeback using the OpenStack's integrated solution : cloudkitty
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this talk attendees will learn :

  • what is chargeback and what is Cloudkitty, the component that deals with it in OpenStack
  • A global description of Cloudkitty's architecture and capabilities
  • Introduction to built-in plugins (collectors, rating, storage)
  • Demonstration of Horizon integration and configuration scenario
  • Description of future changes and features for the Pike cycle

schedule.title: Project Update - Vitrage
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Vitrage and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Vitrage plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Vitrage PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Mistral performance in numbers
schedule.description: In an OpenStack environment using Mistral as the workflow engine seems to be a natural choice. It is integrated with most OpenStack services, it has a simple, powerful and easy to use descriptor language. But "will it blend" in with the expectations? Does it perform well? It is reliable? Does it scale? We will try to answer these and many more questions in this presentation. Let the numbers speak.
schedule.social_description: See how Mistral performs under various conditions.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: An objective and thorough analysis of the performance of Mistral.

schedule.title: Multi-site OpenStack - Deployment options and challenges for a telco
schedule.description:
OpenStack provides a great Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) platfrom for deployment of applciations in virtual machines and containers. For telcos specifically, OpenStack unifies the point of presence (PoP), central office, and datacenter infrastructure. However, many telcos need OpenStack deployed in many datacenters around the region or country. The question is how should they deploy OpenStack for multi-site needs?

Should they consider stretched deployment where different components sit in different locations? Or should they consider replicating the entire OpenStack environment in each location? What impact does this have for Keystone, messaging, disaster recovery, and more importantly, unified management of all these sites?

This presentation will discuss architectural and deployment options for multi-site deployments of OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: Learn about Distributed Deployment of Openstack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Multi-site Openstack deployment

schedule.title: Firehose: A unified message bus for Infra services
schedule.description:
Development and testing of the OpenStack project operates at a tremendous scale, with hundreds of code repositories and thousands of contributors interacting continuously. The infrastructure to support this has to operate at an equally large scale to ensure that it is not outpaced by the volume of upstream development activity.

Accordingly, enabling users and other consumers to see what is happening in realtime in this increasingly complex infrastructure becomes equally complex and large. This is why we need interfaces available to develop tooling to handle this. During Newton we introduced firehose.openstack.org to provide a unified message bus. Built using MQTT and Mosquitto, firehose is an interface where Infra's services can publish events.

This talk will cover the origin and background behind the firehose, how it's constructed and used by Infra, and also explain the benefits to the wider community and how they can use it for their own needs, experimentation and innovation.
schedule.social_description: Firehose provides a unified message bus for OpenStack infra services to communicate on.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can expect to learn what the OpenStack community infrastructure unified message bus is, how it works, how to use it, and what they can gain by using it. Hopefully it will also empower the audience to contribute to the tooling around it and build on top of the messages and events being publish from firehouse.openstack.org.

schedule.title: The COA and Why You Should Take It
schedule.description: At the Austin Summit, the OpenStack Foundation officially introduced the Certified OpenStack Administrator exam. In the almost 10 months since it's release approximately 700 people have taken the exam. This panel would like to present reasons why you should take the exam and what benefits the exam could have for you. The panel will be made up of a hiring manager, an Ops and a Dev to give attendees a more rounded view of the exam.
schedule.social_description: Why the Certified OpenStack Administrator exam is for you
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: They should learn the benefits of taking the Certified OpenStack Administrator exam and additional reasons for taking it.

schedule.title: Openstack-Kubernetes Integration, What is left?
schedule.description:
Containers along with next generation challenges such as orchestration and serverless computing continue to draw interest across the application developers and data center operator communities because of the enormous potential of the technology and the rapid pace of change.

When it comes to Containers and Openstack there are a lot of questions about Deployment, Networking, Storage and Identity Management with What are the problems faced when trying to integrate OpenStack with Kubernetes?

In this session we would like to cover about gaps and missing features while trying to deploy OpenStack with Kubernetes and run a fully functional cluster, Also how they relate to Openstack projects like Magnum and Kuryr.

We will be covering a demo of running your first containerized applications on Kubernetes running on top of OpenStack.
schedule.social_description: Openstack-Kubernetes Integration, What is left?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn the Strategies used in deploying Kubernetes with Openstack and problems faced with running a fully functional cluster.

We will be covering a  demo at the end of presentation on running containerized application on Kubernetes on top of OpenStack.

schedule.title: Toward Fog, Edge and NFV deployments -- Evaluating OpenStack WANwide
schedule.description:
Latency is a critical requirement for Internet Of Things and NFV/SDN applications that favors a more distributed Cloud Computing model deployed at the Edge. This model does not cope with the traditional vision that has been driving the development of OpenStack. Although some efforts such as multiple regions and Cells may allow operators to administrate these new infrastructures, there are no studies thatevaluate how OpenStack will behave in such a massively distributed context.


In this talk, we present results of a study focusing on the impact of Wide Area Network communications on real OpenStack deployments. To this aim, we extended the Enos framework to achieve performance experiments while doing traffic shaping. This is a joint work between the Performance and Massively Distributed Working Groups, following the Barcelona presentation. Experiments have been done over the Grid'5000 and Chameleon testbed. Our goal is to gather metrics to provide inputs to other OpenStack WGs.
schedule.social_description: Evaluating OpenStack WANWide, Fog, Edge and NFV infrastructure under the perspective of OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
While Fog, Edge and NFV infrastructures  are becoming more recognised, the question of using OpenStack to operate such infrastructures, in particular the performance/scalability of the system, is often debated. In this presentation, we will present a reproducible way to evaluate the performance of OpenStack at a WAN level.


Attendees may expect to learn:

  • Current scenarios to operate WANwide infrastructures with the vanilla code (from simple deployments to the multi-region use-case)
  • How to perform reproducible experiment campaigns thanks to the Enos framework?
  • Methodology to emulate network limitations in a WANwide deployment based on traffic shapping
  • Methodology and tools to benchmark an OpenStack deployment.
  • Preliminary results of the impact of the latency/bandwidth criteria on the behaviour of OpenStack

schedule.title: Behind the curtains – Predictable performance with Nova
schedule.description: A behind the scenes look at booting a virtual machine.  Examine what happens when a VM is launched and booted from Cinder volumes with Neutron ports and PCI-passthrough/SRIOV.  A great introduction to Nova and Neutron to help users understand what is happening and how different configuration changes impact the VM performance.  Kernel tweaks, Numa placement, optimizations available but not well known.  People working with OpenStack in Telecom or the Internet of Things in production or developing on top of OpenStack would benefit from this talk to better understand how all the pieces come together to successfully deploy a virtual machine for predictable performance and how to troubleshoot problems when things go wrong.
schedule.social_description: Behind the curtains – Predictable performance with Nova
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How to leverage OpenStack to deploy apps with predictable performance, leveraging all the great features of Nova.

schedule.title: OpenStack at Scale inside NetApp with Puppet
schedule.description:
Want to hear from how we've implemented OpenStack internally inside our engineering support organization?  How we're able to scale to over 7000 VM instances, 14,000 cores across 3 geographical regions (2 US, 1 India)?  Also how we're able to automate upgrades with Puppet between releases for a non-disruptive experience for our users?   If so, this session is for you! 

We will focus on a couple of key findings:

  • What influence the needs of our users had on the choice of the underlying compute, storage and networking layer
  • What challenges we faced when combining this new self-service environment with best practices of traditional IT and virtualization, with a focus on automation and ease-of-use for both our developers and our operators
  • How OpenStack challenges the status quo of support organizations, and where we are taking our internal deployment next
schedule.social_description: How NetApp has implemented OpenStack inside our engineering support organization with Puppet?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will hear real-world experiences of OpenStack deployments in the enterprise.  Not only will strategies for success be discussed, but also trials/tribulations and potential pitfalls and learnings so that other folks will not make the same mistakes.  Also the role of converged infrastructure in an OpenStack deployment and the scalability of the infrastructure will be stressed, with a concentration on how a traditional engineering support organization historically providing VMWare hosting tackles OpenStack operations and developer support as an internal function.

schedule.title: Security Hardening: PCI DSS and security compliance within Keystone
schedule.description:
As your cloud deployment grows and becomes more diverse, you may be required to meet certain security requirements. The Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) defines an industry standard for data security. All major credit card companies require applications that process and/or store credit card data, to meet PCI DSS requirements. And if a cloud application is required to be PCI compliant, then the underlying cloud will also need to be compliant.

Within Keystone, you will find that we have recently added new security compliance features to address PCI requirements. These features can be used to become PCI compliant or simply to harden your security practices within your cloud deployment.

Join us for a tour of these security features, including a live demonstration. Learn how you can improve security within your cloud and audit security events. In this talk, we will also discuss the options for new and existing deployments.
schedule.social_description: Security Hardening: PCI DSS and security compliance within Keystone
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will gain an understanding of PCI DSS and the new security compliance features in Keystone. They will understand the risks and the implications of these changes for both new and existing deployments. Attendees will understand how they can query and audit security events. Finally, they will learn how to configure security compliance in their deployments and become a PCI DSS Service Provider.

schedule.title: Migrating Legacy Monoliths to Cloud Native Microservices Architectures on Kubernetes
schedule.description:
Cloud Native architectures, such as those built on Kubernetes, are envied for their ability to segment different parts of an application into microservices that can separately be containerized, so that each microservice can be written in its own language, with its own framework, and its unique set of libraries. This has been shown to significantly increase developer and team productivity by decoupling dependencies between different parts of a team.

However, most legacy code consists of a large monolithic code base, not microservices applications. And, the lesson of second system syndrome is that many attempted code rewrites will end in failure, as the first system will evolve faster than the replacement system can be developed to displace it. A cloud native architecture that is only useful for new greenfield deployments is not very useful at all.
schedule.social_description: Migrating Legacy Monoliths to Cloud Native Microservices Architectures on Kubernetes
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
So, how can monoliths evolve into modern cloud native architectures, in order to take advantage of the dev ops revolution and the resulting developer productivity gains?

This talk will look at several real-world cases where existing monolithic, legacy applications deployed in multi-billion dollar companies were slowly evolved into cloud native microservices architectures on Kubernetes. They did so step-by-step, shaving off individual pieces of functionality into new applications that were packaged into new microservices applications, until the original monolith was eventually cut down to a reasonable size. In doing so, they demonstrated that the cloud native architecture is suitable across most categories of computing, including both greenfield and brownfield development.

schedule.title: Manila on CephFS at CERN: The Short Way to Production
schedule.description:
In response to the user demand for a light-weight provisioning of distributed file system shares,
the OpenStack and Ceph teams at CERN have recently added Manila/CephFS to their service catalogues.
While leveraging the operational experience with a 190'000 core OpenStack deployment and a 12 PB
Ceph cluster for such a self-service kiosque suggested itself, the service design and setup phases
were followed by a number of functionality and stress tests to ensure the individual components are
ready for production use. The final service design and the results obtained during the pre-production
phase, for instance when scaling to a large number of Manila and CephFS clients or the integration
with Magnum/Kubernetes, will be presented alongside the initial use cases and our first experiences
running these new services in production.
schedule.social_description: Manila/CephFS at CERN: Pre-production testing results and first production experiences.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The presentation will outline the steps taken by the OpenStack and Ceph teams at CERN to evaluate the readiness of Manila/CephFS for production use. Attendees will be guided through the service design and
setup, the functionality, stress and integration testing performed as well as the first operational experiences after production phase-in and (not to be forgotten) the hiccups and bugs found along the way.

schedule.title: Project Update - Zaqar
schedule.description:
Join the Project Team Leader of Zaqar and core contributors for a “project update” reflecting current developments in the Pike cycle and discussion of future development activity.

We dig into major issues and user needs, and how those needs can be addressed in current and future development. We also discuss hot topics from the Project Teams Gathering, and major development decisions agreed by the team.

Get an in-depth look at the top features and enhancements Zaqar plans to deliver in the Pike release in August. Then look beyond Pike to the Queens and “R” releases to learn more about major development themes such as scalability, manageability, resiliency and user experience that the team intends to tackle in the long term.

Developers who are interested in contributing to this project are strongly encouraged to attend, as are users and product managers who want to know more about this project’s latest features, their value to users, and the development team’s roadmap.

Questions and discussion are encouraged from the audience, and this presentation will become part of OpenStack’s project navigator at openstack.org/software/project-navigator.
schedule.social_description: Join the Zaqar PTL & core contributors for Pike cycle updates & discuss future developments.

schedule.title: Real-world Workload Generation: Your Pluggable Solution
schedule.description: The pain-point in real-world workload generation resulting from a lack in number and maturity of tools was seen as an opportunity for the Operations team within the OpenStack Innovation Center. With a heavy focus on testing, validation, research, and development, we created a tooling solution with the end-user, app-developer, and operator in mind. The work load generator not only assists in the benchmarking of a deployment, but also speeds up the creation of production workloads,  assists in cloud health checking, and is pluggable allowing workload customization. In this session we will discuss the tool's [design and] internals, along with a live demonstration of its functionality.
schedule.social_description: A real-workload generation tool. Exercise your OpenStack cloud with production-like workloads.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The importance of production-like workloads when testing, benchmarking, or even staging a cloud before going to production. Attendees will walk away knowing that with this tool, data plane workloads can be easily generateted and customized so users can create them based on their business needs.

schedule.title: OpenStack Kolla Ansible Hands-on Lab Session
schedule.description:
This hands-on lab session will provide an overview of OpenStack Kolla and deployment using Ansible and Docker Containers.  Each participant will get a virtualbox image (Kolla All-In-One).  Docker images created via Kolla-Build will be included.  The OpenStack environment is CentOS based with OVS bridge and LVM Cinder.


The hands-on lab will cover the following:

1) Take a look at the list of OpenStack docker containers
2) Create heat stack
     - Check that cinder volume can be attached to VM
     - Check that we are able to SSH and ping the VM
     - Look at log files in Heka container that are useful for troubleshooting

3) Destroy current environment and rebuild environment with Kolla Ansible playbooks

4) Go through basic configurations in globals.yml

5) Execute Kolla Health Check scripts to confirm successful redeployment

6) Kolla-Ansible multi-nodes deployment on KVM host
     - Multi-node configurations and local registry
     - Demo multimode deployment on KVM host
     - Create test VM
schedule.social_description: This hands-on lab session will provide an overview of Kolla (All-In-One) and Ansible deployment
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendee will gain an overview of OpenStack Kolla, Ansible and Docker Containers.  The lab session will allow participants to have hands-on experience on Kolla Ansible and Docker.

schedule.title: Cinder, it's not just for secondary attached storage any more!
schedule.description:
Cinder is pretty prevalent as secondary (attached storage) for Nova Instances.  What most people don't think about though is that it's also in many cases well suited for other uses in and out of the OpenStack eco system. This talk will focus on lesser known ways to use Cinder for all of the various storage needs in an  OpenStack Cloud.  We'll  use Cinder not only for secondary block storage, but also for storage of their ephemeral Nova Instances and even Glance images.
